I finally came back and tried out Sedanini All Credo. It was baked with pizza dough on top with really hot macaroni pasta, sausages, pecorino with good solid tomato sauce. This was really the highlight of the meal. The pizza dough was very good chewy tasty with good tomato contrast.

The wine Mazzoni Franceschi Toscana 07 that was a blend of Sangiovese and Merlot was a good pairing.

Also had the panna cotta with sour cherry "Amarene" sauce. It was on the more solid style panna cotta and I liked it quite a bit. The coffee that came with it was nice to round up the evening.

The wine buyer John Hurley came by and asked about the experience during the meal. I honestly mentioned about losing that appetizer dish Fritto Misto, which contained only 2 prawns and lots of squids, shaved vegetables plus 2 smaller pieces of artichoke that were all deep fried in some oil that had a stale taste and was just too heavy to almost greasy. I had to have some olives afterwards to cleanse my palate for the main course. He took it off the bill while I insisted not to for a while. Well, to thank for the nice gesture I topped the tip to include the dish since I think it's about good intentions of a place who listens to customers.
author: T L.

description:
I came here twice. The first time was a long time ago and it was during dine about town. The only item I remember was the delicious lasagna! When I came back a second time, I sadly discovered it was no longer on the menu! Apparently, there was a chef change. I did try the Squid ink Chiatara with Cherry Tomato, Fennel, Calabrian Chiles and Bottarga and that was pretty yummy. The new menu seems unfamiliar with the wait staff because we had a few questions about the items that she couldn't answer. 

It's a little loud but the walls are covered in quotes and I love that decor. Cute little place but I really want that lasagna back on the menu! :(
author: Jeannie L.

description: Made a reservation through OpenTable, was curious about this place so I decided why not.  Not much to say, great service, great food, and absolutely LOVE the typography on the walls.  They have a pretty big space downstairs as well if you want to reserve it for a private event.  Since their slogan was "Feed the People", I ended up giving the leftovers to the homeless.  Will definitely be back!
author: Kevin C.

description:
Food here is pretty great. Atmosphere is very open and clean. 

I've been here multiple times on the weekend. Seating for reservations is prompt and service is great. 

I definitely recommend their in-house cocktails. They're super delicious and well-made. 

Our waitstaff every time we have been here is super friendly and accommodating! I appreciate that this place feels right for both families and couples on date night. It 's never too loud here and I feel that I am never left waiting with an empty glass or questions!
author: Lauren A.

description:
It's not CREE-DOH.  It's CRAY-DOH. :)  Si si--it's Italiano! 


Service = friendly.  Our server needed to speak up though.  We could barely hear what the 'specials' were...

Food = delicious.  We had the hummus appetizer, and the mushroom/fontina dip appetizer; both came with crisp flatbread wedges.  Awesome.  I had their special pasta (tortellini stuffed with riccotta and cooked in brown butter sage and hazelnut) totally worth the calories!  The bread for the table, with the awesome spicy olives were to die for as well.  It was addicting, and garlick-y heaven (or hell if you're on the receiving end of the breath.) 

Portions = plentiful.  Worth the bucks.  

Wine list = plentiful.  And they have a few cocktails as well. 

I do love the text/script on the walls; the ecclectic 'repurposed' wood tables; and the wine bottle bottom for water glasses.

Overall, I'd come back here for a nice lunch.   Next time, I'll try their sandwiches....I saw the ginormous pile of fries that came with them too!
author: Fannie S.

description:
Two things that make this place a winner--without even going into the details of the excellent service, the good vibes, and the fine rustic Italian food--1. it's not in the Mission, so unlikely you'd run into any hipster. 2. it's not in Bauer's top 100, which means it's not overrated.

If you go, three must-order-items: tuna conserva salad, tortellini with English peas and mushroom, pork & ricotta meatballs, and torrone pistachio frozen honey ice cream. Oh wait, that's four.
author: Alex B.

description:
I REALLY wanted to love this place.  We went for New Years Eve.  I had studied the menu carefully in the days leading up to it.  I really wanted a nice thin crust pizza so I wasn't weighed down later with a big meal.

Here's what happened.  Waiter opened with "new menu, new chef, no more pizzas."  Ugh.  FYI, menu is still the same on their site...

We ordered arancini.  For $7, you get one the size of a golf ball.  It was delicious, but looked pathetic, lonely and inadequate.  The salad dressing was too fishy.  The gnocchi was so-so.  The potato and sunchokes side was ok.  The meat dish was tasty but is just a hunk of meat on the plate.  

Service was spotty for not being packed.
author: pete c.

description: Came to dinner last night with coworkers, quotes on the wall are really cool, food was great, i loved the lasagna!!, our server Alex was awesome, he gave us good recommendations, will definitely come back when i am in the financial district.
author: Samuel Q.

description:
My company had our holiday party here and everyone, including myself, really enjoyed this place. I was a little worried about booking our holiday party here (it was the only place out of 15 other restaurants I called that wasn't booked). It turns out, I didn't have anything to worry about. 

We sat in the more formal dinning area downstairs (which, like the upstairs, has quotes all over the walls). Our waitress was so nice, she handled our large group gracefully, and gave great recommendations. When I asked her questions about the menu she didn't seem annoyed or bothered by them. Also, everything came out so quickly, which was great since we were all really hungry. Even though the food came out quickly, none of us felt rushed to finish our food. Everyone liked their meals and those who ordered seafood dishes said that it tasted very fresh. I ordered rabbit ravioli for the first time and I thought it was pretty good.

Overall, I would give it 3.5 stars.
author: Abena O.

description: update. was invited to lunch with coworkers and sat at the table in the back closest to cooking area. service was nice but food was not all that.  what really struck me is the artwork of quotes about the Iraq war. as you could imagine the theme of these quotes were all in support of invading Iraq as they had WMD. well we did, they don't, the country's a mess, and extremist religious groups rose up as there was no order to prevent. i request the manager of credo to consider replacing that sign. it's abhorrent that it still hangs there given what we know now.  Please Please remove!
author: Tina K.

description:
I had another company lunch here and let me tell you. It was yumz yumz. I had their steak as the appetizer and it was delicious. I should had order the chicken it would have been better. But nonetheless a good experience. The service was great and i got to order my keen royale drink and it was yummy yummy. 

I did also like the inspirational quotes about believe in yourself. It gave me a good vibe. Make sure not to go with a huge party as it can delayed food, but other than that great place.
author: Alex A.

description:
When my coworker first told me about Credo, I imagined a casual, quick take-out restaurant (since that's how most are like in the Financial District). 

I knew I my assumptions were wrong when I first walked in.  I loved the chic, modern decor -- from the printed quotes/text on the wall to their unique laminated wood tables.  Being a detail-oriented person myself, I appreciated the fact that no aspect of the restaurant was an afterthought. 

Food-wise, I was just as impressed.  As an appetizer, my coworker and I shared the Margherita Pizza.  My only complaint was that the crust could have been thinner.  We also shared Parmesan Fries, which was thinly sliced to my liking. 

The best part of the meal was the Carbonara -- spaghetti with pancetta, guanciale, parmesan cream, and egg yolk.  The yolk was perfectly placed in the center of the dish, and the moment I broke it apart, it blended graciously with the remaining ingredients.  I can feel my mouth salivate just reminiscing my last bite!  This will probably be my default entree here from now on. 

I recommend Credo to anyone who can take a semi-long lunch break.  Either that or go for dinner -- which I have yet to try!
author: Judy C.

description:
Meh... I don't think I'd go back here on my own will, however, if someone suggests it and we're in the neighborhood I have no real issues coming back here. Though, I probably would suggest something else for food.

My happy hour buddy and I went on a happy hour tour through Financial District. I believe this was our second spot for the afternoon/evening. We ordered a cocktail and a glass of wine, we only got wine. We ordered some happy hour snacks, which really are just 1 bite each (and that for the price of $6-$8 is not really "happy hour" in my opinion). The snacks were tasty, however, there are so many better happy hour places in the area that I wouldn't go here for happy hour.

The decoration however of the place is very neat. Good quotes on the wall and everything is made from recycable material. Glasses are made of wine bottles :-)
author: Helen D.

description: Had a work dinner here with 20 or so in the basement room and they did a great job.  Nice service, good Cesar salad, beef dish was done well, and enjoyed chocolate cake dessert.  Menu limited for groups, but seemed to please everyone.  Bread was great as well.  I will reserve a possible upgrade for when I dine in the regular seating and have full menu access, but I'd recommend for a group up to 30 for a small dinner setting with drinks.
author: Marc S.

description:
Was looking for a spot for ten people for my birthday dinner....And yes, like every big party I wanted the best time slot....7:30!  Called around to my final choices (of which Credo was one), and the reservationist at one of the places (which I won't name) practically laughed at me over the phone.  I know he was thinking (just as I thought many times while taking rez's), "Party of 10 on a Friday, before the first turn is over?  Hahahaha! What a fool!"  Needless to say, the person I asked at Credo, cheerfully said, "Let me take a look.... Could you do 7:45?"  Yes!  

One of the big deciding factors in choosing this restaurant was that they were serving one of my favorite dishes (I wait to eat this someplace at least once a year) - butternut squash ravioli.  YUM!  So all the non-vegetarians would have to fend for themselves, I was focused on one dish, and one dish only!  

When I got to Credo, my bf was already waiting at the bar.  I joined him, and the bartender nicely let me test a few wines before choosing one (picky, picky).  Our table was ready early, and once more of our party arrived, we closed out with the bartender and made our way towards our long table.

Our server promptly took over, although I never got her name, or a friendly intro before she was asking for app and drink orders....that part was a bit of a disappointment.  But, as far as I took notice, she was quick to keep everyone's glass full. 

For apps, the table shared the hummus plate, the bison, and the bread & olives.  All were good and got eaten.

We drank plenty of wine, but the only bottle I recall was the Robert Mondavi (?), which seemed to be a hit all around the table.  

My meal was excellent.  My boyfriend ordered his lamb chops med-rare, but I saw they came out more med-well (there was almost no pink).  He said they were "ok" though.  Everyone said their food was good, but I don't think anyone was over-the-top impressed.

My waitress presented me with a little choc lava cake at the end (phoned in from my sis in Oregon) :)  They apparently close at 10pm, which seems very early to me (this is SF!  Even Seattle doesn't roll up that early!), but I noticed our server began doing side work staring at us.  We left around 10:30, so its not like we were still chatting at midnight or something.  

4 stars because they fit us in, and kept the wine coming, and apps and entrees came out very promptly.

Not 5 stars because I don't feel like our server connected with us at all, wasn't very friendly, and seemed kind of pissed at the end of the night (yes, she did get her grat, btw).

Bottom line....My celebration was wonderful which made an extra star.  As for the restaurant itself...I would like to go back with just one or two other people and see if the service is better.
author: Anna S.

description:
Came here last night with my boyfriend for our anniversary, the ambiance was interesting, there were many quotes on the walls, they even had Eminem's Quote on the wall; I know this because my table was right next to his quote. On the back of the menu it's like a news paper, which was quite interesting. The kitchen is a open kitchen and on top it read "feed the people." The tables are created with bits and parts of old wood pieces from scrapped parts. The water glass we had was an actual wine bottle that was remade into a glass cup. I thought that was pretty awesome. Way to go green guys!!  

My highlight of the day was the food, well mainly one dish, the RAVIOLI RIPIENI - Braised short rib Ravioli/brunoise vegetables/braising jus, it was so delicious, the sauce was to die for. I also had the PETTO D' ANATRA - Seared Duck Breast/butternut squash timbale/cranberry caponata, this was good but the cranberry sauce was too much for me, it was too strong for my taste. The duck was cooked perfectly and the butternuts squash puree was delicious, but the portion was a bit too much. My boyfriend had order the special of the day, the Fillet Mignon topped with Foie gras on a bed of fingerling potatoes and string beans. The Fillet Mignon was cooked perfectly and seasoned well; personally I liked my boyfriends dish more then the duck dish.

I would give it all 5 stars but my duck plate wasn't as good as I was expecting it to be, maybe it because I've had better. Other then that, the service was great, I liked the ambiance, and I would definitely go back to this restaurant for the short rib ravioli.
author: Susan K.

description:
Given the wealth of great food options nearby I rarely go to Credo, but finally had a really good meal there last night. The endive salad was perfect, but the butternut ravioli was cooked perfectly. Service was okay. They close up earlier than many places in the area (could be the section of Pine Street they are on, which has more lunch spots). 

They are mid-pricey for that part of town, have an assortment of cocktails and a small wine list. Be aware that they are loud - no soft furnishings and tall ceilings bounce the sound around a lot.
author: Melissa B.

description:
I went here for a company lunch.

My food was fantastic - I had the butternut squash ravioli, and my coworker had pizza which also looked (and smelled amazing).

The downfall, was our other coworker's chicken was raw. :-/ not appetizing at all. Makes me a bit nervous.
author: Amanda B.

description:
This is the most godawful-because-pretentious eating holes in the Financial District. Bar none. There is no comparison. Zero.

It's a hackneyed menu of more than bloody awful food that tries to box out of its class by papering the walls and menus with feel good quotes or statements of belief from secular saints. Feel unimpressed by the barely cooked pasta with tomato sauce? It's OK, there's a nice quote on the walls from Anne Frank (let's think about this for a moment - a Holocaust victim's comments are appropriated by a mediocre restaurant selling spaghetti). Feeling underwhelmed by the practically inedible chunks o' tuna sitting on a bed of arugula sitting on a bed of something else that nobody at the table can eat? With un-ironic melon balls? It's OK because there's an inspiring idea from Teddy Roosevelt and Bobby Kennedy right above you. Or Picasso. Or Mother Theresa Or God knows who else.

This isn't food. It's Grade A piping hot bullshit. The staff knows it and is half ashamed of it. A customer with narcolepsy and dead taste buds would know it in 10 seconds. And the chef (Gustavo Romero) should be ashamed of himself - the idea that anything happening here is the result of 'creative juxtapositions' is an insult. A Cuban sandwich? A mixed green side salad? Penne and sausage? Do you think we're a bunch of rubes who just came over the fricking bridge from nowhere and haven't eaten in a restaurant before?  

I feel sorry for the people who work here. It's a con. I feel even more angry as someone who just ate here.
author: john t.

description:
Ok how gimmicky is a pasta dish covered with pizza dough like a pot pie? Who cares... it's delicious! I am not a big fan of tomato sauces and pasta because restaurants constantly screw up these two wonderful and sacred ingredients. Credo does a good job with the pasta and sausage but the real treat is the pizza dough on top - wonderful.

The stuffed quail was fine and pretty but a little too subtle for me in terms of flavor. The chocolate dessert was fine. The Fritto Misto was very lightly battered, which is nice, but again the flavors were too subtle for me.
author: Marina N.

description:
************* REVIEW 190 ****************

          Cute place, modern, high ceiling & I love how the walls decorated in texts & what not. Down stair another private dining room for special occasion & also modern & well layout. 

          We normally have happy hour here & so they just have a new menu this week, which is awesome to try out. My little sis is going away for college at Chapman, so I tried to catch up with her & my dear friend T.

So here is what we ordered:

- Caprese de Bufala Classca - Buffalo mozzarella, tomatoes, olive oil & balsamic - 4 big pieces & really refreshing.

- Calamaretti in Guazzetto - baby Montery squid, garlic, white wine, spicy tomato sauce, served with grilled Tuscan bread - the broth was wonderful, sweet, aromatic, & perfect for dipping. 

- Lumache alla Pavese - escagots, garlic, mint, red wine, served over grilled Tuscan bread - the escargots were tender & the onion in red wien broth was really tasty!

- Sedanini alla Credo - short macaroni pasta, italian sausage, pancetta, sage, pecorino romano, light tomato sauce, topped with pizza dough & oven baked - This order was in a huge bowl, we laughed so hard when the server brought it out because of the dough. The pasta was OK, the sauce was just too rich for us. 

-  Fetuccine Classiche alla Bolognese - this sauce was so nice, well flavor & perfect.

- Tagliata di Manzo - grilled Painted Hills NY steak, sliced 7 served over roasted gold potato & wilted baby spinach - nice portion, the steak was tender, juicy & cooked to my liking. Of course, it's my dish, because I can't have any carb after 6:30 PM! Ordered my Richard T ;-)

- Torta di Ciccolato - flour-less! Very nice & I don't don't feel guilty at all haha!

- Bailey's was perfect to end the meal.

            Amanda, our server was very nice & attentive, explained very well of every dishes that we ordered. Dinner for 3 before tips $200.00. Of course, we had some wines!

Note: Happy Hour from 2:30-:30 PM at the bar offers plenty of small bites & well drinks!

Overall: 4 stars
For value: 4 stars
For Food: 4 stars
For Service: 4 stars
For ambiance: 4 stars
For location: After 6PM, street parking!
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
I believe this place is pretty damn good. 

Our service was top notch, very friendly and accepting of my non-dairy requests. Cool little place too, skylight for some natural light and I dig that you can see right into the kitchen where the magic happens. They have famous "I believe" quotes all over the walls which are humourous to read and can lead to interesting conversation.

Funny thing is what sticks in my head the most was the water glasses, they're made from the base of wine bottles... Why I remember that I don't know, but importantly I DO remember the food being very good too. I read through some other reviews here and they said the food was lacking, maybe we just got lucky? Maybe they've gotten better?

Whatever the case we had a good visit. They had a bartender named Shannalee who was super sweet to us but I heard word she's no longer there, bummer for Credo.
author: Justin N.

description: This place is solid. I especially like the wine by the glass selection. Lots of italian choices and often a couple that have some age. The 2009 Friulano is a great deal!
author: Paul N.

description:
Came here with a fairly big group. It was one of the only places that could accommodate a group our size (over 20) with such short notice (same day). 

Started with several apps. The Burrata and prosciutto were amazing, and I'm usually not a huge fan of either. The meatballs were also good, but not the star of the app menu.

For my main dish, I had the Flank Steak. The steak itself was tasty, but the accompaniments brought the dish down. The raisin agrodolce were sour and tasted like vinegar, while the broccoli rabe was not very good either. I pushed all that aside and simply ate the steak and fingerling potatoes.

Overall, service was a little slow, but given our huge group, I wouldn't say this could be measured as the norm. The meal was good, but not great. I won't be in a rush to return here on my next trip to SF.
author: Jacob L.

description:
I have had really good service at this restaurant; if you want to eat somewhere you feel taken care of, this is the spot. It's not really 5 star food, but a good 4 stars and 5 star service. I rounded up again - but they deserve it. 

The SHORT: 
The food is quality, tasty and fresh; the price is fair; the staff is AWESOME! Lovely seating, attentive servers, and quick to go service. 

The MORE detailed: 

TO GO: 
5 stars for food to go! I called in my order because I can't leave my desk today, and received an enthusiastic male voice. I asked how long it would take for a Ciabatta Pollo and he said - 5 MINUTES - score! It took me longer to get out the door, but when I did, I had all of 10 steps to take to theirs. My bag was sitting right at the door alongside a well dressed smiling gentleman. Yeah, I like it when people smile at me! 

The first thing this man did right was CARD ME- THANK YOU A.J! You know, the back of my VISA says "See ID" and people rarely ask for my ID. What if my CC had been stolen? Kudos to AJ! 

The second thing he did right was apologize for his establishment not carrying ketchup - upon my request. He did offer to go get me ketchup next door, after I expressed my disbelief. I told him it was cool, didn't need the high-fructose anyway. Yo, he was seriously about to go get me some ketchup though - so sweet - made me feel like a VIP. 

The last thing he did right was tell me to come back soon - he wasn't being fresh, just genuinely nice. I could just tell he likes working there or he knows I am a VIP lol. I'll go back. I got their menu and there are many good looking options. 
FOOD 
Ciabatta con Pollo: 
It's the end of the day on Friday, and I absolutely reek of garlic from my pesto... I don't care though cause it complemented my buffalo mozzarella, perfectly grilled chicken breast and warm ciabatta roll perfectly. 

Fries: OK, not fries, "fried parmesan potatoes" I know why they don't carry ketchup, cause their fries don't need it. However, IMHO, any place that serves fries/fried potatoes should carry ketchup - I'm justsayin I would like the option to ruin your potatoes with ketchup. 

DINING IN: 
When Credo first opened, I dined in and the food was good. I couldn't get a table without a reservation, but they offered me and my friend a counter seat - which worked out well for me! I was perched up high enough to look up in everyone else's plate; and, me being a seasoned drinker, I was very impressed with their liquor selection i.e Clase Azul aka "brandy like sipping tequila." When I ordered it, the bartender got excited because no one ever orders this special tequila with their Italian food. I say tequila with everything - but that's just me. She agreed! I've had this for $12 - $18 a shot, I think it's $12 there... maybe $14. 

The grilled salmon was a little undercooked for my liking, but I sent it back and they gave me a bigger and better cooked fillet - that's wassup. After the shot, I got a lil chatty and the bartender invited us to their tax day event - I couldn't make it but it was cool idea - cheap happy hour to drink the paying pain away! 

They serve focaccia with fresh olives and olive oil for dine in: the olive oil for dipping reminded me of the fresh pressed goodness I get from my favorite Italian spot in Mill Valley - not all olive oil taste like this - it's a treat!
author: Rayna A.

description:
Made reservations through Open Table for lunch on 6/7/2010 to try the Dine About Town 2010 menu.

Food - 3 stars
Waitstaff - 3 stars
Hostess - 1 star
Overall - 2.5 stars

When I arrived to check in for 1, the female hostess (dark curly hair) said that Open Table doesn't make reservations for one. I did and showed her the email confirmation. I asked if she ever used Open Table and she said no. FAIL for the greeting and marketing. 

Luckily, the male host acknowledged me and asked if I would like to sit at the bar. I declined because I made a reservation so I could sit and enjoy the restaurant's decor instead of staring at bottles of liquor. Again the female hostess said "Well, what do you want to do? There's a wait fora table or sit at the bar."  What would happen if I was a recovering alcoholic? FAIL again. The male host saw a table get up to leave and told me to wait a minute while he cleared that table for me.  

Someone needs to teach the famale hostess manners or just fire her before she scares away business or cause the restaurant o loose more star ratings on Yelp.

Loved the decor. As I waited for my service, I spent the time reading the various quotes on the wall. I was very entertained. 

I ordered the following from the Dine About Town menus:

First course: OLIVE ALL' ASCOLANA- Fried, stuffed green olives w/ arrabbiata sauce.
- too dry and hard. My fork couldn't penetrate the outer fried batter and i lost one rolling off the plate and onto the floor.

Second course: BRIACCIOLA ALLA BARESE- Pounded pork chop, rolled and stuffed with pecorino and rosemary, cooked in a tomato sauce served with mashed potatoes
- delicious. So tender and tasty.

Beverage: glass of prosecci and tap water. 

Service was average; friendly and courteous but not spectacular.

I would definitely come back again to try the regular menu.
author: Christine T.

description:
Rolled the dice on another place in SF. This place was interesting. 

Nice place but first strike came from the wine. We ordered a barbera and it was fairly oxidized.  We asked if it had been opened for a while. They said it was open for a few hours. But then we had them get a new bottle and yes it was oxidized. 

Service was good and attentive

Second strike, had the poached pears and prosciutto . I would assume that the poached pears would have been warm and soft, but they were ice cold and hard. It was good  Just didn't want to send it back since we just sent back the wine.

The third strike was the inconsistency of portion sizes. Had the salmon special. It was cooked very well but looking around the sizes varied between patrons. Some real big some small.

Service was good, place is loud. I don't know what else to say....

The experience was pleasant but there are a few things that just doesn't make it amazing, especially since there are so many places in SF to go to.

I would say try it once, if you have a good experience try it again.  Just like another yelper said "I really wanted to love this place"
author: Roy K.

description:
Brought my friend here for lunch as an ongoing birthday paloosa. 
I had the most delicious endive salad (endive, arugula, walnuts, gorgonzola, and balsamic figs, with a honey dressing), and my friend had some sort of pasta ragu. My salad was ERMAZEBALLS. Her pasta was a little al dente for both our tastes (yes, we share!), but the ragu was pretty darn good. 

We had some sort of ice-cream-ish pistachio dessert, which was spectacular, and the wine list was appropriate. I'd definitely come back.
author: Mi M.

description:
Alex, our server apparently has been on staff since restaurant opened. It showed as he knew the nuances of the menu extremely well, his care for great experience showed when we mentioned we saw nuts not mentioned in ingredients apparently appeared on the plate of appetizer, having kitchen make it over.
The appetizers, four entres and desserts had fresh and ingredients and favorably prepared
author: Phillip W.

description: Excellent. ....food, service and drinks...this was my first time at Credo. I will definitely go back again. My suggestion is a 7:00 reservation or later, plenty of free street parking right in front of the restaurant.  If your going to Punchline, its a short walk around the corner maybe 4-5 blocks.
author: J G.

description:
Such a cute place with writings on the wall. I'm not the one to be cheap, but this place is over priced for lunch. 

Burrata with Tuscan Honey, Sea Salt and Crostini-yum, but the burrata was too little.
Strozzapreti with Braised Beef Ragu and Parmesan-really good.
author: Karen H.

description:
Every time I come here I feel like I'm royalty. The staff here is amazing and the chefs as well. 

Located in the financial district just a stones throw from downtown and North Beach,  this is a great spot to go for a dinner date and a nice walk afterwards to any of the adjacent areas for clubbing, after dinner cocktails or if you into that sort of thing ... strip clubs :) 

Great wine selection and desserts as well. 

I suggest the flank steak or the osso bucco. Mad Cred-ooooooo
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I needed a quick reso for a place that can seat an 11ish party for lunch, and this was one of the few I found nearby in the FiDi. The staff and hostess was extremely nice and superbly apologetic for making us wait 20-some minutes for a table. Service aside, I thought the food was ok. I ordered truffle fries and the sausage pizza. Meh. Fries were addictive but moreso because they were MickyD like (mMmm). The pizza - for all the great places in SF - fell shorter than the Lollipop Guild. I didn't mind leaving over half my pizza when I left because it wasn't worthy of any more stomach space.

Hmm I will say that the apps were pretty tasty - the hummus and some cheesy dip that made me 1 minute shy of a heart attack. The decor was pretty cool too - you can see the pizza oven from the door. It's rustic, homey, and very Cali if that works for you.
author: Jenny C.

description: Worst customer service. Tried to go there tonight for dinner. Sat at the bar as I was alone.  I was there for 20 mins and not one employee even acknowledge my presence. I will never go back and I will make sure and let others know.  Don't waste your time.  I didn't mention the place was not even busy. Two others sitting t the bar and maybe 5 tables sat and plenty of staff around.  Ridiculous.
author: Adam G.

description:
I visited Credo for the first time for a school-related banquet.  The banquet was held in a private-room downstairs from the main dining room.  The room was large enough to sit 50+ guests and it was nice to have our own space.  There was also a small bar area in the room, so the waiters were able to serve us directly from this bar.  

The service was pretty helpful in general, but at times, we couldn't find anyone.  

The food (too many dishes to go into) was pretty solid overall.  Nothing really stood out but it was decent.  We had everything served family style.  This was fine for most of the dishes, but made it difficult when it came to dessert, as they gave about 5 small desserts to share between a group.  We ended up trying to divide up the desserts by cutting them, but this didn't really work out that well.

Overall, it's a decent option for a large get-together in the financial district area.  I was not impressed, but not disappointed, either.

Notes:
-They play this somewhat creepy recording in the restrooms- featuring speeches/clips from history (ranging from Howard Dean's Byah! to Roosevelt's address to Congress 12/8/41).
author: Samantha L.

description:
I really dig Credo and have recently dubbed it my new fav fi-di lunch spot. We've come here for lunch twice and I really enjoyed both the space and the food.

The walls filled with "believe" quotes (get it: Credo!) provide great conversation pieces. There's a penne with a nice semi-spicy pepper sauce that I adore (add chicken or shrimp though!). Their pizzas are also quite fabulous. My coworkers enjoy the chicken sandwich.

Note: If it looks like it's too crowded when you walk in don't despair, they actually have seating downstairs. It's a bit odd and underground but they still have some of the quotes and some tables for larger parties.
author: Nikki M.

description:
I went to Credo last night with a group of friends and we had the cool table with a window right by the entrance. 
The evening started off with an entertaining group of guys who seemed to be having a bachelor party and we watched them polish off a bottle of vodka outside. 
I was very surprised with the quality of the food at this place. 
We started with a few appetizers. The meatballs were excellent. I normally don't care for meatballs but these were fantastic and the marinara sauce was perfect. The burratta with crostini was sublime. Possibly the best I've ever had. Even the bread with butter was unbelievably good. 
My entree of flank steak was excellent. I ordered a few Manhattans that were spot on with a bit of orange peel in the cocktail for a very nice citrusy touch.
I'd gladly go back to this place anytime.
author: Matt H.

description:
Burrata was pretty great, probably the highlight of the meal. That said... it's not that hard to get right... so it's not really enough to bring us back again.

We also had the carrot and meatball apps, and the chicken entreé. The meatballs went over really well, second favorite. The carrots and chicken were both unfortunately unremarkable. Not bad, but not something I'll remember or ever order again. A shame, too; the idea of the brown-butter carrots *sounded* so good, I went home and made a version at home myself the next night. So good...

Liked the decor; fun stuff on the walls... though it was pretty noisy.
author: Leah S.

description:
I really want to give it 2.5 stars.  It isn't bad per se, it just isn't good.  Service was slow and fragmented, wine list was unimpressive, and the food was really hit or miss.  Some things were great, something's were marginal.

For the ~$100/person we spent we could have done MUCH better elsewhere.

My advice to Credo - give your hostess a raise because she's great, train your wait staff professionally, and spend more time on your food and less time on your walls.
author: C D.

description: Perhaps a fancified Pasta Pomodoro in the FiDi.  Most interesting to me was the airy space and quotable decor (a perfect place to bring someone you find boring as heck--like a bad date/dull co-worker, etc.--so you can just read the quotes behind their head and feign attention/interest in them).  The bread squares, olives, and my penne pasta + sole special were satisfyingly good and filled me up big and happy.  Lunchtime Fiore di Limone cocktail just so-so (but a good thing so as not to return to work all unprofessional-like).  Nice option for a work week lunch/dinner in the FiDi.
author: Peg S.

description:
Came here for a co-workers birthday. I never knew they had a downstairs that they open for lunch! Good space for private events. Food was excellent. However, the service was extremely slow. We waited a very loooong time to pay and didn't see our server for like a good 20 mins after giving him our credit cards.

- Rustica Pizza: delicious! good balance of flavors
- Margherita Pizza: OK, more cheese would be better
- Ciabatta Con Pollo: yummy sandwich with a nice balance of ingredients on fresh ciabatta. the peppery paremsan fries were really good!

Overall, great consistency in food and I've seen them improve from when they first opened. I think this place has become one of my new favorite lunch spots in the FiDi.
author: Linda C.

description:
Credo is an average financial district spot. Nothing special for SF. Tonight, for the first time in my life and apparently for the first time in the life of the hostess, my party was asked to move, as we had just received our coffees, to make way for a larger party.  She was relatively gracious about it, but it was still unwelcome. We had reservations so we weren't a surprise to their seating plan. 

The service up to this point was ok, but below average.  Our server looked visibly displeased when our out of town guest with english as a second language took some time with the menu. As we debated an appetizer, rather than attempt to help us (uh, it's your job right?), she advised she'd leave us to our musings while she would be elsewhere.  

So food was city ok, service passable, making Credo nothing special. Try other options; There is so much better out there.
author: Chris L.

description:
Best Italian food I've had in the Bay Area so far, hands down!

A couple of friends and I came here on a spur-of-the-moment dinner on a Wednesday night. Started off with a nice cocktail consisting of some bourbon and absinthe, hoping for that magical green absinthe fairy to show up. Damn, that was just a myth. Our group split yummy calamari with a very light, flaky breading. We also split a pizza, which was solid. I ordered the special of the day, which was a cod with a tomato-based sauce. This was good, but not "amazing". My friends, however, had a couple of awesome entrees. One got the breaded pork chop, which was a ginormous piece of pork, breaded and fried, and covered in clarified butter. Mmmm butter! The other got a very good macaroni pasta dish, topped with pizza-dough and baked in an oven. The pasta was cooked al dente, slightly firm and just the way I like it, and was absolutely delicious.

We went a little overboard with the desserts and ordered 3 different kinds. A warm flourless chocolate cake (which they have at just about every other restaurant I've been to), a stuffed pasta brise with ice cream covered in chocolate, and a custard creme. They were all very good and needless to say, we devoured all three things down to the crumbs.



Even the freak rainstorm that hit us on our way out of the restaurant didn't ruin this meal! I'll definitely be returning here again soon.
author: Kazu O.

description:
I was excited about the vibe of this place and walk past it frequently so I was excited to try it with a group of friends.

The food was fine but I was unimpressed with the service. Our waitress was not attentive and was actually disparaging about how much food we ordered! Maybe it was a one-off experience but it was enough to leave a bad taste in my mouth (no pun intended).

Haven't gone back and don't plan to.
author: Sydney L.

description:
I believe that Credo has a lot of potential.
I believe that the FIDI is in need of a casual Italian restaurant.
I believe that the modern decor promises a modern dining experience.
I believe that we paid a lot for a just-ok meal.

The staff at Credo could not have been more welcoming.  Everyone took time to say a sincere hello, including the owner and the chef.  We were there for Valentine's Day, and definitely felt taken care of.  We were also excited to try an off-the-radar new restaurant.

The interior is so cleverly designed with "credos" from various famous people on the walls.  This makes for interesting dinner conversation and has a great modern look, along with the cool tables.  But then - the dishware and flatware are straight from the 80's, which is distracting and dated...like, wait, is this the same restaurant?

The food, unfortunately, was more in tune with the dishware.  A bit dated.  My favorite dish was the Veal Meatballs, but the Fritto Misto was a bit heavy with a too-thick sauce (and a too-small plate! argh!), the Margherita pizza was bland, the pasta was obviously homemade and had great flavor, but was too thick and gummy (like grocery-store bought pasta), and the pork milanese was much too thick, rather than pounded thin.  Desserts were ok but not that memorable.

The vibe they are going for is rustic Italian, and what I got was stylized Italian.  I'd actually love to see it be more rustic - some burn marks on the pizza, some spice, simple white plates, thin thin pasta, hearty meaty sauces, that kind of thing.

To conclude, I believe that would go again for lunch, but probably not for a destination dinner.
author: Liz S.

description:
Came here for happy hour with coworkers. I had a lovely glass of pinot grigio and the most delicious appetizers I could have asked for. As it was on the company that evening, I didn't have to deal with the bill, but a glance over the menu was enough to tell me everything looked pretty pricey. 

The atmosphere is awesome, though! There are phrases written all over the walls and Barack Obama's voice was playing in the bathroom. Sounds weird, but I was a few glasses in so it was actually pretty awesome.
author: Ashwini B.

description:
Love this place!
The service is fantastic and the food is fantastic too. 
I love the hummus and flat bread and the bread and olives is super nice too.
I don't normally take my leftovers, but the food is so good here I never want to leave it behind!
Plus if you don't really like your dining companion you can spend hours reading all the quotes on the wall ;)
author: sarah s.

description:
We came here for lunch.  I ordered the chicken pizza.  The crust was very thin.  It's almost like eating a fried won ton.  I wish the top was less greasy though because the top was swimming with oil when they brought out my pizza.  The olives were gross.  Just plain too salty to eat.  I picked all the olives off.  Sometimes Round Table and their industry jarred olives are a good thing.

My friends ordered the ahi tuna sandwich.  They said the bun was sort of soggy but the sandwich was delicious.  Sandwiches came with fries.

They did not offer us bread until we requested it.  However they didn't seem to have a problem offering to other people because people were getting bread left and right.

This restaurant taxes for Healthy SF.

Overall it's ok but I find the menu pretty sparse.  Meaning there's not a lot to choose from.  I would come back if they expanded their menu.
author: Wendy H.

description:
Went here for lunch with my co worker.  She was awesome enough to take me to lunch.  I can't say anything bad about my experience.  It was busy when we went right around noon time.  There was just me and her so we sat at the bar.  Service was pretty fast so I can't complain.

Food was delicious!  We ordered the rustica pizza and some sort of pasta but I can't remember the name.  They were both so picture perfect and looked so good that when two guys came to sit next to us at the bar, they ended up ordering the exact same thing.

The only thing I didn't appreciate was the snooty people that like to eat there, lol.  Boy, rich people really need to learn how to not look down their noses at people, especially when they're the ones eating by themselves.  Also, I'm pretty sure this place is pretty pricey for lunch...

Anyway, thumps up for Credo tho, our service was awesome.
author: Kay R.

description:
Loved the building that houses the restaurant. The front facade looks retro; however, the inside is definitely modern.

Two of us went for lunch.  We shared the calamari, the pizza funghi, and the lamb burger.  The server warned us that it was good size portions, but we figured, we can always take doggie bags home.

Food paced appropriately, and sure enough, we couldn't finish our meal.

We especially enjoyed the pizza funghi, but everything was good.  

Finished our meal with the kiwi panna cotta dessert  and coffee.  Loved that  the coffee served with warmed steamed milk on the side.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I can't decide whether they're trying too hard or whether I just don't appreciate their kitchy-ness (if that's even a word). In any case, their decor is interesting to look at....framed quotes, tables made of recycled wood planks, water glasses made of repurposed wine bottle bases.

I had the seared scallop salad which was light and fresh - the scallops were cooked perfectly and were really delicious all on their own. My coworkers and I also shared a platter of crispy truffle fries and corn fritters (LOVE). 

I like that Credo partners with a different charity each month, to whom it donates a portion of that month's profits. It's too pricey for me to eat lunch there on a regular basis, but it was nice for a celebratory occasion.

On a side note, they really need to install better binds in the front windows. My coworkers and I kept having to move to escape the glaring direct sunlight spilling in through the windows, despite the blinds being closed. *shrug*
author: Mariela D.

description:
Really enjoyed my second lunch at credo recently. Ok, I fell in love with my waiter for just a moment, and I think he felt it too....anyway he was charming and funny and provided sweetly attentive service to our party of 4 50-something's.
We had had the meatball appetizer before and shared those delicious soft balls of flavor again along with some amazing deep fried asparagus which was perfectly cooked. Just when I thought I couldn't eat another bite of steamed asparagus, this was a welcome variation. Both times we have been underwhelmed by the cheese appetizers. I love that they still serve bread without asking and serve it with sweet butter with crisp salt on top. 
Our server recommended the petrale  sole special and the fish, mashed potatoes and spinach were all simply but excellently prepared. One of my friends had the same entree and we cleaned our plates. 
Lastly we shared some deserts and while the chocolate cake was just like so many deserts I have had, the tiramisu, coyly presented in a mason jar, was wonderful and light and not overly rummy. I would order that again, and not be so inclined to share.
Prices out this out of my every day lunch rotation but if I can get one of our law firms to take us to lunch, this is where I'd chose to go again.
author: Marie K.

description: My out of town visitors needed to carb up before the marathon and I did not want to be elbow to elbow eating from red and white checkered tablecloths with paper napkins.  So I steered them towards Credo where a great table, top notch wines as well as what one visitor noted "had every dish I would want for a pre-run".  Nice chopped salad for all, orenchetti and sausage, linguine and clam sauce and gnocci. Ending with Tiramisu, chocholate Ginache cake and an Almond cake to go. Service was a ttentiove but not hovering! My visitors are already planning a return trip next year when they come back for the race again.
author: C K.

description:
I took myself here for lunch as a special treat, and left disappointed. 

They sat me as soon as I walked in (it was after the lunch rush and fairly slow) and then forgot I was there. I tried to order a drink from a busser, and was told my server would be right with me. Twenty minutes later, My server took my drink order and ten minutes after that, the manager came over to take my lunch order because I'd been forgotten again. 

I ordered an appetizer, because I was running out of time for lunch, and didn't think I'd get an main in time to eat it. What I did have time to eat was really good, I just wish the service had been better.
author: Fiona F.

description:
Last night, I dined with friends at Credo.  The food itself was good but nothing to write home about - it  was an accurate reflection of its overall Yelp rating of 3.5.  The decor has great quotes and has a good vibe.  BUT at the end of our meal, I saw a cockroach crawl across the wall.  We were shocked and let our waiter know.  He did not even act surprised, calmly killed the cockroach, and went about his way.  It was disturbing that he was not surprised by the sight of the roach in the dining area, and it was bizarre that he did not say anything to the table after he got rid of the roach.  

UPDATE - the owner reached out to our group to apologize and let us know that this does not happen in the normal course of business.  He indicated that this was likely a roach that got in from the outside of the building and not as a result of anything in the interior.  He also offered our group a comp dinner & wine.  Makes me feel a lot better about the experience (and also increased the rating level accordingly).
author: Rupa S.

description: Credo is one of my favorite outdoor happy hour spots when it's nice outside. It's an easy transition indoors for dinner. Depending on what you order, it can be a little pricey for the portion size, but the service is always great and the happy hour drinks options are stellar. I love the multiple atmospheres, too.
author: Monika M.

description:
My wife was at the soft opening and reported having a good time.  While I didn't dine there myself, I DID get a great Pizza to-go that was to "die for". The sausage pizza was awesome.

My wife said that it was really a wonderful experience....l ambiance food and people made it a real memorable  time. We'll be going back together in the near future.    Make sure that "Mario Maggi"  is in the kitchen then your in for something extra special!
author: TIM M.

description:
Upon entering Credo, you will find yourself surrounded by white collar financial investors, and account execs trying to seal a deal and/or relaxing after a long day up in the high rise buildings that surround Credo.  The walls are decorated with phrases from influential in both notorious and celebrity fame.  We found ourselves reading off phrases while we waited for our service (which was never long enough to question where our server was) 

Service was great.  Super hipster asian guy that knew the menu and was around the entire meal while dealing with a large party as well and a few other two tops as well. 

For our appetizer, we went with what our server recommended which was the mixed hot cheese with flat bread.  For our mains, we ordered the Oso Buco (braised pork shank) and Capesante (pancetta covered scallop with black risotto.  The hot cheese fondue was delicious, but was super filling.  We could barely eat the whole thing.  The Oso Buco was not as tender as it should have been but edible.  The Capesante was good as well, cooked medium rare, how a proper scallop should be cooked, but it was a bit salty for my tongue.  The black risotto was delish too, made with squid ink. 

For desert we agreed on a chilled chocolate cream with strawberry.  

Even though our meal was comped for business purposes,  the meal was good and satisfying.
author: Cat A.

description: Food here is EXCELLENT! Service is just sub par, as it takes forever to get your food..and you have to request everything..and thats sitting at the bar in front of service! if the service steps up it has potential to be 5 star!
author: Jamaal B.

description: Terrific tagliatelle and rigatoni. The service was also great. Would definitely come back to try more of their dishes.
author: Mypinions N.

description: Happy with our meal and service. Ordered the risotto and the duck dishes. The dessert was amazing too. Had a nice broccoli cheddar soup as an appy and was delicious. We had a good experience here.
author: Ali P.

description:
So the first time I came to Credo was for a Yelp happy hour event, and our group enjoyed the small bar area where they had with drinks that were reasonably priced after the 50% discounts.  Nothing outstanding but nothing terrible with respect to their drinks options.  

Afterward, I decided to make my way back for lunch sometime since I take clients out every so often in the Financial District.  I went with the lasagna bolognese and it definitely wasn't something that I would get again.  It was a very messy dish (like a sloppy lasgna) and didn't have much body to it.   The tomato sauce was very overpowering and there was an abundance of cheese for the size of the entree.
author: Albie F.

description: Went here for a large birthday party and we were seated in the private room downstairs, which was awesome. The decor is modern and the walls have various quotations, which were entertaining to read while we waited. We had our own server and we could be as loud as we wanted! The appetizers were tasty (roasted octopus, pork and ricotta meatball, and burrata). Highly recommend ordering the burrata! For my entree I ordered the linguine with clams. This was delicious, though my only complaint was the small portion size like all the other reviews have mentioned. If we hadn't ordered so many appetizers and dessert, I'd probably be hungry afterwards. For dessert we ordered the creme brulee and I did not like this. The custard was very runny and seemed under cooked because of this.
author: Krista L.

description:
This is certainly one of the better dinner spots in Financial District.  I wasn't too hungry when I came, so only had 2 dishes instead of my customary 3-4 (+ dessert), but those 2 dishes really hit the mark.  Started with a kale salad (I mentioned I wasn't too hungry, right?) - surprisingly good, given that it was, well, a kale salad.  I then had the garganelli which was tasty and everything I want in a meat-based pasta.

The service was pretty standard fare (in a good way), and the walls are decorated with famous sayings that are a joy to read (and pass the time if you have nothing to say - not that I had that problem or anything).
author: Josh Q.

description:
A fancy venue for Italian peasant food (which seems like a misnomer given that modern peasants in Italy are likely immigrants not eating native Italian food).  Some of the food can get quite pricey, but there are ample pizzas and pastas for the peasant budget.  Aesthetically posh with a good sized bar, I can see this becoming a popular lunch and happy hour joint.

Chicche Pavesi w/ Gorgonzola Sauce: Chicche Pavesi sounds like a cabaret performer and has the biting personality of one too!  I may sound like a plebe, but it was very much like an extremely tender gnocchi.  The sauce stole the show though, with a pungent cheesiness that surpasses even some of the best mac & cheeses I've had.  Don't think blue cheese dressing, think Alfredo with a stinky edge.  YUM!!!

Quattro Formaggi Pizza: Simple. The dough was the star, more like tender thin flat bread than a crispy bottom pizza.  There were some nice bitter greens on top to contrast all the cheese.  It was a good blend of cheeses, but everything melted together making it hard to distinguish the flavors.  Perhaps some different textured cheeses or post-oven toppings would help.

Tiramisu: Loved that the lady fingers were so soft and airy with a generous soaking.  The cream was a bit too firm and custardy for my tastes.  Didn't last very long...
author: Adam B.

description:
I'm always a bit skeptical of new restaurants in San Francisco just because there are so many and disappointment has been my experience many a time. But I must say, Credo has certainly impressed me and left me in awe of their decedent  well thought out menu selections. Their menu constantly changes, but I had the crispy chicken with veggies cooked to perfection, the spinach, caramelized onion, and tomato pizza, the chocolate molten cake, and panna cotta. All of which was absolutely TO DIE FOR. The only reason why I hesitated with 5 stars and settled on 4 was because they needed at least one more person on staff for how busy they were. Our food came out as soon it was ready, but it was difficult for her to come with the dessert menu and the bill since she was working so wonderfully to please every guest dining that night. 

The decoration was stunning and the theme that echoed throughout the dining area all the way to the bathroom was certainly inspiring. Across the walls are "I believe" notes from people of the times. It's beautiful and possesses a lot of character. Take a visit to the bathroom where you find articles hanging in a single horizontal line.  The written inspiration is just as fierce as the sound track. I don't want to spoil the entire experience for you so I will end with a strong suggestion for you to take a visit.  :)
author: Alba G.

description:
Finally a nice and affordable place for lunch in the FiDi area.

Lunch Service is super nice.  Simple but tasty fare.  I had the Casoncelli di Bergamo al Burro Fuso.  Very succelent tortelloni with a nice hint of ricotta and spinach bathing in a warm sage infused brown butter.  My coworkers ordered the Insalate and they said that they were fresh tasting with a nice light vinaigrette.  

I will definitely come back.  Next time around, I'll bring my BF for dinner.

Did I mention that lo chef is Italian?  Mario e' bravissimo!
author: Veritas V.

description:
After trying to go to Credo multiple times and having no luck because it's been busy at lunchtime, I was finally able to go today and I really enjoyed my experience.  The layout of the restaurant was very cool and the quotes on the walls were interesting to read as there were some good ones on there.  Check out Tiger Woods' on the left side of the restaurant.

The bread an olives to begin with her very good and the olives had a nice spice.  For our meal I had the salmon salad which was delicious and had the right amount of salad dressing on there.  We also had the  Rustica pizza which was very falvorful and light.

I only had two downsides to Credo which was that is was pretty loud in side so it was hard to hear the conversation I was having and the wait staff was just ok.  They weren't bad enough to stop me from coming back though.
author: Blake B.

description:
This place is fantastic! The staff are so friendly and the food is great. The prices are also reasonable for the Financial District. They have a decent selection of wines by the glass and great deserts. 

I really loved the friendliness of the staff. I was sitting by myself at the chefs table watching them cook when a Sous Chef came by and started a conversation with me. I believe her name was Kate. She talked to me about her favorite dishes and made great suggestions. What I really liked is that she came back and spoke to me at later points during the night. I was able to ask her about what the cooks were currently making and how they were created. 

I had the special which was Fillet Mignon topped with Foie gras on a bed of fingerling potatoes. I got to watch them prepare it and it was so delicious. 

For desert I tasted a trio of chocolate truffles that the Sous Chef Kate had recently developed. The trio represented the ingredients in a "White Russian" (Vodka, Baileys, Kahlua). The Vodka and Baileys we my favorites. The worked extra well with the double espresso I was having. 

Tip: Try to sit in front of the chefs. You can see exactly how they create the fabulous dishes including your own. The Sous chefs will hopefully also come and speak to you about the dishes.
author: Roderick S.

description:
Came here the other night for a quick bite before my partner-in-crime and I went to see The Lion King (which is also amazing, might I add).  We started with a caesar, and devoured it.  It's been a while since I had a caesar salad with anchovies on top.  It was perfect. And the soft boiled egg on top... wonderful. And genius!  

She had the Sedanini.  It looked so cool!  Pizza dough baked on top of a big bowl of yummy pasta and meat?!  Order it.  We've never had anything like it before.

I had the Raviolone aperto di pesce.  Delicious.  I didn't want that dish to end!  The sauce was light and perfect, the seafood inside was whole, but easy to eat.  It's a lot lighter than I thought it would be, and the dish is pretty small, but it was perfect for the mood I was in.

Definitely going back.  Since I'm currently not eating meat, there are some other options I'd like to try!
author: Denise H.

description:
The first thing I noticed about this place: Credo, the name.  Which means "I believe" in Latin, and their walls are plastered with "I believe" quotes.  Very nice to know I retained some college Latin!

The waiter service is impeccable.  They refill your water often because they serve water in tiny glasses upcycled from wine bottles.  The bread and olives are tasty.  The fries give a nice crunch.  I had a steak sandwich and found it surprisingly tasty and easy to chew.  I tend to stay away from those because the steak is poorly done at many establishments, but Credo showed me otherwise.  Their personal pizzas are actually pretty big if you're wondering if its enough for one person.  I'd say that you can split a pizza and sandwich or entree with one other person, but its definitely larger than a "personal" size.  

For those who are allowed to take long lunches, take an hour or two at Credo.  I'm lucky enough to work in the offices right upstairs of this building and our agency had a company lunch here a few weeks ago.  I notice that its busy everyday around lunch hours, so definitely make reservations!  Its also really loud, but I had a great time here with a large party!
author: David O.

description:
I brought a client here for lunch on a Tuesday and had a less than amazing time. The front of house staff seemed disorganized, and in fact forgot to tell me that my client had already arrived and was waiting on me! Then we were taken downstairs to our table, which wasn't prepared for us so we had to awkwardly wait next to the restrooms while they set up our table. So lunch already started out a tad awkward...

Being seated downstairs was nice because it was much quieter than the upstairs which enabled us to have a great conversation without having to yell across a table.

Overall I thought the food was good and portions were remarkably substantial, which is why I'm giving it 3 stars and not 1. More than likely I will not be coming back...
author: Justin G.

description:
Every year, I have the great opportunity to help plan the company End Of The Year party (no not a Christmas, New Years, Festivus etc. party). This year it will be catered by Credo. I have never had the food until this past week. 

Amazing. I ordered the fish w/ some sort of white sauce, sauteed spinach and tomatoes. Light tasting, filling, overall a great experience. 

I look forward to the party if Credo is serving the food.
author: Angelo F.

description: Came here for lunch today with a friend, and was able to snag a seat at the bar. Apparently -- lunchtime reservations are preferred here -- just an FYI. I ordered the 4 cheese pizza which was thin, crispy, and delicious. A bit on the pricy side, but I have to admit, I did enjoy the newsletter on the back of the menu, the quotes decorating the walls, and listening to a 2 minute speech whilst in the bathroom, haha.
author: Mel G.

description:
I love the texted based art work all over the walls and great architecture. If you like Jenny Holzer art works this is a place like her exhibits. It kept me entertained reading the walls during dinner. 

Food was good but not wow. But I liked the ambient, was very cosy and service was very good. I enjoyed a nice meal in the middle of the week, but of you want a real fine dinning experience that melts in your mouth, this is not.

I had lobster legs on risotto. It was good but a bit bland. My husband had lamb chops with parmesan polenta which was yummy but again not amazing or different from an average restaurant.
author: Visda G.

description:
I had the lasagna bolongese which was delicious.  All the flavors of the meat, bechamel, cheese, basil and tomato sauce were perfectly balanced.  The tomato sauce could have been a little sweeter, but it was still good.  I did think it was overpriced ($13.95) for the relatively small portion size (like 6' x 2').  

My friend had the cheese tortellini in sage butter sauce which was also yummy and super rich (and small portion size, I think you get like 7 pieces of them).  I will definitely come back some time, but it won't become a regular spot cause its way too expensive.
author: Olivia T.

description: Came here with a group of coworkers for a luncheon. Everyone enjoyed their food. Liked the literary motif, very cool. I had the Margherita pizza and it was pretty good. I know someone had scallops.. and liked it. Um oh and some pasta I forget. But yeah everyone seemed to like it. A little expensive for lunch  though. But not bad.
author: Vol T.

description:
Went to a private dinner in the basement. A TERRIFIC room to hold the event. They have sayings from famous people all throughout the room.  Service was very good and the atmosphere was great.

Food was good but in not remarkable.  But on the other hand, you're serving to 40 people, so that should be expected. Soups and salads were tasty with reasonable portions.  The chocolate lava cake was ordinary.

Again, not a bad place to go for a group and I'd be eager to try the main dining room to verify our experience.
author: Dan S.

description:
Carbonara with bacon... To friggin DIE for!

+ Generous servings... especially the pizzas
+ Great appetizers - hummus, truffle fries, complimentary bread and olives
+ Amazingly attentive service, even during lunch rush! Our glasses were never empty, and used plates were collected in the blink of an eye.

If you're RSVPing as a party of 7-8, I highly recommend requesting the beautiful mosaic "Chef's" table in the back, near the stairway. Super secluded and close to the kitchen, so you can expect superb service. You can peek at the chefs working their magic too!
author: Serena N.

description:
Downtown chick restaurant with quotes all over the walls, actually some great quotes I must say that can be quite good conversation starters or debates.   But the look and feel of this place just screamed gimmick.  On a Friday night it was quite dead, and parking available right in front of the restaurant.  

The menu here is typical California cuisine, nothing special or inventive and the dishes unfortunately are quite forgetable.  We started with the calamari which were in a very good tomato sauce, but the calamari themselves were very chewy to the point of overwhelming.

For the main courses we got the veal and steak.  While they were good, they weren't great, the sides were just OK, something we make at home and it didn't add to the dish except in color.  The potatoes were quite salty as well.  

All an all, we were not impressed and even less so with the price tag of $150 for a dinner that was quite average.  I'm sure this is a nice place to take a client out to lunch and expense the tab but not for a foodie dinner.  San Francisco is a tough fare, very competitive and restaurants need to try harder to impress the foodies.
author: Inga W.

description: I usually don't review on yelp because I've been in the restaurant business all my life and I don't think people understand what is good in a restaurant and what is not.  This Place, hands down was one of the best steak salads I have ever had-steak was top quality and cook to perfection, the spinach, persimmons and fennel salad was sublime.  I would of reviewed early, but I couldn't remember the name until I looked at the receipt-do your self a favor and try it
author: Michelle J.

description:
What a great spot! We came here for dinner and sat at the tables overlooking the kitchen for a great evening of food and food prep. 

Everything we ate was good, and the chef explained the origins of some dishes for us. I loved seeing local sustainable sourcing for ingredients and meats.
author: Susan W.

description:
Even though I had something simple (penne w/ red sauce and chicken), I have to say that I was very pleased with the meal. The portion was generous for a lunch serving. 

Slight ding in rating for the sheer noise and crowds. Not exactly the best place to have conversation or elbow space.
author: Mike K.

description: Credo is a great place for lunch because it is open and airy and really vibrant. I liked the sayings on the walls although I could see where some of the posters might offend some. My server, Adrian Garcia, was attentive and professional and I enjoyed the Arugula salad, and Calamari. I think the 3.5 rating is "dead on."
author: Chocoolate I.

description: Unique establishment  boasting "belief" statements all over the walls in large to small multicolored fonts. Credo = I believe in Latin. From historic entrepreneurs, comedians & more statements from generations most centered on turning s nose down on politics. It's intimate with less than 20 tables & a bar that seats around 15. Best dish...huge bowl of pasta baked with pizza dough as a lid. Puffs up and gives great table presence. I had the filet with bone marrow & fingerling  potatoes. (order med rare & got medium)...I forgive them because they were on point & the pasta was so awesome how could I judge.
author: Catherine A.

description: Way too salty, and the "inspiring" quotes on the wall grated on my nerves.
author: Lian C.

description:
The food was pretty good. My ma ordered the shrimp pizza and I had the scallops over potato puree with wild mushrooms. Their argula salad with chunks of persimmon was refreshing! I really liked their olives drenched in the olive oil with pepper flakes and roasted garlic. That comes with the meal. The overall meal was tasty.

The ambiance is also pretty nice. We sat downstairs so it was much quieter than the upstairs. There were quotes from famous ppl written on the wall. The table setting and chairs are contemporary. 

Our waiter wasn't super friendly, but he gave us decent service. I definitely would go back.
author: Kissy F.

description:
If I could, I'd give Credo 3.5 stars.  Since I'm in a good mood today, I'll round up rather than down :P  I came here for Dine About Town last Friday night.  I really liked the quirky, open, high ceiling and modern ambiance of Credo.  For the appetizer, I had the Chef's Daily Soup (I was a little buzzed by this point...but I think it was a roasted pepper), which was thick and flavorful.  For the main entree, I ordered fish served on top of a grilled pineapple.  Even though the portion wasn't large, it was surprisingly filling.  Some of my friends ordered the chicken, which I think was the better choice.  The chicken was so tender and stuffed with some kind of cheese, I believe.  For dessert, I had some sort of a fruit tart, but one of my friends ordered a unique cantaloupe/honeydew puree served in a champagne glass...It was deliciously refreshing, the perfect end to a meal.

The reason why I would bump my rating down is due to the haphazard service.  I'm not sure if it was just an off day, but the waitress/server brought out several wrong entrees.
author: Andrea W.

description: Came here for dine about town. The dine about menu for the evening looked more interesting than the regular options they had on the menu so I opted for that. We opened with a platter of mussels, which were rather tasty.  Our table also split a serving of sweetbreads. I thought that was the best part of the meal. It didn't even have the iron taste that sweetbreads sometimes has. The steak was my main course and cooked to perfection. For dessert, lava cake. The dessert was a bit overdone as the center was a bit solid and not very gooey. Service here was excellent.
author: Kenson K.

description:
I came here for dinner several weeks ago and man, was I uptight! I was meeting someone for dinner who I had not seen in more than 20 years. We had ended our friendship kind of badly so this was kind of a tense situation. We finally reconnected via Facebook, and when she came to SF, I chose Credo as a dinner place, mostly because I knew about all the quotes on the wall, and figured that would give us something to talk about in case conversation wasn't that scintillating. 

When I walked in, I was greeted by the chef who was looking through the night's reservations. A hostess quickly came over and after I identified myself said my guest was waiting for me. I recognized her right away, and we had a big hugging session and some tears. She had clued the server on to our reunion, and the server was a complete doll and very solicitous of us all night. 

The food was fantastic! The bread was chewy and warm and accompanied by delicious olives. I had a wonderful ahi tuna steak that was prepared with capers, anchovies and I can't remember what else. My friend had ravioli stuffed with peas and feta, and again, it was fantastic! We were too busy drinking wine to order dessert, but what passed by looked pretty damn good. 

Thanks, Credo, for making what would've been an awkward dinner into a great, friendly reunion.. Oh, and neither of us had to use any of the quotes as conversation topics - we never shut up the whole night!
author: .Hon H.

description: Super ambience. Food isn't bad. Could be more authentic.  Service superb. A great find and the a must try!
author: A M.

description:
I really can't comment on how worthy the food is with the price since I didn't pay so, I'll just comment on the food itself. 

It seems like all the tables start off with olives and bread. The bread is nice and soft, and I personally don't love olives, but they were pretttttty good. I could actually eat some...

We then ordered 3 starters to share between the 7 of us. We ordered 2 of the Burreta Caprese. It was delicious. The cheese is so good. We also got an order of the Tuscan Hummus and seriously, it was really good. The flatbread with cheese on top is so delicious. Hummus plus the bread is good too. ALL AROUND GOOD.

I ordered the involtini di pollo which took the longest to get, but look amazing, and tasted great too. First the chicken breast is wrapped around the artichokes and peppers. It is nicely placed on top of the mashed potatoes with the truffle cream sauce on top. I finished off my whole plate and would have cleaned it if it wasn't a business lunch.

The quotes that we were sitting next to were about the iraqi war which is kind of cool that they used quotes about things that are relevant to our lives.
author: Nina Y.

description: The restaurant was awesome to accommodate our growing new years eve dinner from 14 to 18.  We were seated in the basement.  Service was on the slow side but what can you expect for a large dinner party.  Food was ok.  Squid, brussel sprout dish was tasty and flavorful.  Burrata and my ragu pasta was ok.  Prices were very reasonable.
author: Meredith K.

description:
We checked this place out on Friday night... got a table at 7pm, no problem. 
Service was friendly and pretty responsive.
We shared the lamb tartare, which was great. Surprised at the amount of lamb it came with. Definitely a filling app for two people.
The gnocchi and duck breast were both tasty as well. They weren't overwhelmingly awesome, but both solid dishes. Flavors were well done, both cooked and seasoned well. Large portions again with the entrees, so that made us happy.
I agree that the pricing seems a BIT high... especially their wine menu. I'm hoping they add a couple, more approachable bottles so you don't feel like you have to add $50 to your bill just to get some wine.
Overall we were happy with the experience, and I will definitely go back to try some of the other things on the menu.
author: Jordan R.

description:
Credo is a bit schizophrenic in that it has a modern feel, with political, jazzy quotes written on the walls, but strangely the food is pretty classically Italian. It's a pretty interesting experience to be eating a rustic lasagna bolognese while reading a Dick Cheney quote announcing, "My belief is we will, in fact, be greeted as liberators." Weird, no? Is it just me?

Regardless, I really like Credo. I love simple, classic food made with fresh ingredients. A lot of the dishes are made with fresh, homemade cheese.

My favorite are the appetizers. You get a free appetizer of bread and fresh olives tossed with olive oil and red pepper flakes. The olives are the perfect balance of salty and a little spicy, without being overly marinated like many preserved olives are. 

I recommend the white bean hummus with pitas. Smooth, creamy, tasty- it's way better than normal hummus! I'm a huge fan of it now and I'm on the hunt for more.
author: Cathy S.

description:
Delicious meal. Be sure to ask for the specials.

Update:

I've had some great meals here, and others that have left me wondering why I had ranked it so high. I think a 3 star is more appropriate given some inconsistencies between experiences.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I have been to Credo three times now, and every time I return I am not disappointed. The hostess has seated me immediately every time, without a reservation. I have arrived early though, around 5:45-6:15 ish. I went twice last season, and once this season, so the menu has changed a bit. I have tried most items on the menu, as I have been with hungry groups every time and everything I have tried knocks it out of the ballpark. The kitchen is open and allows the restaurant to watch as the chefs create masterpieces in a timely fashion. 

As far as appetizers go, I have tried the arugula salad (amazing), the pineapple queso fundido (by far my favorite- a delicious cheesy melt filled with a sweet pineapple surprise), the sweetbreads (I'm not a huge fan of sweetbreads but these had an amazing flavor), the carpaccio di polpo, and the tuscan hummus, which is fresh and yummy. 

In terms of entrees, I have had the pork shank once, which comes with a delicious arugula polenta and tomatoes confit. I have also tried the "sedanini" pasta dish, which is amazing in presentation, taste, and texture. A must try. It also comes vegetarian style as well. 

The fig pizza is to die for. It is new on the menu, and I will definitely order that bad boy again. 

I recommend this restaurant to anyone heading to the city. To anyone who is adventurous in their restaurant selection and palate, I highly suggest Credo.
author: Ellen P.

description: Credo is fine, nothing spectacular.  I had a reservation and needed to change the time - when we checked in, they had changed the time but also changed the number from 4 to 2.  While annoying, they were able to accommodate us downstairs, which actually turned out to be much quieter than upstairs.  Service was fine, but a bit on the slow side since we were a bit out of the way.  I had a burrata appetizer, which was good, and a pasta that I can't remember now.  That probably means it was fine, but nothing extraordinary.
author: Michelle C.

description: So I am a regular at Credo.  Meaning I have eaten here 10 plus times.   Mainly for lunch.  This evening my husband and I had a party of ten friends plus out of town guests with and so having a good experience was very important.   We got a lovely big table by the window so plenty of room and somewhat private from dining with the fray.   From first bite to end the quality of food on all dishes was exceptional.
