Squash blossoms and buratta were great.  Main courses the gnocchi tagliatelle and pork shoulder were standouts.   Desserts were classics created with care and excuding flavor.   All that being said when we first arrived it took 15 minutes to get a cocktail and service seemed sluggish on drinks.   Our waiter was very good but he could not control this.  It seemed that there were senior staff hanging at the bar but not paying a ton of attention.  So I discreetly brought this to the attention of said staff and they took my well intentioned feedback very well.   From here to the end of service the pace and expected attention was as it should be.  So kudos for taking positive feedback and acting on it.  Overall very good experience and a slightly hidden dinner gem!
author: Clare W.

description:
I went in for a late lunch today. This was my first real meal (consisting of something other than candy, pastries, or horrible chicken--long story involving an ill-advised tour of the Mission/Tenderloin districts) in San Francisco. The minestrone (soup of the day) was a little bland--the fresh pepper added in was a bit weird given the other flavors in the soup--but had rice, beans, and other good vegetables. It seemed nutritious, which was what I was looking for after a few days of pizza, chicken nuggets, and pastries.

A cute Asian couple walked in and the lady was looking at me and talking to a man who I assume was her husband. I thought she needed me to move in so that she could pull out her chair but when I looked at her, I realized she was talking about the soup. Moments later, she ordered the minestrone too. (So I guess it looked good or I looked like I was really enjoying it.)

I thought the complimentary bread and olives were a nice touch. The bread was perfectly seasoned with oil, salt, and rosemary. It was also interesting to see a salt accompaniment instead of butter/oil. I liked the fact that some of the olives were pitted. GATC (see my other reviews) has fantastic warmed olives, but it's a little awkward to be in company saving pits in your mouth or trying to gracefully slip them out of your mouth into a spoon. Still a few of the olives had pits. I ate them anyway--I was alone so I didn't care what I looked like.

You should know that only salads, soup, and appetizers are served between 2:30pm and 5:00pm. Other reviews seem to have indicated that there is a lunch rush. Maybe the buzz died down because when I got there at 2:30pm, the place was pretty empty (servers outnumbered diners). 

It's worth noting that the restaurant is almost directly across from the SF Stock Exchange and has a beautifully appointed window facing the street. I liked the fact that there were a lot of tables--I  am not a fan of the communal dining set-up favored by a lot of new restaurants. The ladies restroom in the basement was spacious and clean. I seldom try a new place without scoping out the restaurant inspection report. Credo hasn't been inspected yet (at least I couldn't find the report) but it seems very clean. I might go again for lunch or dinner.

I didn't notice any pictures with "I believe..." stories. I'll try to remeber to look out for those next time.
author: Jolene S.

description:
As usual with other dining places in SF, Credo's a bit pricey for what it serves.  That aside from the random quotes placed everywhere, the food is actually pretty tasty.

- The Brussels sprouts are amazing.  The texture and taste is surprisingly good.
- The scallops with the risotto.  Scallops were executed well, although I felt that it needed more seasoning.  However, the risotto was cooked perfectly, and stood out as the best item on the dish.
author: John S.

description: First of all, the decor alone is a reason to stop by.  I just love reading all the inspirational quotes on the wall.  Decided on a last minute date night last night and had another great meal at this place (minus our appetizer).  We ordered the burrata cheese plate and I'm giving minus one star for that- it was just too much in one pile.  But things looked up after that- great wine, service, and entrees.  I ordered the half chicken and it was delicious and juicy (and good for leftovers the second night too).  My bf got the pappardelle pasta with pesto and it was equally delicious and seasoned just right.  The waiter made great suggestions, but I guess we forgot to ask about his appetizer suggestions!!!  This place is good for a lunch outing with your office too but make sure to make a reservation.
author: Mindy R.

description:
I wish I could give Credo a higher rating because there were some things I really like about it. However, it is just too overpriced for the quality of food that you get. I know that is not surprising considering the location, but even considering the location, it's overpriced.

Here are the things I liked: 1) Great service; 2) Nice ambience; 3) Good portion size; 4) They donate some of their profits to a new charitable cause every month. Credo seems like the type of business I would like to support, however, I probably won't come back here, except maybe for happy hour when the prices are more reasonable. For entrees that are ~$20, I expect something good, but the food was mediocre.
author: Alison B.

description: Food is ok. Service is bad! The whole time we were there, our waiter never checked on us. Had to call all the time to ask for water. This should have been ok if the waiter, didn't pass by us several times. That made it worst! If you will pass by your assigned table, at least check on them, say a few words like, "is everything ok"? I don't think that is too hard!
author: Janet S.

description: Really good food and atmosphere. Really unique use of quotes as decor that myself and my group really enjoyed. The cocktails were really nice, I especially liked the Bronson. The food was very tasty and everyone in our group enjoyed what they had. The burrata as a starter is really nice and good for sharing with multiple people. I had the halibut for my main course and really enjoyed the combination of flavors. The sauces and sides really complemented the fish but didn't overwhelm the natural flavor. I enjoy the dining environment and overall feel of the restaurant.
author: Silas F.

description:
Simply: a nice place to eat.

First thing: the decor! "I believe" quotes from all sorts of popular people are all over the walls. Nice to read and remember, even make fun of some. My favorites are the sports players and those who write lit.

Nice space, easy to get to in the FiDi, plenty of room. Nice servers, great lighting, can see the small kitchen in the back, but in a clean and cozy way.

The first time:
My partner and I went for Valentine's Day this year. He really knows how to pick them well. We're not too fancy schmansy, so this was perfect. A little nicer, heels and a nice sweater, button ups and dark jeans would suit. Special Vday menu was on par. Decent veggie options. Just right portions, especially if you are sharing and having a few drinks. Servers are very courteous and accommodate very well.

Second time:
Such a pleasure, again. We had a group of about 6 for my partner's birthday dinner. We had our own table in the back, and our server was such a pleasure to chat with. I had to raviolone again, as one of the very few vegetarian dishes that I appeal to. More omnivore friendly dishes here definitely. Just ask, and they'll help you out if you're anti-meat. From everyone else, they were all happy with their food, good portions. Fun drink selection. Full bar, wines good too. A happy place for food and drink.

If you're like me and make more than one trip to the loo while having a few drinks, you'll pass by a room that's part of Credo that they do banquets and parties in. This time, I was so jealous! It was one of those wine & painting parties! It's nice to know Credo is willing to host events like that. They do other events, I just wish I had know about that specific one. Of course, events are run by other companies, and Credo provides the space.

Overall, a great place for yummy food, drinks, and bonding time.
author: Sophie C.

description:
Place seemed nice but pretty disappointed with the food. I mean, it tasted like they flash fried the pasta and then scooped some pulled pork on top

And it was like $25. Really
author: Jay Y.

description: I never eat out in the FiDi, but I thought it was great to have a "normal" (as opposed to over-the-top-old-school-or-fancy) restaurant in the neighborhood.  I liked the wine list:  it was eclectic enough and not horribly expensive.  The proscuitto was good, and while the burrata salad (could it possibly be?) had something mixed in (or just on the side) (chevre, blue cheese?), it was fine too.  Credos on the wall were fun to read.
author: Laurel B.

description:
Believe in something else.

Walls are covered with quotes large and small, from the famous to the infamous, stating what they believe in. Really liked this.

Complemented the open space perfectly. Bet you find yourself visually wandering from the walls to the open kitchen. Great design.

Enthusiasm does not carry to the food.

We were seated late. No big deal. Free white bean hummus and pita appetizer soon arrived as an apology.

Loved the hummus. Did not love the crispy flat bread coated with butter nor the $13 price had we been paying.

Entree was also disappointing. Achiote chicken was big enough for two meals, or perhaps I lost my appetite with the overwhelming amount of butter and oil.

At the end you couldn't see the bottom of my plate. Not because I left food. But because of the leftover saturated fats.

Wished they believed in healthier food.
author: Jason B.

description: This is my favorite place for lunch right now downtown.  The squid and brussels sprout appetizer is perfect and easy to share.  All the food is super fresh, on the lighter side and very yummy.  Great wine list and they have cocktails.  The only downside is the noise.  If you are soft spoken get a table after 12:45 pm, buy then the noise will have died down a lot.  From noon to 12:30 pm the noise is significant.
author: Albert S.

description: We went for a late night bite and had some really amazing apps.
author: William F.

description: Came here for a work event and thought the place interesting and yummy all at once. Loved their panna cotta with strawberries!
author: Erin T.

description:
I've been here twice for lunch, both with my team at work, and we were seated in the private downstairs area. Decor is cool and I love the quotes scattered all over the walls.

However, service here is pretty bad. Both times, it took us over 2 hours to finish the meal, even though all we ordered were apps and entrees! The waiter took forever to take our orders... and they refilled our drinks at least 5+ times before appetizers even came!

Food is okay. Pretty standard American/Italian food. The appetizers that I enjoyed the most were the Corn Fritters, Tuscan Hummus (SUPER garlicky though!), and Burrata Caprese (literally melt in your mouth). I've only gotten the Salmon Salad for my entree... really, nothing special.

I guess Credo would be good for large parties (because of the large downstairs space), but only if you can afford to wait and chat it up for hours.
author: Carolyn W.

description:
I went here with one of my girlfriends for valentines day since we wanted to have some drinks and dinner. The food was pretty nice (portions were alright, not very big). I had the bison meat sauche with Gnocchi which was pretty yummy. The thing that annoyed me was the fact that nobody asked us if we wanted dessert. We sat there for 15 minutes waiting for someone to ask us after they took our plates away (i'm on Paleo and didn't want to keep cheating that night unless someone offered me some tasty treats). 

No dessert = sad panda
author: Tanya S.

description:
Great food! Everything is fresh and tastes excellent. The pizzas at Credo are fantastic. 

Lunch is busy so make a reservation in advance.

I definitely recommended it.
author: Kelly Y.

description:
I came here for a business lunch with a party of 8 (with reservations), and unfortunately was disappointed. We were shuttled to the basement, where the acoustics are quite bad. The server didn't speak loudly enough for us to hear the specials, and we couldn't hear each other well despite being quite close together. 

The food? OK, but pricey for what we got. The server had said that the Cesar salad and Salmon salad were entree-sized - but they were awfully small entrees - I think they even came on salad-sized plates, not entree-sized plates, despite being $16-20.  The pasta I ordered (Pici with olives, capers, and broccolini) was tasty though, and good-sized.

The service? The servers seemed somewhat confused - they brought the wrong drinks a couple of times and had trouble getting the right dishes to the right person.

Probably won't go back any time soon!
author: Caroline S.

description:
Credo is absolutely adorable.  It's like I stepped into a toddler's center with word blocks.

Lasagne bolognese.  Get it.  Eat it.  Love it.

Return for a slightly upscale HH without the super upscale price.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Yum yum. Credo is good. The atmosphere inside the restaurant is very New York, or so I've been told. It feels like a good spot for a biz dinner, probably due to its location firmly in the Financial District. I've had consistently good service here both at the bar and seated at a table, and the food is tasty. I don't know that they switch up their menu often enough - I visited two separate occasions close to a year apart and I thought the menu looked exactly the same. Perhaps the pasta dish with pizza dough baked on top stood out, because it's so unique.

The pizza was delightful, baked perfectly with airy bubbles but I wouldn't have missed the squash. We also had the burratta appetizer and I'll be damned if it wasn't some of the most delicious burratta I've had in a while. I enjoyed the gnocchi ragu as well, though the gnocchi itself was a bit thick and floury.

The bartender mixed my friend an incredible Dimmi Collins, but I am really put off by the price of wines per glass. $8 for a mediocre montepulciano and $15! for a glass of pinot noir. Combined with the price of the food I can't say that I'd make this a regular weeknight stop, because while the experience is lovely, it's still pricey for what you get. 3.75 stars.
author: Lisa P.

description:
3.5.. almost to 4.

The service was great - prompt and friendly. We had the caesar, I had the mushroom ravioli, fiance had the scallops, and our friend had the squash pizza. The caesar was fantastic and I think the scallops were the outstanding winner here. I felt as if my pasta needed a little something - maybe more cheese or some different spices. The the squash on the pizza wasn't cooked - it was almost raw.

I would love to try their sugo though, i can smell it whenever i walk to work. will be back - would love to try some other menu items though.
author: laura f.

description:
I didn't want to let this place not get my review, as I think it's stuck in the 3.5 range, but it should be better than that!

First order of business: this place is on the higher end of $$. We're talking 17-20 for a "first plate" and 20-35 for a "second plate", although you typically don't have to order both! So, come in expecting to get a 10-15 dollar appetizer, 20 dollar plate, then drinks (and perhaps dessert).

I'm glad I wasn't put off by the price though since the food was great! My girlfriend and I ordered the rucola (arugula) salad and the saladini (pasta served in a bowl that is covered with pizza dough - think of "Italian pot pie"). I also got to try my friend's risotto and brussels sprouts. The food was very good - Italian inspired but certainly not totally authentic. But that's okay, I like to see a spin on it. My only critiques: the risotto wasn't a star (definitely some hints of Mac 'n' Cheese flavor in it) and the decision to leave the sage in the saladini dish lead to one unfortunate bite. Other than that, I left absolutely satisfied. Portions were good - the saladini is enough to share, especially with a side of the brussels sprouts.

Service was good - no problems here. In fact, we had arrived around 8 and they close at 9. Although we didn't end up leaving until 920, when the chefs had been long gone, they never rushed us and took their time putting things away for the day without ever giving us the impression that we were imposing.

That's not to mention the good music selection and fun atmosphere. I'm glad our party of 6 couldn't be served at Barbacco, because this place was legit!
author: Kellen F.

description: I absolutely love this place. The credo dish with the crust on top is great. And the best part is, they have a vegetarian option made of fresh seasonal vegetables. Money is well spent here! I love the contemporary feel and the recycled wood tables.
author: Maddie P.

description:
I came here with my mom and aunt after hearing so pretty awesome stories about this place.  I live to describe this place as simple food made really well.   I love the spicy olives in chili oil with focaccia.  Its actually spicy and tastes amazing with bread.  And that's just the free part of the meal.  I had their Fungi Pizza, Penne in Spicy Tomato Sauce, Fritto Misto, and Mixed greens with Prosciutto wrapped Shrimp in a grape dressing.  

Everything was delicious.  I didn't have the prosciutto wrapped shrimp but the dressing to the salad was really good.  The fritto misto was also very tasty with shaved veggies, shrimp and calamari.  The stand out for me was the Fungi Pizza.  It was delicious.  I mean honestly, who doesn't like truffle oil?  The pizza also had black fungus which is something i've never seen outside of asian cooking.  I added an bite to the pizza that you wouldn't usually get.  LOVED IT!!  The spicy penne was also really tasty and just perfectly done considering how simple it was.  

Other than the food, everything was great.  I liked the decor, atmosphere and service.  Sadly, I don't have a great story to tell here, but just know the food is great!
author: Aaron G.

description: Had a great private dinner in the downstairs room for my team after we launched our product. The staff was friendly and helpful, the food was delicious and timely and the ambiance in that room was just perfect. The sea scallops were fantastic, BTW.
author: John P.

description: I came to Credo with a small working (business casual-type) group of 4 for dinner. Overall, it was a good experience. Food was great, service was great, drinks were great and I really like how Credo is one of the few places in FiDi that doesn't close between lunch and dinner services. For dinner we started with the Beets and the grilled octopus - both were fabulous. For dinner we all ordered pasta dishes. I ordered the gnocchi, I know we had a linguini and clam order, a rigatoni in ragu, and noodles with salmon. Everybody at the table was pleased with their food. For dessert we shared the tiramisu, which is a must have. Service was timely and courteous and the restaurant wasn't terribly noisy. Great time. Definitely recommend if you're in the FiDi and want Italian food. Enjoy!
author: Ken C.

description:
Came here for lunch and their menu looks a bit like Barbacco's.  They had a lot of inspirational phrases up on their wall downstairs and that was a nice touch.  I don't think many people know that they have a downstairs at all.  You go down a flight of stairs and you're lead into this room.  Weird, but still nicely decorated.

We ordered the pizza and it was quite delicious. On a flatbread, so thin crust, good amount of cheese and ingredients.  Best of all, it was HUGE.  I am glad we ordered it as an appetizer.

I had the pasta and it was not bad. The spicy sauce had a pretty good taste to it.  

Friends tried their sandwiches and they said it tastes better than Barbacco's, so I guess I will order their sandwiches next time.  

The only thing that was missing from this restaurant is lack of service.  Waiter came, took order, and we never saw them again.  We were generally left to the service of the bus boys, which they did their job, but still, no checking back to see if the food were ok.  Also, they didn't give us plates for the pizza. We had to use our tiny plate that usually holds the bread/butter.  

Now that I think about it, should've just tipped 10% instead of the 18%. Dang it!
author: AhLin C.

description: This place is amazing!  I didn't know it existed and now I am sad that I have missed out for so long.  My fiance and I booked Credo for our Rehearsal Dinner since it is part of our wedding venue company (Merchants Exchange Building) and couldn't wait to try some of the menu items.  We went there for a date night and were blown away by the food, service and the atmosphere.  We really ate so don't judge us but we ordered 2 appetizers, 2 salads, 2 dinners and 2 desserts - we wanted to try options for our rehearsal guests :).  Everything we ate was just as delicious as the plate before it.  We did the meatballs and warm goat cheese appetizers and we could have licked both plates because they were so good.  My fiance had the green salad and I did the spinach - the spinach salad would be something worth going back for over and over again.  We did the steak and the garganelli - the garganelli deserves its own yelp review because it was mind blowing.  I wanted to push my fiance out of the way and eat it all myself.  We both took our first bite and said that this was a choice for the rehearsal dinner.  The whole time we were stuffing our faces the manager and staff made sure to answer our questions, give food recommendations and tell us about the restaurant.  Even though we both were grossly full, we couldn't pass us the caramel pot and chocolate grenache.  INCREDIBLE!!!!!!!!!! I am not even a dessert person and we were fighting over bites.  It was definitely one of the best meals I have had in a long time.  The manager Scott was the most gracious host and took me down to see the private room we booked and gave me ideas of how to set up tables, decorate etc.  We left there feeling like royals with stuffed bellies and anxiously awaiting our event.  We couldn't have had a better experience here and plan to bring friends back soon.  It is the perfect place for a date night or small group, there are plenty of food choices and the service is some of the best in San Francisco.  Go there!
author: Arica V.

description: Food is pretentious with out substance.  The desctption of the food I had to decipher for the others in my party.  Menu was limited. REally Really not good.  Only one bartender...And I cant remember his name. ughhh.. Can make drinks. So If I dont see him when I pop in for drinks then I move to my next watering hole.
author: Aloysia E.

description:
Stopped by for some girl chat and drinks before dinner. I've passed by this place a bazillion times and never once stopped to take note of it. When we came in, the ambiance was really nice. Great lighting and I loved all of the quotes and sayings that filled the walls. 

Our server was great and suggested some options before the three of us decided to just order one appetizer to share so we didn't spoil dinner. We ended up with the Fonduta del chorizo, which was housemade chorizo, caramelized onions, mozzarella, and crescenza. It was served with these awesome crispy triangles that tasted like parmesean. Pair that with the foccacia and olive oil dip and we us girls were in carb heaven.

We sipped on the Basil Julep, but they ran out of Basil and gave us Mint instead... which is what most places would serve anyway, right? In any case, the drinks were strong and they definitely weren't skimping.The fondue was very heavy and I'm glad we ordered just that. The cheese was super gooey but clumped up fairly fast, so dig in with a quickness! 

Very chill atmosphere and the pizzas looked awesome, so perhaps I'll have to give that a shot in the future.
author: Vinh N.

description: Wonderful service.  Very good food.  Cool atmosphere.
author: P B.

description:
The menu is on the pretentious side. Food is decent, though overpriced, for what it is; service is fine. I think it's overrated... The place is always crowded with financial-district types, so make a reservation.
They have all these "motivational" quotes everywhere on the walls. They're like what you would expect to see in greeting cards made by the Wall Street Journal or Reason Magazine.
author: Michael E.

description: Limited menu (even moreso for happy hour) but what we had was delicious. One of the more pricey happy hour spots and a very small selection of HH items.
author: Amber M.

description: Great food and nice service. Highly recommend. A little too loud for a business lunch, but perfect for something casual. They also have a great little corner that is kind of private for larger groups. We had a goodbye to a colleague and had a great time. BTW - LOVE the Gargannelli (sorry for spelling) with sage meatballs - it was so tasty my mouth waters as I type this review...
author: Carmellina E.

description:
I'm a writer and agency owner in the business of brand storytelling, so I love this place. I try to have all of my business meetings here as it reinforces the idea that brands should stand for something. The quotes on the wall represent a truly awesome collection. 

My last meal there was the Octopus Appetizer and the Gulf Prawns. My client had the risotto. All of it was tremendous. Quite delicious. I'm a true believer.
author: Todd A.

description:
This is one of those places that you go, its good.  Then a few weeks later you try to remember what you liked about it.  All I remember is the overwhelming amount of quotes on the wall that I'm still trying to figure out the point of.

Food was good, but our server was not good.  The bartender was not that great either.  They just disappeared most of the night.  I think a lot of places have an attitude about dine about town, like the riff raff comes in for it.  Hate to break it to you, but I probably would never come here otherwise!

I would give it more stars for the food, but all of the other things just overshadowed it.
author: jessica b.

description:
In a plethora of Italian restaurants they blend in with everyone else. 

The positives: Offering of some very unique wines. Simple interior. Good service. 

I'd definitely stop by again for a drink and an appetizer...3.5 stars.
author: Roger H.

description:
Had a birthday treat here. Really love the service and personality of the servers and bartenders. Decor is amazing and I love the quotes printed all over the walls. Food is delicious, healthy and portions are reasonable(for me). 
I would definitely return again!
author: Rachel L.

description:
My fiance took me to Credo for my birthday about a month ago, and it was a great experience! 

The atmosphere of the restaurant is very unique - the walls are filled with inspirational quotes and the bathrooms have audio of famous historic speeches.

The food was delicious as well. We ordered the Fondue of Wild Mushrooms appetizer, and I would have been satisfied with that alone. The mix of truffle oil, mushrooms, and cheese was amazing, and I can't wait to go back for more!

Our entrees were the famous Sedanini alla Credo and Lamb Chops. The Sedanini is truly unique, and the pizza dough that covered the bowl was absolutely delicious! The pasta itself was mediocre, and a bit on the salty side, but we still enjoyed it very much. The Lamb Chops were overpriced for the portion, but they were juicy, tender, and flavorful. I wish they came with a side of asparagus or other vegetable though.

Overall, our experience at Credo was great, and I would definitely go back to try more dishes.
author: Leslie F.

description:
Credo is underrated on Yelp, but also under-priced. If you order anything other than pizza, it's a three-dollar-sign joint. The obvious solution: order pizza!

We ordered a pizza margherita and the "Capesante" entree, which contained seared scallops with saffron risotto. The pizza was quite good, though it wasn't quite what I expected. I expected it to be Neapolitan-style:  thin, crispy, and lightly cheesed (it's a word according to my browser's spell-checker). It was relatively thin, but not too crispy and quite a bit of cheese. None of those things were problems; in fact, I appreciated the extra cheese since the quality was so high.

The scallop dish was also quite good. The scallops were perfectly seared, and the risotto was quite tasty. However, it was a small amount of food for an entree; only three large scallops for $26, compared to the $12 pizza that was about the same amount of food.

For dessert we ordered the flourless chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream. It was good, but not spectacular.

Long story short: order pizza. It was probably the best dish we had, and by far the best value.
author: Adam B.

description:
I really wanted there to be more on the menu.  There really was not that many choices to choose from.  I did enjoy the food that I ordered including the Antipasto and the mista.(sp)  But the manner in which they served them was hard to share.  The antipasto had a total of three pieces of bread and the other appetizer was piled high on three large pieces of bread. 

It was also weird how how they felt it was okay to charge 20 bucks for 5 raviolis, that had pesto that was really garlicky and not all that tasty.  It took over the pallet for the rest of the meal.

There were some elements there were really good including the olives and bread and the nicely made salad.  

But really??? Who puts lemon peel in a Manhattan?  There were too many faults to make a repeat trip, and I didn't even pay for this one.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Good spot for work lunch, and although a bit expensive, most things I've had were worth the price. I've been a few times for lunch, but I need to go back for cocktails because they look sooo great! The ambiance and decor is nice and the service is fine. Try one of the pasta dishes. The noodles are made in house -- nice treat!
author: J S.

description:
I don't believe the children are our future but I do believe in a thing called love. Credo = Consistently good. I had lunch here today, probably my 2nd time here for food, and I've been to the bar for drinks after work a handful of times too. Ok, who am I to kid, it's not like I don't drink wine with lunches too...

There's something to be said about sharing a good plate of veggies and calamari with a girlfriend at lunch, even better if fried. The fritto misto is a must get for me every time. I'm sure I'll be sick of it soon enough, but for now, it makes my belly happy.

Over the past few months, I've had the lovely opportunity to sample the margherita pizza, the rustica and the milanese with friends. I have to say the milanese is my favorite, with fresh egg on top and smatterings of asparagus strewn about. The margherita, you can't go wrong with, but the rustica just wasn't hitting the spot for me. I think the cheese was smoked last time, and for my tastes, it just didn't blend well with the other flavors. They are great to share, typical CA thin THIN crust but full of flavor, and really don't weigh you down. Unless of course, you eat the whole damn thing.

The penne with spicy red sauce and fresh mozzarella is a simple, yet satisfying dish, done well and a little too easy to keep shoveling in your mouth. I had the chance to sit at the chef's bar today and watch the cooks do their magic, watch the pizza oven go and those sauces get blended to perfection. I'm a sucker for a good show. 

Get reservations - for they seem to be quite the little spot for lunch in the FiDi as I'm sure they are for dinner or post traumatic conference calls and staff meetings. I'm also a fan of their outdoor seating occasionally when the temp is just right...in SF...which is a rare, yet splendid thing.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Loved this place! The atmosphere is relaxed but still elegant. The many quotes on the wall from famous people kept me intrigued the whole time. 

Everything we ordered was delicious, including really interesting cocktails. Special call out for the chopped salad -- wow. 

Finally, the service could not have been better: fast but not sloppy, attentive but not hovering. Can't wait to return and try more items from the drinks and food menus.
author: Richard T.

description:
We recently made a return visit and really liked it.  I really do like the vibe of the place.  The important thing is to order the right thing though.  I highly recommend the mushroom fondue.  
The real find here is the house wine.  I understand the owner also owns the winery, with limited production.  I'd buy it if I could.  It's fantastic, quite a value given the price.  I'd come back just to sip wine.  Actually, I think that's what I might recommend for this place.  Come here for apps and drinks?  It's a cute place with some great dishes (do a little research before you visit) and enjoy the terrific house wine!
author: Kara H.

description: They have a new chef and have updated the menu. The feedback from my group was not for the better. We miss the pasta dish with the dough on top :(
author: Brooke G.

description:
Love their Carbonara, a bit on the greasy side but the flavor is there. The shrimp salad is fabulous and pizzas big enough for 2.

Definitely a decent casual spot to go for lunch if you are in the FIDI area and feeling like having some great pasta.
author: Catalina C.

description: I wish the menu was a little bigger personally, but the heirloom tomato salad was really nice. The salmon entree was also quiet tasty. A good lunch.
author: Josh B.

description:
Modern place to eat...reminded me of LACMA or being inside of museum with all the quotes on the wall. 

Wasnt really a fan due to the following reasons:

1) After sitting down for 15 min. there was still no service...no water no waiter....Throughout the lunch our server was barely to be seen. I mean, they sat us in the basement but it was full so they should have had SOMEONE designated to that room most of the time...

2) After an hour (which is the normal alotted time span for most ppl in the fidi) our main dishes were not served yet. Appetizers were out but our main dishes came out at the 1.5 hour mark which normally  would have sucked (good thing my manager was with me...) 

3) Food was okay: Tried the hummus (very good), calamari (not fried so I didnt care for it as an appetizer), proscuitto wrapped shrimped (okay), fries (okay), pizza (good) and lasanga for main course (okay). For something I waited so long for, I expected the lasanga to be spankin' sorry.

The best part of my meal was probably the blood orange-grapefruit juice. If the drink was the best part for me and I wasnt AT A BAR, I think i will pass for lunch...

I wanted to try this place for happy hour but its from 2:30-5:30?! Nevermind.
author: Amy S.

description: It's been a long time since I ate at Credo. I wasn't really wow'ed. Eh, food was OK, service was OK - this place gets an A-OK.
author: Christine P.

description: Excellent food, well-prepared, good service, good environment.  Great place to take a friend. Can get noisy.
author: Scott J.

description: Went here for a company lunch, so thankfully I wasn't paying for any of this. They got my order wrong then took forever to get my food out, so I just asked for it to be boxed up to go. They did comp my meal and were very apologetic, which I appreciate, but the food was very disappointing. I got the half chicken, which had slimy skin and was served atop insanely over-salted vegetables. I was left with a somewhat unsettled stomach afterwards. Not worth it.
author: Ryan K.

description: The food was just a OK - I've been wanting to try it for all the feel good things and sayings the restaurant promotes.  I tried the spinach pizza, which was flavorful but got soggy within a few minutes - others at the table had the pasta with squid ink and the rabbit pasta - their plates were wiped clean!  Service was efficient but felt rushed - maybe it's not that a great place for a business lunch.  Willing to give it another try though - interesting enough menu.
author: Ketan D.

description:
We were pleasantly surprise by this place! we ordered a grilled chicken pizza, capaccio, and the lobster risotto. We are extremely picky with our pizza crust,  and this pizza was very well done with olive oil just like the one from Rome. The capaccio was also very yummy and fresh. The risotto was a bit blend but the lobster was very fresh and well executed.

We also love all the " I believe" quotes inside, because credo means I believe. 

We will definitely be back!
author: Leah C.

description: My company had a lunch outing here. While I fully enjoyed my salmon entree, which was cooked just right, and with the right amount of olive oil, others in my party complained about how salty their entree and sides were...I guess this place likes to lay it on thick with the salt? We sat downstairs, which provided a quiet ambiance that allowed us to carry on a conversation without shouting, although, upstairs seemed quite noisy. Overall, can be hit or miss, depending on what you order and where you are seated.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
I feel really bad giving this place such a bad review but this was one of the worst meals that I've ever had.

Came here with a girlfriend for dinner a few months ago. She ordered the soup of the day, which was a mushroom soup. It sounded promising but it seriously tasted and looked like Campbell's mushroom soup from a can. I mean the mushrooms were cut up so small that it didn't seem like it had the medley of mushrooms the waitress told about.

I ordered the calamari dish and the calamari was rubbery and not that good. I was starving though and continued to eat it. My entree was a crab/lobster ravioli and there were SHELLS in my ravioli. The sauce wasn't delicious either. I almost wanted to complain but I was so over my meal and just wanted it to be over. I think I ate 2 ravioli. 

After this, I was still SO starving that we went to get a 2nd meal at Akiko's. That was much better and a lot cheaper than Credo. This place is fine for happy hour if you're just getting drinks but I will never ever eat there again.
author: Jackie T.

description: Service was great and the Après-Spa cocktail was certainly refreshing, but the food was disappointingly mediocre! I ordered the lunchtime Market Menu and I was decidedly underwhelmed. The sausage and lentil soup was bland and the vegetables were mushy.  The pan fried barramundi was overcooked and the whole dish was a little boring and lackluster. It's sad to say that the best part of the meal was the complimentary focaccia and olives. Perhaps their regular menu items are better but for a $50 lunch, I'm not rushing back.
author: Vicente G.

description:
I heard about Credo after my girlfriend's boss treated her to lunch one day. We decided to come back for dinner because of her stellar lunch experience. 
We had reservations for 4 and wisely decided to make it nto happy hour while we waited for our table. Happy Hour prices were perfect. Beer, house wines and well cocktails suited our every desire. 
Everything after that was just as enjoyable. The service was just right. There when we needed them and away during most of our conversations. Most entrees tend to be a pricey but the menu blew me away. Quite the array of lucious mouthwatering meals. Worth every penny though.
Take a dive, splurge on yourself, make it to happy hour and leave warm inside and out.
author: Kate V.

description:
SUPER SLOW Service but really good food. 
If you are hungry when you arrive, definitely order appetizers because the food here takes a long time to arrive.  We ate here last night and it took about 2 hrs to get our entrees.  We expect to wait longer with a party of 7 but this was was quite a long wait. Luckily we ordered appetizers or things would have gotten ugly.  Even the desserts took a long time. The food was very good though -the osso bucco was fabulous.
author: K B.

description:
I'm playing review catch up here and so while it's been a few weeks since I've dined at this establishment, it is my civic duty to give you my two cents.  

The execution of their restaurant's theme is worth nothing as I found myself trying to soak up every single inspired quote written on the walls ... a difficult task indeed.  I especially love how intimately and well decorated their banquet room downstairs by the bathroom is set-up.  Seems like an excellent place to hold a big group event.  

I digress.  Onward ho to the food.  Between my dinner date and I we both shared a cured meats plate.  The pickled veggies were delish but sadly the only thing I really truly enjoyed here.  For entrees, she had a pasta dish and I had the seafood risotto special.  The portion sizing is definitely on the "don't wear a belt to dinner" side comparatively speaking for this price range, so you can certainly get some bang for the buck there considering their entrees are mostly $20+.  That being said, I find their food mediocre.  I found the risotto very heavy and lacking some zest and after trying the pasta I thought it was good, but nothing really special.  

Creative dining décor meets average Italian food at fine dining Italian food prices?  Take your money and run, hon.
author: Jean A.

description:
...lunch review only...

mMm... french fries with aioli, gnocchi with red sauce, wild mushroom pizza, scrimp wrapped in pancetta with salad in the mix, foccacia with olives, 2 glasses of wine!! so good! the foccacia and olives are especially yummy!!

 i LOVE all the quotes on the walls!! if your company is boring or just talking your head off, just stare at the walls and read the quotes, while you nod your head. thank god i didn't have to do that. btw, sit at the bar if you can. the bartender is pretty cool to chat with. :)
author: Ann T.

description: Went Credo with a group of friends and got the chance to try different kinds of appetizers and main dishes - in the end my conclusion is: food has no flavor, dull and it's very dissappointing to see a restaurant located very centrally, decorated with an urban feel but losing it all because of the zero taste in the menu.
author: Beril Y.

description: A nice colleague brought me here for lunch. It was a reminder that I don't work in Berkeley anymore. Very classy, trendy, and white shoe for a casual Italian place, we ate on the sidewalk. The menu was classic. I had a piadini and it was solid. Whole experience was solid, if not unremarkable.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Came here on a random Tuesday after work with my bf using a coupon from LivingSocial. We came in at a perfect time (around 6pm) because happy hour was still valid and we can order from the dinner menu. Happy hour consisted of few cocktails for $5 and small plates for $8. We decided to try two small plates and split a main entree. We asked our server/bartender if that is enough to feed us and she confidently said definitely.

This is what we ordered: 

Small plates-
Pici Toscano: heavenly. You can taste slight gaminess with mix of bison, veal, beef, and pork while the pasta is so fresh it was perfectly chewy. The fried kale really made it pop and savory. 
Burrata Crostini: If you've never had this before, you will love it. Bread, caramelized onions, fried kale, aged balsamic, and Burrata. YUM

Entree-
Painted Hills New York Strip: This one really surprised us. pan-seared foie gras, two cuts of of meat, brioche toast with balsamic. You have to try to really know what I mean by surreal delicacy. 

Overall, this place shocked me on how magnificent and filling their "small plates" were (I was thinking tapas size but it's more like appetizer size!) as well as excellent customer service and quality of entrees. Not to mention great ambiance with quotes striking intriguing conversations. I will be coming back!

Quick tip: MUST eat for happy hour. You can get away feeding two people happily with 3 small plates with a $25 bill. Not only that but the food is incredible. 2:30-6:30pm Mon-Fri. See you there.
author: Johanna P.

description:
Needed a spot in the Fidi for a party of 8 on Saturday night at 8:30pm. Credo had availability so went for it. Arrived right on time for our reservation and were seated immediately. The best thing about the whole night was the table. We were seated in a very large one piece square table in a little alcove next to the open kitchen. This was cool. But that's about it... 

The food ranged anywhere from downright bland to "suck all of the moisture out of your mouth" salty. The caesar salad was just plain awful and inedible. 

Loved the table and loved the company I was with, very unhappy with the food. Won't be back.
author: Jen D.

description:
Good restaurant.

What we ordered:

- Sedanini alla Credo (pasta dish topped with pizza dough and baked, the meat option)
- Vitello Tonnato (seared ahi tuna and veal)

The pasta dish was awesome. It's a bowl of pasta covered in pizza dough and baked. I've noticed some people have posted pictures. It's a nice experience. I ordered the meat option which comes with sausage, pancetta, etc. Good pasta, good sauce. They make the sausage fresh at the restaurant.

The seared ahi tuna and veal was also awesome. The sauce is an anchovy lemon sauce that's great with the tuna, not so great with the veal, or if you're not into fish.

Great ambiance and decor. Service was good too. 

All in all, a pleasant dining experience.
author: Parise S.

description:
I really like the interior design, especially "feed the people" with red neon light. The atmosphere is very cozy and warm :D 

Food tastes good. It's very light and clean. My main course was the sea bass with vegetable spaghetti.The sea bass was cooked perfectly and the vegetables are very crunchy and delicious. I think overall the dish had a good balance.
author: Jac L.

description:
The Good:

The service was amazing. We loved our server.

I recommend that you make a meal from the appetizers, which were pretty solid:

Get the pillowy soft Burrata Caprese and the Fonduta del Bosco

The Bad
The main course was sub-par and not worth the price tag.  The scallops were over-salted and the Osso Buco was a tad dry.

Update: Received notice from management. Again, I gotta say that these  guys know service. And because of their service-minded ethic, i've bumped them to a 3-star rating.
author: Vince H.

description:
Food slightly above average. Service very slow and there was only two of us at dinner. Place was full but not overly busy.
I have never waited so long between dishes. And we ordered standard fare for this place - pizza and pasta and salad. If service was normal, not even exceptional, would give this place 3.5 stars.
author: Atish B.

description:
I stopped here because I was walking around desperately looking for a sit down lunch at a place with a restroom in the financial district, but without white table cloths. (I know, my standards are way too high.)
Well, I was pleasantly surprised with lovely decor, spotless floors, table, and bar area and an interesting menu. My favorite credo board had SF only quotes. Awesome.
I had the spinach salad, which included delectably crunchy panchetta and the dressing was nice and light, and pretty reasonably priced at $10, which included 3 slices of bread and wonderfully soft butter. But I noticed even tables with more people only got 3 slices of bread too...sooo...don't plan on being too spoiled.
My main gripe is the hostess.  Twice when I was ordering with the bar tender (was sitting at the bar) she interrupted us in order to have a social chat about gossip about other employees/customers or who and so's girlfriend. I know standing at the podium post-lunch-rush can't be all that fun, but have some sense about what else is going on outside your own little world...Not impressed.
author: Jessica S.

description:
came here for a banquet so we used their banquet room on the basement floor.  The venue was ok, it was clean and sleek but nothing impressive. The food was decent but of course my standard for Italian food is pretty high having lived in Italy.  Also since it was a banquet the menu was pre-set so i'm not too sure of the name of the dishes we had.  

"THE MUST HAVE"
1. Hummus and garlic pita-like bread - very garlicy and flavorful!!! loved it.

2. desert - flourless chocolate cake - just right... a good balance of chocolate flavor... not too sweet

"THE YOU CAN DO WITHOUT"
1. the chicken pasta - the chicken was dry and the flavoring was off.  well actually there wasn't much flavor to it.

2. the shirt steak - once again it was ok.... nothing special 

3. spinach and strawberry salad  - not enough strawberries 

what i am impressive with is the service!!!!

for the huge party we had they were super attentive!... i was the only person in my table that was missing a fork and before i even asked for it they gave it to me.  Also when we were short a piece of chicken for someone at our table they were on it to and even gave us more than 1 piece. 

OVERALL: the food was ok but for the service i would give it a 3 1/2 stars !!!
author: JY L.

description:
The food was ok. I wasn't super impressed, but I will say the Tuna Tartare app was delicious :) 

Price was about right for the FiDi & the service was ok. Not a long wait at all so was nice to be able to get seated pretty immediately.
author: linda t.

description:
Not every restaurant can be fabulous, amazing and out of this world and there is nothing wrong with that. Keeps prices and our expectations reasonable. You won't find a scene here. 

Good, not everyday Italian dinner. Great flavors, inventive menu, perfect portion sizes, yummy cocktails and a good wine list. I don't think you could ask for more in a downtown location and I will come back. The service was good and I like the open kitchen. It's a good option to meet up with people after work when you all live in different directions and just want to share a meal and conversation.
author: Amarar S.

description:
I'm going to give this place a solid four stars, and that;s after taking time to review our experience and make sure everyone's on the same page.

We went here on a Wednesday night (for the 1000 points on opentable) and when we got there they did not have our name down; I double checked and realized I had inadvertently made reservations for Thursday night.  They were very accommodating and changed our reservation over so that we could still get the points, and they seated us immediately.

The Host really couldn't have been better.

We brought our own bottle of wine and it was quickly opened and decanted for us.

For appetizers we split the Pork belly (DIVINE - just melt in your mouth quality) and the fonduta.  Both really were excellent, and have probably helped this place in getting 4 stars and not 3.
My only qualm is that our bread and olives were brought out when we were almost halfway through our apps instead of before our order being taken.  But, not that a big of a deal in the grand scheme of things.

For entrees we had the Funghi pizza, the prosciutto pizza and the pork ravioli.

The pizza's really were big we probably could have shared one and had one other entree between the three of us and it would have been enough.  Out of all the entrees the prosciutto pizza was a tad disappointing; I'm not sure if my expectations were too high, but it was just a very basic pizza with huge strips of prosciutto on and spinach and other greens on top.  The dough could have been cooked for a minute longer and the prosciutto could have been sliced into lsightly smaller pieces, and the greens on top, good, but just too overwhelming.  It didn't look like a pizza made with a lot of love.  Eating it was also difficult as the prosciutto had not been fully sliced on the pizza, so it kinda came off in one glob.  It wouldn't have been hard to slice it properly and/or give me a proper knife to cut it properly.

At the end of the meal we had more or less a whole prosciutto pizza left (I only ate one slice and hubby had one) half a plate of port ravioli, and 3 slices of the Funghi pizza.  I guess the wine had kinda hit our heads by then, because despite asking to have it wrapped, we totally forgot and left the restaurant without our leftover :(  We only realized when we were getting off bart in the east bay, and of course it was too late by then.  

That's why I took a couple of days to make sure I write a fair review, I circled in with hubby and girlfriend and they confirmed that we were sat at the able for about 15-20 minutes after they cleared our food finishing our wine and chatting.  That meant that they had plenty of time to bring our doggy bags to us; of course we could have asked but out of site out of mind.  So, one star goes there.  I'm sure my follow up would have got me my food, but it's not my job to follow up.
author: Kym P.

description: $26 for a small portion of succulent salmon in an interesting room with pop quotes that contain the word "believe" in them.
author: Ethan K.

description:
Finally - a good FiDi spot for lunch where service, atmosphere and fare are all good are the price affordable!

Today, I had vegetarian lasagna which was surprisingly good.  The coffee was excellent.  

In summary, a much better place to eat than any in the "lunch alley."
author: David A.

description:
The best soup I've ever had, hands down. I'm talking about the traditional pasta e fagioli and it is outstanding.

The setting is relaxed and mellow. Note the custom made tables. Pick out some interesting 'credos' on the wall. 

The food is tasty and filling. Been there twice now and will definitely be headed back soon. 

Our waitress was something of a letdown last time there, but still the food was terrific. 

It's actually not difficult to park near there in the evening. Check it out.
author: Alan S.

description:
This place is a case of lost potential.  While this placed opened with much fanfare, it has quickly dropped to mediocre food.  It is alas a story of lost potential.  Service is still decent, but the "gourmet" pizza is not even as good as the free wood-fired thin crust pizza that you get for free at Palio d'asit during happy hours.  My NY steak was underseasoned and overcooked.

San Franciscan's are ruthless when it comes to food.  This place needs to quickly spend six figures and hire a "top chef"; otherwise, this place will be soon be doomed.
author: Laurence H.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE IT! 

I had my birthday dinner there with 13 other people and it was fantastic. Every one of my guests enjoyed their dinner. 

Tried the veal ravioli and it was outstanding! Every single guest finished their meal and raved about it. Their cocktails were really good too. 

And the service was fantastic. For me, service goes a long way and this did it. 

Don't forget to read the quotes on the wall, some are way awesome!
author: Myra B.

description:
Another decently priced lunch joint that accepts reservation. Yay! Service was very quick and attentive, although it may be because we were seated at what I consider the best table in the restaurant. If you can, request a seat by the window. This is best, because it's the quietest and it's right by the server's computer, so you can easily get their attention.

Yes, this place gets super loud. But, food is quite good. We had soup, pizza and salad. Everything was fresh and refreshing.

This has become one of my standard lunch spots.
author: Su K.

description:
A great upscale lunch spot in the center of the FiDi, but bit off of the beaten dinner path. So worth the detour, and free parking right outside after 6! I will also highly suggest this place for a first date just for all the quotes on the wall. Run out of things to talk about, you have dozens of very interesting ideas to discuss. Date goes badly, you have a lot of reading material to pass the time too...

Their bread is a tasty warmed focaccia, that comes out with a small bowl of olives and a very flavorful sea salt. The SALT impressed me. I am all about attention to detail like this. 

We started out with the octopus carpaccio, which was very good. I didn't know what to expect, having only had beef, or salmon carpaccio before, but I was impressed with the dish that we got.

for the main I had a veal with asparagus and mashed potatoes with asparagus puree. Nice and simple, but the flavors were amazing and blended so well together. The veal was the best veal I've ever had, it was seasoned perfectly, and the potatoes were absolute best I've had.....ever. It was a straight forward dish that was seriously unpredictably good. I got an absolute foodie face buzz that I haven't gotten in a long time. 

Tiramisu and espresso for dessert. Delicious. 

Probably my favorite part: The chef came out to the dining room to check on people! That is such an old school, time consuming thing to do, whenever I'm at a restaurant and I see the chef walking the floor, I am already impressed. 

I will be back to Credo very soon.
author: Sterling S.

description:
I officially love going out with my pregnant friend.  I wish I would have found this out sooner, since she is due in 2 weeks.  Table with no reservations?  Check.  Special accommodations for her temporary and soon to be gone dietary needs?  No problem.  Hostess memorizing her baby's name by end of meal?  Done.  Oh, I am going to miss this.  

Tried it for the first time, and this place was buzzing during lunch, and it was pouring out! I had the chicken and rosemary pizza and it is made to order thin crust, and totally delicious.  Could have had the whole pie by myself no problem, but I didn't want to look that desperate.  My friend can't eat garlic for now, and of course, we choose an Italian restaurant.  They were actually super accommodating, and they made a dish just for her, which she really enjoyed, and she is a picky eater to start wish.  

We shared a tiramisu for dessert, and it felt totally sinful.  If you eat one by yourself, be advised; it is delicious, and you will feel like a really bad person afterward.

Glad to have found this place really close to work, and will definitely keep bringing people over.
author: Vivian P.

description: Went here for a team lunch and it was great spot.  It's a open restaurant which can be loud at times, but the decor is nice and the open kitchen is cool.  Shared two types of pizza, had the mushroom pizza and the sausage/peppers pizza.  Mushroom pizza was very good, no red sauce and this it has truffle oil on it.  Would definitely go back again.  Looks like a good spot for a quick dinner after work
author: Josh L.

description:
My ex-coworkers planned a going-away lunch for me at Credo. The food was fine but nothing to write home about; I ordered the Pizza Funghi and the Strawberry Shortcake for dessert. I've certainly had better. But the main reason I'm writing the review is due to the lack of good/attentive service. We sat for approximately 10 minutes before our server apparently had the chance to even take our drink orders. We then sat for an additional 10-15 minutes before we even received our drinks - which did not consist of anything alcoholic or remotely difficult to concoct.

I wouldn't come here again, nor would I recommend it to anyone, but if you're in the neighborhood and you see it as your only option, go for it.
author: Michelle B.

description:
It is hard to get a seat here at lunch time unless you go early or have reservations. Not that easy to get past the feisty hostess for a seat. 

White Bean Hummus - Quite Good. 
Antipasto - Loved the different salamis and coppa. 
Beet & Carrot Soup - Cream based and oh so delicious. 
Spinach Salad - Add your protein and you have a complete meal. 
Seared Scallops - The scallops can be a little on the raw side but they were happy to re-cook them for me. 
Spaghetti Carbonara - Oh so rich but Oh so yummy. 
Arnold Palmer - The lemonade did not have enough presence in this mixture. 
Special Seafood Stew - Salmon and Sturgeon with Clams, Mussels, Squid, etc - you can't go wrong with this special. 
Pappardelle with Lamb Ragu - Meat was tender and pappardelle al dente. 

Their pizzas are thin crust and can be shared. If you work close by, this should be a must try at least more than once.
author: Elaine L.

description:
Edit: I toned this down because the first pass of my review was perhaps a bit too harsh.  Maybe you'll have a better experience than I; I think the restaurant has potential and the people working there shouldn't live and die by my one review.

If I had to choose eating here again or some horrid act of desperation I would choose eating here again. But that's about all that would get me back in here.  It's not that the food is terrible, it's not, it's decent, but it's also not the clean, simple flavors I expect from Italian food.  And it's not that the service wasn't acceptable, it was actually quite good.  It's just the cost / value isn't there for me.

I had a simple bowl of rigatoni and a beer and paid well over $20 before tip.  My friend ordered some bizarre concoction that was basically a bowl of pasta covered by pizza dough.  I mean, come on for more than $20 my pasta had better be damn near sublime,  I mean I better leave feeling like I couldn't approach that at home, but it wasn't.  Instead it was just a rigatoni with a slightly heavier than expected creamy smoky sauce that felt like it had been under the heat lamp for 20 minutes.  And last time I checked Italian food was about class and sophistication, not covering a bowl with pizza dough and throwing it in an oven for a few minutes.  Maybe give it a shot but I don't see what all the 5 star reviews are about.
author: Nate A.

description: Credo is a nice restaurant - fun vibe, nice menu and the staff was friendly. But, I do not know what was happening in the kitchen the night that I went. The food took a LONG time to arrive. The staff was aware of it and brought us free beers and olives to make up for it - but the service was just very slow. That said, when the food arrived it was tasty but I wasn't very impressed with the pizza crust.
author: Sarah G.

description:
So I'm actually taking a quick break from studying so I'll make this short and sweet:

Credo has a nice American-Italian menu with some great fresh ingredients and hearty portions. The feel of the place was nice, and the service, altho a little slow, was wonderful (the waitress carried around a tide-pen for spills on shirts....genius!! + 1 star just for that!). Really great for seafood :)

It's located in the Financial District, so downers include (1) finding parking that won't break the bank and (2) the price of the food.
author: Ash M.

description:
Good food, Great view! 

I am not a big Italian food fan (is Pizza Italian?) but I was surprised by Credo. 

I joined a friend for lunch and I have to tell you, my entrée was so good I finished the whole portion. We arrived for lunch (reservation through opentable.com) and were seated immediately. We were seated towards the front of the restaurant which was great if you like to people watch on the busy streets of San Francisco. 

Bread and water were brought to the table as customary and I ordered the "Cream of Mushroom Soup" as an appetizer. I must say that my pallet is way to barbaric for a soup of this nature, I was expecting the same color and consistency of Campbell's Soup. Suffice it to say, I did not enjoy the soup (no fault to the chef) 

My lunch-mate ordered the salad (no complaints) and chatted while we waited for our entrées. I ordered the Lasagna Bolognese (sp) and our orders were there before we knew it. I was so giddy over the taste from the first bite that I cannot remember what my lunch-mate ordered. I didn't hear any complaints coming from her side of the table either. 

The bill was resonable for eating in the financial district at lunchtime...no dessert :-( cause I'm trying to bring sexy back... AGAIN

I will definately return to experience what the dinner atmosphere is like and this time sample dessert because sexy is back with SWAG!

Bon Appétit
author: ARSON P.

description:
Came here today for co-worker's b-day lunch...chose Credo cuz of the groupon I had purchased...

There were 7 of us, 3 of us (including me) ordered the seafood stew w/ mahi mahi, salmon, mussels and shrimp.  2 ordered a panini of proscuitto, tomato & mozzerella, and a panini of free range chicken w/ pesto, 2 ordered pizza, a sausage tomato pizza and a artichoke heart, sundried tomato and basil pizza.

The stew was awesome.  We all finished the stew to the last drop.  It was flavorful, hot, and full of seafood essence.  Pizza was crisp, light and very good as well.  There were praises for the paninis as well.

They served the b-day boy w/ a tiramisu on the house, and it was light, not too sweet, rummy and yummy!

You can't beat the quotes on the wall...the decor and how we had to walk 2 flights of stairs down to our table...which was private and intimate~!
author: Diana C.

description:
The ambiance is very casual, with wimsical quotes on the walls. It might feel best-suited for lunch; for dinner it felt a bit too casual for this price point. It may sound cheesy, but I think it'd help set the mood for dinner if there were some candles, flowers, and more subdued lighting. 

The cocktails sounded amazing, but unfortunately they were out of a key ingredient (elderflower) to make many the cocktails on their drinks menu. Bummer. However the wine was superb and the food was a hit overall. Service was friendly and very casual. I want to try this place for lunch next time.
author: Ryan L.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian

2.5 stars

My D.C. enjoyed the carpacio appetizer but wasn't thrilled with the ravioli (selected by the waiter when asked to decide between two entrees). My pizza was fine but the crust wasn't right. It was crackly; not crispy, but crackly. Good pizza crust need a little chew to it somewhere and this was closer to a flatbread.

The food needs a little work but they might warrant a revisit for a pasta dish if I'm in the area.
author: Bob R.

description:
I had heard a lot of great things about this place from friends working in FiDi and come here for happy hour so decided to check it out for myself. The food lived up to expectations. We ordered an Affumicata pizza (basically a pizza with chicken, roasted garlic, kalamata olives, pecorino fresco, and caramelized onions). The crust is thin with generous amount of toppings and the taste/smell of cheese is not overpowering. The decor is modern and area is rather spacious considering it's a restaurant smacked in the middle of FiDi.   

What I was *not* expecting was the service. My friend and I sat down and the waitress immediately asked us if we were ready to order and we barely got our menus so we said we needed a minute. Lo and behold, she returned in exactly one minute! Alright, so we told her we need a few minutes....and when we were ready to order she was nowhere to be found. All of the above didn't bother me so much until this moment - my friend and I were chatting and still had about half a pizza left (ie. four slices). She came over and asked if we wanted a box...um I thought this was a restaurant not a speed-eating contest? She kept pacing back and forth with a few "are you girls ready for the check?" every now and then. Well we took the hint and ate faster, as soon as we finished our pizza she shoved the check in our faces.

The dining experience went downhill when the waitress was trying to usher us out...not sure what the hurry was since there were quite a few  empty tables around us. Anyhow, I wouldn't mind coming back for food/happy hour but not exactly a fan of the service.
author: Melody L.

description:
Came here for a work lunch so I can't really speak to value (since I didn't pay... haha). We didn't have a reservation, but they squeezed in our group of 4 anyways. Always much appreciated.

I had the spinach salad with chicken, and I was almost tempted to lick the plate for every last speck of goat cheese (although the chicken was a bit dry)! The Rose paired perfectly with the salad, nice and light.

Everyone else seemed to enjoy their lunches as well, although the tortelloni was a rather small plate compared to everyone else's. Two people got the specials and were very happy, so when in doubt I recommend those!
author: Shannon B.

description:
Went here about a month ago on a Friday night for dinner. I found Credo by following my nose. Truthfully, I was looking for a different restaurant in the area I found on Yelp but the aromas coming within pulled me in. Since it was crowded I sat at the bar. The bartender was really warm and friendly. when we were seated we were provided with warm baked bread and olives. (Note: I am a fan of olives. I mean I got olive t-shirts and key chains --no just kidding but I do love a good olive)  and hummus. The hummus was delicious and made from scratch, the olives & garlic were the kinda things legends are made of. So, I can say I was most impressed  - - but I think you get the picture. 
I ordered the chicken (which was just melt in your mouth good) I noted several people around me had ordered the chicken as well, I wish I could say it was the most popular item on the menu but....wait there's something else. My boyfriend ordered the steak with Bone Marrow,,,now if you have never tried bone marrow before, do yourself a favor &  open yourself up to the experience. And if its your first time, do  it at Credo!   All I can say about the bone marrow is... I would never had thought there would be a time when I would want to lick a bone clean & in public no less....but I have meet that time and I meet it at Credo. It was delicious. I have nothing to compare it to because it was my first time trying bone marrow, but, I imagine I have experienced it at the highest level.  I  noted that apparently everyone in the place knew about the bone marrow but me. The steak was quite literally flying out of the kitchen.  
In summary , Yes Credo is definitely winning! When I tell you the taste lived up to smells coming out of this place. Believe it me it does!
author: Ericka G.

description:
The sweet potato fries are their saving grace. Enough said.

Went back for round too and the service was great, the food (a special soup) was good but didn't set my world on fire. 

The olives they serve are fun and delicious (made in house too I believe)...
author: Allison S.

description:
Went to lunch at Credo on a typical Wednesday.  What a treat!  It was indeed busy, and despite having no reservations, my buddy and I were sat at a corner of the bar and proceeded to enjoy a wonderful meal.  We started with some drinks and their fried olives - so yummy - and I highly recommend.

Our entrees were exceptional: I had the halibut w/ vegetables, my friend had one of their pasta dishes.  We both enjoyed and would have stayed for dessert but we were too full.  I'll definitely return!   Host and waiters were all professional and delivered very good service. 

I recommend their signature drink: Aperol, prosecco, and spritzer.  Heck, I might go back just for that!
author: JJ V.

description:
I visited Credo for dinner several weeks ago and really enjoyed it. Food was great, service good, interesting space. Worth coming back. 

Two days ago I went back for lunch. Credo is less than a block from my work and the lunch prices seemed acceptable for what I knew the quality to be from the first visit. 

Food was good, not too pricey. BUT.... I haven't felt this pressured to hurry up, eat and get out of any restaurant EVER. It bordered on rude. They must rely on turning the tables a certain number of times each lunch service in order to make a financial goal. There wasn't a long line of folks waiting to be seated and we did have reservations. I won't be going back for lunch. Dinner: maybe. But definitely not for lunch.
author: Amy V.

description: Been here twice, both for lunch. The first time was deelish, the margherita pizza was perfection and the carbonara pasta was a creamy, peppery, porky plate of heaven. The second time....notsomuch. I ordered a shrimp scampi w/tomatoes pasta dish since the menu had changed and the carbonara wasn't available for lunch anymore (who takes off carbonara??!?!). The shrimp was way overcooked and the pasta way undercooked and I don't mean al dente, I mean al crunche. The tomatoes were mushy and I bit into several large chunks of raw garlic which looked like the chef just went too fast with the knife and didn't properly check his work. While a fun atmosphere, this place's quality and consistency changes as their menu changes. Probably won't be back after my last experience.
author: Shariyah M.

description:
OK, cool concept in theory, but the food was just awful. I am really not a complainer, its more feedback for the owners...

Spinach salad was tough, not warm, not delicate.
Veal raviolis, WAY too much salt, and covered in sauce to mask something.
Atmosphere, too loud. Put some noise blocks in the corners or something, who wants to hear a bunch of loud mouthed cougars.
Lemoncello, tasted like the rind. 

These guys are not gonna make it if the food can't sustain a quality standard.
author: eric g.

description:
Good food, great atmosphere, good service. I was here for dinner, and there was no problem sitting and talking for a good two hours. 

The meal started out with little bites of good bread and salty olives. We ordered, to share, the caprese (mozzarella with tomatoes) as an appetizer, a tossed salad, and the Rustica pizza. The mozzarella could have been a bit more flavorful, but it had a good texture. The salad was a standard salad; the vinaigrette was very tasty. The pizza crust was thin (which I like!), and the smoky sausage, caramelized onions and peppers on top were so good.

Good amount of food; I should have skipped dessert, but of course, I had to indulge. I had the funghetto, which, to me, was a puff pastry cut in half and filled with vanilla ice cream, drizzled with chocolate sauce. Very satisfying!

It all amounted to being happily fed while being engaged in conversation. The quotes on the wall are so fun to read, and the space is welcoming. Come with friends and family; I'm sure you'll enjoy it.
author: A.L. H.

description: Service was slow and non existent for a good portion of our lunch. We were downstairs and that seems to slow things way down. Ordered the risotto. It was awful. No other way to put it. Watery rice with barely cooked peas and soggy meat pieces. But never got to tell our waiter... See service note above. I ate bread while the the other people picked at their plates. Really disappointed.
author: K H.

description:
My good friend and I visited this new restaurant last Friday for lunch.  We made reservations before the lunch crowd so getting a table wasn't a hassle.  It was very busy.  
The service was attentive and the food came out quickly.  We had a Rustica pizza for an appetizer and that was very good.  I really liked my Schiaffoni Pasticciati dish.  I love pasta and the creamy sauce.  That was recommended to me by our server.  It was a great lunch experience.
author: Brent T.

description:
Great place to go for a quick business lunch. I saw that some of the other reviewers felt like they were rushed, but we didn't get that, and I actually really liked how snappy the service was. It was just right - as was the food. I tried the Ciabatta con Pollo and fries, which were marvelous. Other people at my table had salads and other sandwiches and all were impressed. The prices are a tad on the high side, but it's what you should expect for this area and food quality. The place was hopping at noon on a Monday but had a great atmosphere.
Worth a try!
author: H M.

description:
Excelling in mediocrity...still.  It's been a bit over a year since I first reviewed Credo.  It's convenient for me and I had really hoped that they would pull it together- Sadly, they haven't.  

My pizza this evening was horrific.  There is absolutely no reason in the world to put that much cheese on anything.  It was gross.  Per ounce, cheese in one of the most expensive ingredients in the kitchen.  Your cooks are cannibalizing your margins on that item...Not to mention the fact that it was nearly inedible and the result was a customer that won't return.  

Credo- Really?  After all of the reviews saying things like "nothing special", "just ok", "underwhelmed", and "average quality" you've done nothing...Nothing.  I suspect that this space will be available for lease in the near future.

I won't bother coming back.  I'll walk a bit further and go to Barbacco- Similar price point but superior food.
author: Spidermonkey J.

description:
I'm updating not because I came back here, but because the manager of the joint contacted me via yelp, and that deserves mad props.  Any manager that takes the time to contact individual reviewers obviously cares deeply for their business and is committed to customer service.

For that, I salute you.
author: Clayton R.

description: This place is dangerous to your health in my opinion.  Their undercooked chicken meatballs gave me what the doctor called Salmonella poisoning.  Their poor service gave me just as much to barf about too.  There's a reason this isn't on anyone's "A" list of places to eat in San Fran.  Moreover, you have a bad experience and report it to the management - as we did twice - don't expect a return call or your bill adjusted.  Expect to be ignored. Their arrogance will get someone very sick or worse someday. Thankfully, I recovered from the experience here. An older or very young person may not have.
author: John F.

description:
In Latin, "Credo" means "I believe."  Upon walking into this new Financial District hot spot, I immediately noticed the prints on the walls.  The prints contain scrawling quotes from famous individuals (political, controversial, inspirational, artistic...) all beginning with the phrase "I believe."

Here's what I believe:

I believe that Credo will become an established destination in the SF culinary community in the coming weeks.  

I believe the sauce in the sauteed calamari is so delectable that it needs to be licked clean from the bowl.  

I believe that sometimes, just sometimes, the kids need to be left at home.  Seriously, why bring children to a soft opening at a restaurant?

I believe that all service at restaurants should as fine-tuned as Credo.  The staff here is fantastic which made this a notable dining experience.   

I believe the Sedanini alla Credo is a dish made for a king.  A hefty king.  A king who loves pizza and pasta so much that he can't choose between the two and wants both rolled into one monster meal.  This dish can EASILY be shared.  

I believe that Credo covers all its bases in terms of variety, yet not one part of the menu seems to fall short.  There is something for everyone here.  

And finally, I believe that no matter what dishes they decide to keep and cut from their soft opening, the lovely dining experience at Credo will secure more visits and recommendations from me.  

Sanitas bona! Bene tibi!
author: Kerry D.

description:
we celebrated a friend's birthday here the other day... wanting to try a different place close to work. 
the mint, Ginger cocktail I ordered was bland.. needed more alcohol.
