the seafood risotto was okay.,. d mussels tasted weird. my friends and I agreed that all in all, d place decor was cool but the food and drinks were nothing to be excited for.
author: Learnee L.

description:
The bf and I were apart on Valentine's Day, so we needed a good place to celebrate our second one together. This year, he let me do the choosing and after a little searching, I found Credo. 

This is a very untraditional Italian restaurant. Yes, there's pasta and pizza, but there are so many other items on the menu that it's way beyond what I was expecting. We ordered tuna capraccio to start, then I had the seafood risotto and the bf had steak. 

The capraccio wasn't too fishy (for me-- he thought it was), and came with thinly sliced cucumbers that were a perfect combination when I got both on my fork. The risotto was fantastic; it was a little milky which I've never seen before, but it worked. It comes with clams, mussels, calamari and shrimp. I reaffirmed my dislike for clams, but otherwise the seafood was amazing and there was definitely a lot of it. The bf's steak was also very good, though I thought it was a bit cold. 

I noticed the menu has hummus and rosemary foccacia as an appetizer; not sure why that's there because they serve you the foccacia with a side of olives, and hummus is more for Mediterranean restaurants, so I am glad we didn't order that. The bread is damn good though, so I'm glad you get it!

Oh and drinks! I got a glass of wine which I wasn't too in love with...some white wine the waiter recommended but honestly, I should have taken the "sorry, no Reisling by the glass" information to heart. The bf, on the other hand, ordered this absolutely amazing cocktail off the menu: it's the one at the top of the list that has elderflower liquor and limoncello in it....like spiked lemonade! Luckily he let me take several sips.

Lastly, we ordered dessert. A rare occassion in our dining excursions because we are always too full, but the wine soaked pear was totally worth it and just enough of a dessert.

I liked this place. I guess it wasn't as romantic as a Valentine's celebration should have been, but I'd suggest it for a dinner date.
author: Emilia S.

description:
went for a Friday lunch with friend from office- placed was packed and we waited for a good 20 minutes for out reservation time. unfortunately there was no room at bar, so we just had to wait at hostess desk.  Ended up sitting at the chef's counter overlooking kitchen- which i prefer. It is a great way to see and smell the dishes being prepared.  We had a fritto misto which was flavorful while still being light. We then cleansed the palate with a spinach, goat cheese and prosciutto salad. it was wonderful. Everything was fresh and filled with flavor.  went to pizza next- 4 cheese...nice and thin but could have you a few more minutes for extra crispiness. Enjoyed a nice Italian wine off the wine list- decent bottles but by the glass seemed a little weak.  Dessert was tiramisu- unbelievably good. so light and fluffy while still being sweet.

Nice place to be for excellent food- but loud.

Highly recommend and anxious to go back for dinner.
author: Scott W.

description:
Really cute place. Was expecting more from the food quality. It was mediocre.
But nice place to have appetizers and a glass of wine after work.
Liked the burrata and the tempura asparagus.
Pastas and entrees could be a lot lot better.
author: Neil B.

description:
I have passed Credo on Pine Street numerous times and was really looking forward to sampling their happy hour. I made a reservation online for a table and was happy to get one at short notice. Once I got to the restaurants, I realized why OpenTable was completely open--there was only about 5 customers in the restaurant. We sat at our table.....and sat.....after about 10 minutes we got up and moved over to the bar. The hostess came up to me and said in a snarky manner, "Was there something wrong with your table." I replied that there wasn't but we want happy hour and it seemed that you weren't serving the tables during happy hour. To that response, she scoffed off without responding.

We sat at the bar for another 5 minutes as the bartender finished up making a cocktail for another customer. Once he directed his attention to us, we asked to see a happy hour menu, since we hadn't seen one yet. Much to our surprise, happy hour was over in just a few minutes, at 6pm. The website states 6:30pm, so we had assumed we would have plenty of time to order a drink and a few snacks. Another surprise about their in-person happy hour menu is that about 1/3 of what is advertised online is actually offered. We opted for a cheese plate of 5 different cheeses. It looked great; however, the five large slices of cheese came with 4, yes only 4 mini slices of crostini. Straight away I asked for more bread and was told it would be $1-2 for more crostinis. Fine. The food runner came back with 4 small crostinis which cost us $.50 each. I just don't understand how a restaurant can charge you for bread on a cheese plate. Four slices of tiny crostini is not nearly enough for 5 large slabs of cheese. Until they fix this problem, I would avoid the cheese plate, unless you don't mind spending an additional $10 on bread to eat with your cheese. 

I must say, I was thoroughly disappointed in Credo. Although, I only sampled their happy hour, I was not impressed and a bit frustrated when I left. Happy hour should be fun....Don't nickle and time your customers and then not offer the advertised happy hour.
author: Alice S.

description: If you're feeling spendy for lunch, this is a great place for a pizza (house made sausage) and a fancy cocktail (Italian Grayhound). And the (free) olives are especially delicious (and pitted).
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Summary: Good food.  Service can be more attentive.

4 of us shared 4 dishes.  All 4 had very good flavors, but if I have to rank them in order of what I liked most to least, they would be:

1. Trofie Al Pesto Genovese
2. Vesuvio Pizza
3. Milanese Pizza
4. Pollo Salad

The one thing that would've made my experience better was if I didn't have to constantly flag someone down for more water.  It didn't help them that I happened to be getting over a cough and had a scratchy throat that demanded a lot of water.  But anyway, I digressed.  It also didn't help them that the water glasses they use, though cute, are too small to serve any purpose.  Couple gulps and it's time for another refill.  How about bigger glasses to help out the water boy?

I will definitely be back.
author: Irene T.

description:
Great service and decor.  Still happening (loud and many full tables) even for dinner on a weeknight when the area is generally dead by then.  

Food though was inconsistent.   Some great dishes and others not so good.  

What's good:
- mozzarella & prosciutto appetizer with salad.  the balsamic was nice and sweet
- pizza (4 cheeses).  nice and crispy. topped with arugula

what's not good:
- paradelle pasta with funghi and truffle oil.  texture is all wrong.  tastes like it's yesterday's pasta re-heated or basically undercooked. 

what i'm indifferent about (nothing special but i could eat again):
- veal meatballs.  tasted good, with tomato sauce, but nothing to write home about
- tortellini with browned sage/butter.  the crisp sage is always amazing in any dish.  it was a good dish-the tortellini is filled with cheese so it was really filling.  about maybe 6-8 tortellini units in 1 dish?
author: Alias A.

description:
The great thing about eating dinner here instead of lunch is that you can stuff yourself full of things that normally would make you fall asleep (which is apparently frowned upon in a workplace situation)..

yummy things like..

mushroom fondata.  whiffs of truffle oil and yummy chewy cheesy mushroomy delightfulness.

a decent but small charcuterie platter.  housemade pickled berries.

slightly overpriced but drinkable wine.

meaty steaky textured seabass with solid potato gratin and eggplant something or other.

lightly sauteed spinich with a bit of garlic.

heavy but small chocolate cake for dessert with whipped cream and gelato.

Not a luxurious decor and dinner took slightly longer than I would have preferred (around two hours) but overall a nice place to have a quick dinner if your office is right nearby.
author: Poppy C.

description:
I came here last Friday with my girlfriends for dinner.  This is a very chill restaurant in a very casual setting.  The restaurant was less than half-full at 7:30PM, and this is a very small restaurant.  

The waitress asked us what we would like to drink .  We wanted champagne but coincidentally all three selections on the menu were unavailable.  The waitress explained that an event booked earlier that week left them with a low supply of alcohol.  Seriously?!? Then I remembered the restaurant had an announcement on their yelp page promoting 30 different bottles for $30 or less.  I asked the server about that.  She said, "We only serve those on the weekends, but let me get you the menu anyways."  I always assumed Friday was part of the weekend.  Oh well.  Our first choice was a white wine.  Surprise! They were out of that wine.  Luckily, our second choice, a bubbly red wine was available.  However, there was another obstacle.  It wasn't chilled.  She had to chill it while we drank it.  The first glass wasn't cold at all, but subsequent refills were much better.

The food was very good. We ordered the mushroom fondue and the sausage pizza for starters.  They were great.  I also loved my main course, which was the sausage penne pasta in a tomato sage sauce baked under a pizza dough that resembled puff pastry.  My friends had the scallop risotto and the steak.  Those were yummy as well.

Besides the sad fact that they were out of many drinks, the server was very attentive.  She refilled our glasses promptly and made sure we were enjoying our food.  I would've actually given 3.5 stars if that option was available.
author: Gloria Y.

description:
This is a great spot for a business lunch! The menu is pretty simple but the quality is very good. Service is very friendly and efficient. They respect that you probably need to get back to the office, so they bring everything in a timely manner but don't leave you feeling rushed.

The decor is very cool!! There are quotes all over the walls that make for great conversation. I've noticed they have been setting up a few sidewalk tables on nice days which is always a plus!!

Since the place is pretty small, I would not recommend it for groups. A table of 6 feels cramped. 2 to 4 people is just right. 

Overall, my experiences have been very good. The prices are a little steep for the portion sizes. Expect to spend about $18-25/person for lunch.
author: Kandace K.

description:
We had reservations here at 12:30pm to take a friend out for her birthday and we weren't seated until past 1pm BUT they were well aware of us waiting and accomodated us very nicely.  After waiting for our table for about 15 minutes the host gave us the option of sitting in front of the cooks for our lunch or waiting there for the next available table.  Since we were there for a special occasion we decided to wait for a table.  As we waited on the stool seats we were given a complimentary glass of wine along with their bread and olives.  Majority of the tables are for 2 people so it was understandable that they needed a couple of tables together to fit our party.  While we were enjoying the wine and bread we were soon seated at our table.

We loved the food and the complimentary desserts as well but I really wanted to point out their exceptional customer service at Credo.  We had a lovely lunch, even after waiting, for our friends birthday and look forward to returning and trying other items on their menu.
author: Michelle D.

description: This used to be my go-to place for an easy dinner in the FiDi. There's a lot of great lunch spots and nice dinner spots in the area but I've always felt like Credo filled a much needed hole - someplace quick and easy that can always accommodate a walk-in. I went back to Credo for just this reason last week and was disappointed to see that they had completely changed the dinner menu - it is now full of heavy entrees...no more pizza!! Big bummer. Not sure I'll be going back since it's now at the same price point as many of the other Italian restos in the area.
author: Gina C.

description:
Love the fun Credo Quotes on the wall.... "I believe" this is a pretty unique modern restaurant to come to. great for a small party of friends, a date, or even for a bachelorette party (as the super loud table next to ours demonstrated for us. still fun none-the-less) 

We came because of the Dine about town deal... pre-fixed menu and you can try 3 dishes at a decent price? i'm in! 

Fresh baked bread, with olive taponade. yummy! huge pieces of olives. :) 

The caesar salad was yummy, with sardines as well, a bit too much dressing though. 

Hummus was good, not great, but the pita was amazing :) 

the Perch - apparently swam all the way from hawai'i to come to Cali to be eaten. tasty but spicy 

Credo pasta special. their signature dish. someone at the table MUST order this. it's presented beautifully! In a big bowl, covered with pie dough that's baked... they even show you how to crack that bad boy open! And when you open it, it's kinda like baked ziti inside with bigger noodles, and tons of meat (sausage and ground beef) ... mmm... :) enough to feed a girl twice! (Or feed her and her date if he's still hungry after eating his food. lol.) 

Apple tart was what i ordered for dessert... Yummy! just baked with ice cold vanilla bean ice cream... mm... 

we also had 2 bottles of prosecco... split amongst 6 people. too bad i don't recall the brand of prosecco it was... i'd love to have that at home!
author: Judy N.

description:
Loved Credo. The food might not be quite 5 star but it's close and the environment is incredible.  The wordplay on the walls is conversation stimulating and the brightness of the interior is mood stimulating.  Actually, the whole interior of the place just makes you feel good, upbeat and energetic.  I had a great time here. Check it out.  

BTW I love quotes and it took all of the restraint I could muster to not walk around the restaurant for an hour, weaving in between dinners and servers, reading the walls.  

"I think I've discovered the secret of life - you just hang around until you get used to it."  - Charles M. Schultz
author: Eamonn T.

description:
Saturday was date night, so I let the gf pick the spot and surprise me. Credo is tucked away in the financial district, but offers a very modern Italian meal with inspirational quotes painted on the walls ranging from Pete Rose to Mahatma Gandhi.

The gf and I had a very nice romantic dinner with wine, cocktails, carpaccio, seafood risotto, and steak. Our server was excellent. The gf did not know what type of wine she would like so he brought her a taste of two whites to choose from. He also made me a cocktail that will not be forgotten. He did not seem to disturbed by our clear lack of indecisiveness when it came to ordering. 

I was not in love with my meal, but the decor and service made up for it. They bring you fresh foccacia from the oven with a bowl of delicious garlicy olives on the side. Thankfully, the gf did not like olives or she would have had to fight me for them. However, she did love her risotto that was overflowing with clams, mussels, shrimp, and calamari. My steak was good...but a little to ordinary for the price.
author: Adam S.

description:
Our dining group recently held a dinner here.   Even though it was late after work on a Thursday night in FiDi, the restaurant was bustling with activity.  All tables were full, and the noise level was high.   Fortunately, we had the corner table in the back, where it was a bit quieter.

Yeah, the quotes on the wall, all starting with the words "I believe" are an interesting gimmick.  Some are entertaining, others controversial, and depending on where you are sitting, hard to read.  Bring your glasses. And yes, the tables are all handmade by a Dutch wood craftsman, "the product of hours of human labor and a keen devotion to sustainable design", so don't spill your wine.

The service was professional and attentive.  We had at least four different servers waiting on us.  They were helpful without being intrusive.   And very willing to accommodate special requests and substitutions, which I always appreciate.

I thought the menu offered a good amount of variety with some unique dishes I hadn't seen before mixed in with the usual Italian fare.   I started with the mixed green salad which was fresh and lightly dressed.  My main course was marinated grilled chicken paillard over grilled asparagus. I also ordered a side of penne pasta.   It turned out to be a lot of food, as the portions were larger than expected (the chicken dish included two breasts).   Overall, I'd say the food was good to very good, but fell short of exceptional.    The flour-less warm chocolate cake with ice cream which was dessert was deliciously decadent, but somewhat small and expensive at $10.   

Overall, a very satisfying if not exceptional dining experience.  I believe... I'll be back ...sometime.
author: Gene C.

description:
I visited Credo for the first time last weekend, not knowing what to expect. When you live so close to North Beach, its a bit of a gamble to go anywhere else for Italian food. However, I'm sure glad that I took that gamble. We started with hummus and calamari as appetizers, both of which were fantastic and in generous portions. Their wine list extensive, including a number of fantastic Italian wines. The pork milanesa I got as an entree was delicious and almost too much for me to eat in one sitting. The quality of the food and portions are over and above what they charge for them. Their tiramisu was outstanding, and authentic. After all that, I finished the meal with a nice glass of scotch. Overall, an outstanding dining experience. I wont mind straying a bit from North Beach to visit this place.

As a side note, I noticed some of the people who previously reviewed this complained about the decor. This place is called "Credo" and the decor fits this theme properly.
author: David H.

description:
Dine About Town (DAT) lunch, party of 8.  Some of us tried to order from the standard menu but so many things were out of stock that we were forced back to the DAT options.  The waitress blamed it on unexpectedly large DAT crowds wreaking havoc with their supplies on hand.  I believed her, but it's a sad story when DAT is supposed to lure people in and the positive experience is supposed to bring them back.  Gotta chalk that up to poor management.

Had the lasagna which I thought was very good but other party members thought was salty.  And it took freakin' 65 minutes to bring out the food -- which I understand you can't hope for a 60-minute lunch hour at these places, but a 90-minute lunch break was even out of the question given the slow service.

The ambience didn't feel like anything special.  The first few quotes on the walls were dumb so we didn't even waste much time trying to read them all.  Painfully mediocre restaurant despite their efforts to be something so much better.
author: Gary D.

description: I just ate here last weekend, although the food was good it was SO LOUD we couldn't enjoy our company.  It seems like there is nothing in there to absorb the sound, very distracting, even for our 21 and 27 year old children.
author: Dawn C.

description:
Oober new, and oober LOUD.  My friend and I went to check out Credo last week during the lunch hour rush, and there really was no point for conversation since we couldn't hear each other anyways.  The server was sweet, but I could only tell by reading her lips.  I didn't even understand what the specials were.

Otherwise, the decor was quite pleasant, and somewhat mimicked the volume of the restaurant.  All around the walls are quotes plastered in various typography and sizes all beginning with the phrase, "I believe..."  Which I came to later deduct was the meaning of "Credo".  So smart am I.  It was pretty interesting as they quoted every reputable celebrity, politician, athlete, comedian, model, etc.

Now the food.  The menu was definitely enticing.  We opted to share the PIADINA VEGETALI: Housemade Italian style flat bread folded and stuffed with char-grilled zucchini, yellow squash, eggplant, roasted peppers, and sundried tomato goat cheese, served with mixed greens.  They went a little nutso on the goat cheese, because that's primarily what it tasted like...goat cheese flatbread with goat cheese filling.  Coincidentally, I'm lactose-intolerant.

We also tried the FOCACCIA PROSCIUTTO E MOZZARELLA:
Warm housemade focaccia cut in the middle and stuffed
with imported prosciutto di Parma, mozzarella, and basil, served with parmesan fried potatoes.  Much better.

Completed it off with the PANNA COTTA CON AMARENE FABBRI 
Panna cotta in a sour cherry "Amarene" sauce.  Again with the cheesy overload and my already gaseous tummy, but it did me good...until afternoon time.

Be it may, "I BELIEVE CREDO is pretty decent.  Food is pretty good, the place has great decor, it's loud as hell, and it's not gentle on the lactose intolerant."
author: Ivy R.

description:
We went to Credo for Dine About Town and had a really great experience. The ambiance is welcoming, the wait staff was pleasant, the place was clean, not too noisy or uncomfortably quiet, and the food was wonderful! 

We picked from the Dine About menu but I'll definitely be going back to try some of their regular menu options.  We started out with the soup of the day - cream of Shitake mushroom soup... really good. Our main dishes were the Fettucine Bolognese, also very good and the Sedanini Alla Credo - at first glance, its extremely overwhelming, but after our server walked us through how to eat it, it wasn't so bad, not to mention how yummy it was. We finished it off with some Tiramasu and Panna Cotta... YUM!

This is a great little place to go for Italian food. I highly recommend it and I'll definitely be going back for more.
author: Ping N.

description:
This is a great new spot to come during your lunch break if you work in the Financial District of town. The food is a solid 4, but the decor and service I would say is a 5 by far. 

When you walk in you are overwhelmed by the words that are all over the walls surrounding you - it's very tastefully done and would be a great place to take client's or when celebrating something for sure. I would make reservations because when we walked in at 12:00pm it was packed. There is bar service so if you are a party of 1 or 2 you could shimmy up there and eat too, but I would call ahead otherwise you will be waiting a while to try their tasty food. 

Now the food. Very typical Italian menu and very much geared to the worker. I felt like we ordered and 10 minutes later we were eating which is great when you only have an hour to spare. 

I had the veggie lasagna which was really good - spinach noodles and light on the cheese which I appreciated. My coworkers each got a ciabatta chichen sammy which looked really tasty and they come with fries or a salad on the side. I also loved the foccacia bread and marinated olives - divine! 

Great spot that will become a staple lunch eatery in the financial district! Check this place out if you can!
author: Heidi S.

description:
...aaaaaaaand I'm updating again. Mike(our fabulous server) sent me a message to remind of the 2 wines we tried, loved, and subsequently forgot.

Said Mike, "The white was a Gavi from Michele Chiarlo and the sparkling is the Brut Rose from Fantinel."

Thanks Mike!
author: Amanda F.

description:
Great new addition to the Financial District.  We made reservations through our hotel concierge and when we arrived, we had a lovely table waiting.  I enjoyed the decor and the warmth of the place.  It's a soft and inviting way to come in out of the cold.  The theme includes famous quotes that are both thought provoking and sometimes controversial.  It gets the group chatting...hence to Latin term Credo...to Beleive in, have a feeling about or opinion about something. 

I appreciated the freshness of the food and the tasty combinations.  Our group was large so we tried most everything on the menu and we all loved our food.  

I like that they put their own twist on Calamari...I get so tired of the traditional deep fried, over crunchy not very exciting pile-o-fish.  Credo took a different spin and simmered them in a tomato base with cruncy toasted bread.  Yum!

I've read several reveiws and I think the nod to the negative service is not entirely unfounded.  The manager was terrific and greeted us warmly.  The servers were a bit uptight.  I felt like I was in L.A. all of the sudden...and for some, that may be a turn off.  Others might dig that.  

Bottom line: food is good, service is good enough and you should try this place.

P.S.  There's a terrific "New York loft type" private banquet room downstairs that seats 50.  Check it out!  It's very modern but could be a hidden gem for some!

Happy Eats!
author: Victoria B.

description:
This is what I love about San Francisco, that around every corner there's a good restaurant just waiting to be discovered. And one miserable Saturday evening, one where I spent all day working in my unglamorous office, I discovered Credo when I finally went out for some air and sustenance. The space itself is stunning, funky, and all around cool. It has an open, loft-like design, with walls entirely covered in witticisms and, well, credos. Note to the restaurant though, you might want to take out Tiger's credo, where he talks about believing in the values his parents taught him. I'm just sayin'! 

But more importantly, the food did not disappoint. The tuna carpaccio was nicely tart, but not overly so, the calamari was served in a very flavorful broth that was also delicious with some bread dipped in it, and the buffalo mozzarella was fresh and tasty served with bell peppers and tomato. Everyone in my group loved their entrees, but I was more interested in my own, which was the Grilled New York steak. It was the perfect portion, and it was cooked perfectly! I've been on a steak streak recently, and this definitely satisfied my carnivorous craving. Luckily for me, this place is only a couple of blocks from my work, so I will definitely be back and try them out for lunch one day. And if you're reading this review, please leave them alone so they don't get too popular. Thank you.
author: Meg P.

description:
I know they've only just opened, but they could definitely use some help.  I will start with the positive: appetizers and their wine list.  The quotes on the walls are also interesting.

After that, the whole experience went downhill pretty quickly--perhaps the chef and our server were having a really bad day?  All four of us were served entrees that were almost inedible (and they ranged from meat to pasta dishes).  We ordered creme brulee for dessert, but were served a cold creme caramel that hadn't been torched (we could see the sugar crystals on the mushy top).  The presentation of the dishes was also pretty gross.  My polenta was so watery I found it inedible.  Our server didn't even bother to ask what we thought of our meals (which I found staggering given the fact that all of our dishes still had a lot of food on them when they were cleared).

Also, they need a lot of help with their lighting.  It had the ambiance of a cafeteria. Some hanging light fixtures would probably help soften things up.

We loved the location though... And are hoping this place improves.  Quickly.
author: Naomi K.

description: We ran a conference dinner here. service was impeccable. Dinner was varied and tasty throughout. feedback from 95% of participants was excellent with negative comments being on food being not to their tastes which is fair enough as we would never have been able to fit everyone's preferences unfortunately.
author: Guy E.

description:
Went here for lunch with a buddy of mine today, thought it was pretty good.  I had the prosciutto mozzarella sandwich on focaccia bread with Parmesan french fries, which was good.  I wouldn't say it was great...I just was not disappointed. 

If anyone knows why they serve salt with their bread and olives pre-meal, let me know.  I wasn't sure if I was suppose to put it on the bread, the olives, or if we were suppose to be served olive oil to dip the bread in and garnish with salt.
author: Ken V.

description: I have been to Credo twice now and both times the food has been exceptional. The selection is incredibly unique and overall delicious. The Sedanini is a beautiful dish unlike anything I have ever seen and is quite delectable. The interiors, service and atmosphere are all pleasing and accompanies the wonderful food quite well.
author: Zach P.

description:
I am thrilled that authentic Italian eatery has opened one block from my office. After one lunch and two dinners, I know this restaurant has joined the financial district to stay. 

My favorites: 

Veal meat balls 
Hummus 
Fritto Misto 
Spicy pasta with sausage served under a pizza crust dome (yummy) 
Pounded Pork Chop 
Tiramisu 

Portions are large, so be ready to share. Wine list is unique and full of great choices. 

Setting is vibrant and service is very attentive. 

I am looking forward to trying more dishes.
author: Michael P.

description: I've been here twice in the last couple of weeks and the food is amazing.  I was able to get reservations for the day and time preferred and was seated promptly when we arrived.  I ordered the roasted chicken both times for the Brussels spouts.  It's delicious.  I also tried the ahi salad and pizzas from the people I was with.  I'd definitely come here again.
author: Maggie T.

description:
Went here after work for yelp drinks week. Stunning place with fantastic decor. Large open space with killer lighting, great acoustics, good general ambiance. The quotes on the wall are a good way to break the ice and are eclectic enough to stray from your average bumper sticker Gandhi "be the change"... 

Drinks were of primo importance, and have to say I was incredibly disappointed. We were seated near the bar and could see the bartenders. They seemed to be a little lost making these drinks. Even with minimal patrons, drinks took about 10 minutes to make it to our table. Don't get me wrong, a little TLC is necessary for a good cocktail, but the bartender TASTING a drink with a straw before sending it out is a bit much. Even after they passed the sippy test, the drinks were lackluster. We had the limoncello vodka drink, manhattans and gin and ginger drinks. Each drink didn't quite gel and felt like they were missing something, on top of being small. If they had been full price I would have been insulted! 

We also had some apps which were surprisingly great. The fried olives had a great texture and went well with the arribiatia and the flavors weren't in competition with one another. The pita was light and crispy and made me really wish we had ordered pizza, because if the crust is similar to the pita it would have been divine. The rosemary on the pita was a little overdone, but it balanced nicely with the lemon's acid in the hummus. 

Service wasn't great either. For being generally overstaffed, they seemed distracted and slow. I didn't have a napkin and although the staff were milling around, couldn't get anyone's attention and we weren't checked in with. 

In essence this is a 2 star review with a benefit of the doubt third star. 
Big pluses for having a unisex bathroom and breathtaking private room which I've already thought about for our next corporate event. 

But overall, nothing too spectacular and both the bar and serve staff seemed new and lost. I'd be willing to try again for dinner but will be skipping drinks altogether.
author: Ali R.

description:
My first attempt at lunch here failed ... they were completely booked, so without a reservation, I wasn't getting in.  If it's that popular, I consider it a good sign.

Reservation handy, I got in on the second attempt, and a few minutes after I arrived, the place was packed again.  And i can see why ... the food is quite good, with good service.

First, they started with some bread and delicious olives.  Plus they included a small bowl of salt.  I'm not sure why that was there ...does anyone really use THAT much salt?.  Besides, I'd prefer getting condiments and spices in a container where I'm confident prior patrons weren't sticking their fingers into things I'm going to put into my mouth, thank you very much!

Anyway, the food -- I had a chicken sandwich with basil pesto on a ciabatta bread ... quite tasty.  And my dining companion had a seafood stew that had me salivating in envy from across the table.  Both were excellent ... well worth the second attempt.

Now for the bad: it's just too bad I haven't mastered sign language.  Because the volume of noise in this place is so absurdly loud, that within minutes, everyone in the room is shouting, trying to be heard over everyone else.  I'd give Credo 4-stars based on the food ... plus the entertaining "belief" sayings on the wall art.  But the place is so horribly noisy, that one can't enjoy it.  Only once in my life have I experienced a louder dining spot (Aqua ... I'll never go back there again!)  Really: who in their right mind creates a restaurant with nothing but hard surfaces all around, turning the dining spot into an echo chamber?  Then, just when a few patrons left, and the place finally started to get to a tolerable noise level, they turned up some music.  Ugh!

I believe the food is quite good, and I believe this place has great potential.  But I also believe this place is entirely too loud to actually enjoy one's time there.  And until they do something to quiet down the noise, I believe I'll never go back, nor recommend it to anyone ... except the deaf.
author: Chris A.

description:
Accompanied a friend to the soft opening of this restaurant.  Definitely still working out a few kinks, but the food was solid and the decor was really thought-provoking.

Service seemed on top of their work, despite being brand new.  Pastas were simple but solid, especially the pappardelle and the lobster ravioli.  They still need to work out a few menu issues (it's massive, but informative and comprehensive).  Don't miss the breaded / stuffed olives on the anti-pasta menu.. highlight of the evening for sure.

Pricing is on the higher end, but well worth it.  Definitely worth checking out!
author: David O.

description:
Review for Happy Hour only!

I'm adding this to my list of to-go spots of HH.  I was a bit confused because the restaurant's website presents conflicting information regarding HH compared to Yelp.  It turns out that what's posted on Yelp was the updated one.

The huge downside of this place is the lack of seating.  Unless you get there really early, your chances of sitting down for HH are virtually zero.  But I liked the atmosphere and decor of this place... yes, it helped that we had seats.

The Margarita pizza for $5 (HH price) was great.  Add a bit of pepper, and you got yourself a treat.  Also had calamari... it was... meh.  I would rather get 2 additional pizzas for the same price.  For drinks, we only had wine, but I can't imagine the other drinks being poor.
author: Eric P.

description:
Met a friend here for dinner on Monday and we really enjoyed our meal.  I had the truffled salmon w/vegetables, she had the special (bass I think) and we shared the molten chocolate cake and panna cotta for dessert...Everything was yummy!  Even the complimentary spicy olives were great.  If I had to fault any of the food, I'd say the bread could have been better.  Something about the perfectly symmetrical slices made the texture a bit sponge like, but it did match the modern decor I guess.  I like the recycled materials used for the tables and water glasses.  

I don't think this place would drag me into the city, but it was just right for an upscale meal with casual ambiance on my way home.  The bar was not very crowded, but this may be different closer to the weekend.  Also, the staff seemed to really be making an effort to make sure we had a nice experience (perhaps trying to improve their rating here?).  I'm looking forward to trying lunch here, but it'll have to be a special occasion or working lunch.
author: Ariana L.

description:
Still only 3 stars.  Beware of busy times and an impatient hostess.

Why? The food here is pretty good, the service at the table was phenomenal, the hostess was not with the most-est.  

Granted, I came here on the night that the Groupon was going to expire, so everyone and their mom would be trying to use the Groupon that evening.  However, being rude to the customer and then ignoring the customer is not the way to go.  I left still somewhat annoyed, but enjoyed a good meal... at this point, not sure if I have a reason to come back. 

2 stars for service (only at the door), 3.5 stars for the food, 4 stars for the service at the table = average, 3 stars.
author: Lisa L.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to try a new place this past Friday and I chose Credo because it was 1,000 pts on OpenTable and the menu sounded tasty.

Service: 4.5, very attentive

Ambiance: 3, points loss for the fact that every time the door opened we were assaulted by a gust of cold air (we weren't even right by the door, I'm guessing at least half the restaurant could feel it)

Food: 3, like I said, menu sounded great, thoughtful combinations, but was just ok, nothing worth raving over

If I could give half stars, I'd give a 3.5, but overall, we were underwhelmed.  With so many options in the city, I doubt we'll be back.
author: Shelby S.

description:
It's a good spot for the financial district, less pretentious than the majority of places here. I liked the quotes on the wall, (good if your lunch partner is boring :), the food is reasonable but just OK, the hummus was terrible, my 4 cheeses pizza was way too salty, bread salad boring (2 toasts, tomatoes and cucumbers.), mozarella ruletta good. I felt like it's a hit and miss.
Service was good even if  a little slow at first. 
Will not be back.
author: Carpe D.

description:
New place and Boo that their "mixologist" is already gone!...and you are prohibited from ordering drinks off their mixed drink menu until they hire a replacement. Good news is you can custom order any drinks and their wine list is ample.

The ambiance is light and perfect for a business lunch/dinner or a group meeting.  Also, the quotes all over the walls are a great conversation piece.  

While the menu offers a variety of choices, the flavor needs some work.  Not that any of the dishes tasted bad...they were just bland.  With that said, the customer service is excellent. The group I went with stayed half an hour past closing yet we never felt pressured to leave sooner.

I'd go back here in a couple of months after they iron out all the kinks.
author: Shree R.

description:
I didn't eat here, but came for drinks. Great ambiance with the quotes on the wall. 

My friend ordered a glass of rose, and while the bartender got the order wrong twice, she made it right and the manager came over to apologize. 

The open kitchen looked very inviting and I'll definitely be back to partake in the deliciousness wafting from there.
author: Eva C.

description:
Went here for lunch today because they were offering to feed me for free, well at the price of comments.

I would go back , and definitly would pay for it. Service was great, decor was nice, food was good and reasonably priced. There were a couple things about the food that I would approve on, but hopefully after my comments all of you dining here will have no improvements to mention. I had beef carpacio and a pasta with pancetta cream sauce.
author: Steven C.

description:
I found Credo on Opentable when I needed to find a location for an important lunch meeting with my boss. It seemed like tun to try a new place and put us both on neutral ground.

Ambiance: LOVE the open bar, LOVE the amazing myriad of quotes that line the walls in various fonts, textures and colors. They are there to insight conversation and open thinking, which I think is a really cool approach to dining. Its not just about the food. The tables are made by a Dutch designer and are made of scrap wood and then lacquered within an inch of their life. They are so cool and add a really great touch to the feel of the restaurant. 

Service: Our waitress was really helpful and friendly, but she did stumble a bit over some questions we had. I chalk this up to the fact that they'd only been open for three days. They're still working out the kinks, but she was attentive and friendly so it made up for her confusion. 

Food: I started with the Soup of the Day which was Potato Leek Puree with crumbled pancetta on top. Oh My Hell. It was AMAZING. So deeelish! I could have eaten two more bowls. Not to say that the portion was not ample. It was actually a nice serving, I just wanted more because it was so freakin good. 

My boss started with the Ahi Tuna Carpaccio, While I did not have any, she enjoyed it and it looked beautiful and delish!

My entree was the Ahi Tuna sandwich with Parmesan fries. The sandwich was ok,,,nothing to write home about...but the fries were killer. Really yum.

My boss had the ceasar salad with grilled shrimp. This was a bummer. They grilled the lettuce, which is always a questionable choice as the leaves look dead and wilted. The shrimp were small and there were only about six of them. The portion of this was really disappointing, especially for the price. 

All in all, a great experience. LOVE the ambiance. A great choice for after work happy hours or downtown lunches.
author: Amber M.

description:
Credo has become my go-to place for lunch meetings and happy hour get together's when ever I am in SF. You can beat the service whether you're in jeans and a T or a three piece suit.

The pizza's are to die and don't get me started on the Sedannini  or the burger or the Veal Chop or the steak sandwich....  I think you get the point I am making. Delicious with a capital D on all fronts.

Be sure to save room for dessert, i hear they have a new pasty Chef that is out of this world!
author: B R.

description:
Summary: Ok food, but bland and nothing special. Overpriced.

Tried this place because my roommate gave me his expiring Groupon. Was somewhat excited since I generally like both Italian and home-style cooking, so I figured the combination would be a guaranteed W.

Business was swamped, as expected, given that I went on the day the Groupon expired. I had a reservation though, so was seated quickly. Service was a bit slow and brusque, but again, they were pretty busy so certainly understand.

Food however was just not great. My friend and I split the funghi pizza ($18), vegetarian sedanini alla credo ($24), and tiramisu ($8). The pizza was decent - a bit small and was coated in a layer of truffle oil, but not bad. Sedanini had a cool presentation but was lacking any real flavor and salt. Tiramisu was decent but bland.

All in all, I can't ever see myself going back. Food was mediocre and badly priced.
author: Gary Y.

description:
I came here with a group of friends. Very nice place in San Francisco Financial district. Good food and my friend brought a wine to go with it.
The only thing is pretty pricey for dinner which is expected in the Financial district.
author: Leon C.

description:
randomly popped in with a friend last week and while the place was empty the hostess asked us if we had reservations, when we said no, she and I'm guessing the manager on duty "discussed" for a bit before showing us to a table.

besides that the service was great. prompt but not rushed and the waiter checked in on us every now and then for refills, extras, desserts etc.

attention to details on the decor of this place is amazing down to the little things like utensils

the food wasn't amazing enough that I'd want to come back again and again 

but I don't regret eating here!
author: Whitne Y.

description: Over priced for the quality of the food. Twenty four dollars for chicken that had no interesting features. Not worthy.  Service just ok.
author: Patrick E.

description: Enjoyed a very good lunch with a friend at a bright, sunny table in the front of the restaurant -- main level has a lot of nicely-spaced tables before huge street-side windows, and has high airy ceilings to showcase the quotation "art".  Thought the various credos, etc. would dominate, but they really just form an interesting backdrop.  Service was fast and attentive, from my early arrival through the various stages of the meal.  We lingered an hour+ over a wonderful beet ravioli (amazingly good if you like that kind of thing) and a huge, tasty calzone plus bread/olives and a liter of Pellegrino.  Would have liked more pasta choices, but otherwise, definitely a good first visit.  (Had an opentable reservation.)
author: Carol H.

description:
I have been eyeing this place across from my equinox gym, which makes me think this may not have been an incidental placement for a restaurant. Falling for the trick, I have pored the menu standing outside a couple of times, but desisted from undoing positive karma from a good workout, deciding to return more dissociated from gym thoughts.

A friend suggested dinner at Credo and I jumped at the opportunity. The design seems functional at first, nothing too elaborate. The subtleties are a pleasant surprise. For example the tabletops seem a patchwork of laminated wooden tiles. The walls plaster a jungle of 'credos' of the famous and infamous as 'I believe' statements that contrast the dull conversations ;-) around, but some may actually aspire by ironically staring at the walls

We selected the scallops on saffron rice and the barramundi fish on a spinach bed for entrees. While the ingredients were not dramatically transformed by cooking genius, there was the intelligence of doing no damage to high quality ingredients, but even highlighting them with ribbons of garnish and subtle sauces. The opening act and finale stole the show,  
so perhaps these paled a little but only in comparison.

Earlier, biting into the appetizer of wild mushroom cheese medley, conversation stopped, jaws fell slowly, and gods smiled mischievously for flashing a glimpse so suddenly to confused mortals. That they repeated this at the end with the Panna Cotta dessert, made one feel suddenly, inexplicably, blessed. We were left deconstructing, bite after bite, what ingredients in what proportions caused this successful alchemy. Only conclusion.. We believe, in credo
author: anurag p.

description: I went to Credo yesterday to support one of my favorite non-profits, OneJustice, and had a delightful lunch with my girlfriends.  First, it is important to check in to show your support for OneJustice, as they get bonused from Credo.  Even better is to start your meal with the delicious Justice cocktail, a cucumber gimlet.  I had mine with vodka as I don't love gin, and it was wonderful. We shared the beautiful burrata salad and some truffle fries. And the I enjoyed the cubano sandwich. It was so tasty, and the house made pickles were perfect.  Looking forward to my lunch there next week, and my next date night with my husband.  Great place.  Additionally, there is never a shortage of things to discuss based upon all the amazing quotes on the walls.
author: Sallye M.

description: Good food. The chorizo sausage and potato salad was delicious. Great that they were able to seat 20 of us at short notice.
author: Chris R.

description:
I really hate walking into a completely empty restaurant and being told there's no room...

I tried eating here on 2 other occasions and was turned down because they were "full".  And by full, they meant full of you know what, because the place was literally EMPTY. 

Anyhow, I'm no rookie, I know how these things work (should've made a reso after the first swing and miss), but jeez, pre-lunch rush on a Monday, not a soul in the restaurant yet, and still nothing?  

Anyhow, I digress.  

Finally got the opportunity to have lunch here recently (outside, of course, but luckily it actually felt like a Summer day in SF).  Had the soup of the day (great bean and noodle something-or-other) and the salmon salad.  The salmon was a bit fishy for my taste and I bit straight into a shell while eating the hard-boiled egg, but it was fine.  Vegetables were fresh and green and the bread plate with olives satisfied me where my salad fell short.

Service was excellent.  It did end up being jammed packed inside around 12:30pm and yet our guy still managed to come around just enough.  

I ventured down to the lower level to use the restroom and I must say I'm glad we didn't choose to dine down there when offered.  There's no natural light and it's just an awkward, sterile space (at least from what I saw).  No amount of good interior design could've saved that in my opinion.

Overall, lunch was good (mostly thanks to the sun), though not worth having been turned down twice before.
author: Marie A.

description: If you need a quiet, elegant and easy going atmosphere then you have found the place. If you are searching for a quick after work drink at reasonable prices, then you have found the place. I love the spicy jicama and seriously only want to go when my bartender Greg is there. I really only have ever had a glass and a bit of a bite, the full menu looks pricey, yet if you check in you get a free glass. Enjoy its a good place to unwind.
author: Natasha M.

description:
Went there after getting 50% off Groupon.  High expectation due to Yelp review.  Nice location, can easily get there via BART/MUNI (3 blks fr station).  Made reservation beforehand over phone, easy.  Arrived and greeted mildly by matradee who seems too distracted/unimpressed with his new trainee.  Our server was very hospitable tho, good save.  Ordered Caprese for appetizer.  Not impressed b/c for $15 we got 4 slices of tomatoes and mozzerella, ea. topped with a tiny piece of basil!  Main course we had the lobster ravioli and porcini pasta at $18 ea.  I liked my pasta, which is drowned w truffle oil (yum!)/  My partner's lobster ravioli has great sauce on, but there's so little sign of any lobster in it.  It's so well blended that he thinks it's all cheese and potatoes, no lobster flavor whatsoever.  He had a Manhattan Martini, which he said was very good.  No dessert.

The place is bathed with natural light from large glass storefront.  The back, above kitchen has this large clear glass looking into an uninspiring light well btwn office buildings.  Interior decor is basic, with LOTS of more uninspiring and unnecessary quotes as "artwork".  The tables are cool.  Bathroom clean but nothing a designer would scream about.

In all, thank you Groupon for a chance to check out new/different places, but will not return and pay in full.
author: D M.

description: Awesome service. Farmers market menu quite yummy. Everyone helpful and friendly. Thank you for the exceptional service and great food.
author: Johnson H.

description: I dined here for colleagues for lunch back in November 2012, and we all enjoyed our pizzas and pastas. Nothing spectacular, but decent pizza and ravioli. We decided to go back for dinner with a big group of international colleagues in February 2013, only to find a completely different menu with no pizza and only very obscure pasta dishes. That's fine, we're adventurous, but the problem is it was all designed to look fancy, but didn't actually taste good. The biggest disappointment was the fish dish that several of us ordered. The dishes came out and the pungent smell of fish overwhelmed our table - it was clearly not fresh. I couldn't eat it. No one was thrilled with their meals. The bill was outrageous for such mediocre food. It looks like pizza is back on the dinner menu - maybe the chef has changed again? Not sure, but I wouldn't risk it.
author: Anna Y.

description:
I needed a lunch reservation in the Financial District... on a Friday... during the holidays... for 6 people... with less than 24 hours notice. Insane, right?? Facing the impossible, I bravely dialed number after number fending off many "I'm sorry, we're booked" responses until I stumbled upon Credo.

My weary call was answered by Michael (who has a very charming and cordial phone voice, btw) and instead of shunning me like the rest of the hosts I'd spoken with he worked very hard to accommodate my request and managed to secure us the largest table they had to offer. 5-star service right there.

Unfortunately, that's where the good impression ended. My party arrived at Credo, slightly early, and we were not greeted by a single employee for 10 minutes. People saw us standing there, but nobody attempted to make eye contact with me or offer a, "I'll be with you in a second," smile at all. I do admit they were very busy, but employees did see us standing there and nobody made the effort to make us feel welcomed.

Finally the hostess ran over up (I don't remember her name), and I had to stop and inform her that we had arrived. Another 10-ish minutes of waiting ensued. However, the nifty selection of quotes on the wall kept us occupied...

I was very pleased with our seating arrangements, as we were given a very large & comfortable square table that was nestled in a little side area of the restaurant. It was near the open kitchen, but it still felt private none the less. We also didn't have to shout at each other over the noise of the restaurant. Points for that.

Complimentary olives & bread were yummy... the olives were pitted (YAY!) and had a nice spicy kick to them. I wasn't a fan of the gnocchi I ordered. The portion seemed awfully small compared to what everyone else received and it was very very bland and very very oily. Maybe that's what I get for ordering gnocchi tho?

The rest of my table ordered lamb paninis (which are actually more like lamburgers...haha), chicken paninis, and a salmon salad. Nobody complained about their food at all, and everyone else seemed to have a reasonable portion. It was just me that got the short end of the stick! 

Also, our table was tended to by two very attentive waiters. I don't remember their names either, but they did a great job as my water glass was never empty.

Soooo 3 stars? 4 stars? I'd say they're right in between.
author: Caty K.

description: The bread and olive oil was fantastic! It was a friend's birthday and so we brought a cake, which the waiters gracefully put in the fridge for us. When they brought it out they had it placed on individual plates (the cake as already cut) which I thought was great! Great staff.
author: Eric I.

description:
Went to Credo recently with my Groupon, probably just like everybody else. Maybe it was because they were overwhelmed with grouponers, but i was not that impressed. 

Decor: pretty cool. I like the writing all over the walls, and the space was nice and seemed cozy. 

Service: good. Attentive waitress, super nice host, and overall they made me and my GF feel at home. 

Food: we got 2 appetizers; the fried olives which were pretty tasty (sauce was bomb), and the squid, which was also well prepared and really good. 

The reason for 2 stars here and the "meh, i've experienced better" attitude is because of my main course. I got the seared rare ahi. Now granted I know this is not a spectacular cut of fish in general, and seared ahi has recently soared as a pretentious, over-priced dish for people who don't like the taste of real fish, but by those guidelines good restaurants should not mess it up because it's easy to prepare. 3 mins on either side of a high temp grill with some sauce and voila, you're done. This piece of fish I got was bland, dry, and overall just tasteless. I paid $27 for a piece of fish, and they totally ruined it. Ahi retains juices well, especially when prepared almost rare, and this had none. It was like the chef wrung out the piece of fish like a wet towel before he put it on the grill. I don't know many places that mess up seared rare ahi but these guys pulled it off. 

So anyway, i might go back here, i might not, but i say 2/5 Credo. Apps were good, drinks were good, service was good, but people sit to dine for entrees, not fufu crap. So get that right then we'll talk.
author: kareem d.

description: Very tasty...had a great spinach and caramelized onion pizza paired with a nice endive salad with picked radishes.  Yum!
author: Ginny F.

description:
I've been to Credo for lunch twice in the last few weeks.  The first time the soup of the day (beet) was actually very flavorful once you got over the lumpy texture, but they were out of the only thing I wanted on the menu - the lamb burger. I settled for the penne with roasted chicken, which was good but spicier than I had expected.  The grilled lamb I had on the second trip was solid, and the accompanying parmesan polenta was delicious.  

I haven't tried Credo for dinner, but the menu looks worth a shot.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Their fried calamari with prawns are definitely a good starter. We went here for a birthday lunch at 11:30am and that seems to be an ideal time for most FiDi restaurants.

I ordered the seafood soup. A bit on the pricey side, but could have been better if my colleague didn't find hair in her vegetarian dish. Not cool.
author: Miles G.

description:
Once you get to know the staff there, the place feels like a nicer, hipper version of home. The vibe is a little like L.A- exciting, fresh, open, simple- and the energy stirs up a feeling excitement and potential. I love how the venue is verstile. There are private dining rooms downstairs and a more open casual main floor. If you sit at the bar at happy hour, you will almost always meet new friends over some of their amazing cocktails and pizzas. 
Great place for a hearty meal with friends!
author: Shirley-May S.

description:
Alright, I'm officially ignoring Yelp's pithy assessments of their star ratings, because while this place is not, in my book, "A-OK," and in fact my overall reaction upon leaving was very much akin to "Meh," I'm going to go ahead and give it three stars because in the San Francisco dining landscape, that's how I see it. 

It should be noted off the bat that this is despite their very good intentions--they give x% of each check to various entities like the Food Bank--and, it must be admitted, the general elan with which they present themselves. On the whole, though, it was just too much money--omgod, and now I'm remembering that it was this much money despite not getting any wine!--for food that too rarely impressed. Even more damning, a great crime was committed. 

Great crime: Serving gnocchi that looked, and felt like (i.e., texture-wise) like it came from an extrusion machine. Thick, gummy, tubey little bullets of gnocchi. Ixnay on the nocchigay! (Oh how it makes me yearn for Blue Plate's gnocchi, melty and delicate and languorously stretching, if memory serves, its sage flavor all across my tongue.) 

Other than that, the only thing I can recall from the meal was a wild boar ragout that was pretty good, but not good enough to plea bargain itself out of the Great Crime mentioned above, which Great Crime was, of course, exacerbated by the significant bill for a wineless dinner.
author: T U.

description:
The best thing about the place are the cocktails. Best Manhattan ever. We had a pretty crappy table right by the exit to the bathrooms. The food - I had been looking forward to the scallops (from reading the online menu.) They had that carbolic taste that tells me they are less than fresh and when I told the Matre'd he said he would take care of it then walked away - Like he was too good to pick up my plate and bring it back to the kitchen. I guess his job is to look pretty! Our waiter did take care of it and without question! Tracy did a good job. 

Good Manhattan or not - I doubt I will ever go back.
author: Marty R.

description:
I went here because of Michael Bauer.  I don't generally listen to critics, but when he mentioned a dish called Sedanini, I knew I had to try it.  Well, I had to get my boyfriend to try it.  The dish is basically a bowl of pasta with pizza dough draped over it, and then baked in the oven to cook the dough. It only *looks* overwhelming, trust me.  Pasta and pizza are my bf's two vices, so naturally we have to give it a go.

The Sedanini itself was pretty good.  The sauce tasted fresh, and the sausage in the pasta was nice and pepper-y.  Pasta was al dente, pizza dough was thin and crusty.  The other dishes we had was pretty good too: lobster/shrimp ravioli (each bite makes you think of the ocean), fritto misto (the vegetable peels were nice and crunchy), and olive all'ascolana (wish there were more fillings, or bigger olives). We finished our dinner with the panna cotta, which was dense and creamy.

Looking back, I can't help feeling that something was... missing.  I can't put a finger on it, though.  It might be just that everything we had was on the heavy side.  It was kind of a palate overload.  Mental note for next time: do not do three courses.  Two is more than plenty.
author: Yohanna B.

description: Chef Gustavo emailed me shortly after I wrote this review appologizing for the dirty plate and said it would be addressed at their next staff meeting.  I very much appreciate that he takes the time to read and respond to his Yelp reviews and addresses complaints.  His response reassured me that our experience was most likely a little blip in an otherwise efficient and professional Credo experience.  I will be sure to go back and give it another shot in the future.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Michael, the Manager, is wonderful...he got us in after he already had 3 large parties that night...wonderful job.  He even stopped by our table to chat for a few minutes...what great guy.

Our table was fantastic, lots of room for 12 people and it was ready for us when we arrived.  The server was awesome and very attentive...it really seemed like they always had someone right by us doing something for the table.  I couldn't have asked for more.  

We tried the white bean hummus, excellent, the mushroom fondue (to die for) and the tuna...all great and all disappeared really quickly (by the way the house marinated olives are great along with the warm bread).  We tasted the smoked chicken pizza and found the crust to be thin and very well made.  The two different raviolis on the menu are great...but go with the butternut squash one, it really is fantastic.  We also had the pork loin with a yummy polenta and the lobster with risotto.  

Everything was wonderful.  I couldn't have asked for a better dinner for all of my students from Southern Oregon University.
author: Lisa S.

description: A great place; Both the food and the atmosphere were distinct, interesting and generally very good. The staff was friendly and the whole experience fun. Nice appetizers, pizzas were great and the risotto exceptional.
author: Bill R.

description: Unbelievably great! We planned a Sunday wedding here in only 3 weeks and it was an OUTSTANDING event! Days later I'm still getting raves from our guests about how interesting and fresh the place feels, the delicious organic food and the wholehearted way the event manager Mark Lehman cared for us. This is a place for thinking people: the walls are covered with thought-provoking and witty quotes--even the bathrooms have intriguing audio snippets piped in. If you want to host a party for lively progressive people this is the best place in San Francisco to hold it!
author: Melody H.

description: Pretty good. I got the Sedanini (sp?) and it was something new to try. Very filling and large, but tasty as well. The service was pretty good, considering we were a party of 20. They also gave bread with olives, also very good. Overall, a pretty nice experience (very good for business meetings).
author: Nikita K.

description: Oh yes.  Very acceptable:)  Had appys and drinks here the other night.  The burrata was INCREDIBLE!! I have never had better burrata in my life, I almost passed out.  it was like butta!!!  Lovely ambiance, just gorge, modern and minimal.  I didn't even get past appys, so I can't speak to the rest of the menu, yet everything looked amazing!  Only draw back is that it is exceptionally loud.  They have poured concrete floors which I love, yet it echo's all the noise.  So, if you're looking for a quiet night out, go later in the evening when the crowd dies down as it is not so loud!
author: Nicole F.

description: I could sit here and read the walls all night long. Food is amazing and the service is excellent.
author: Paula M.

description: I hosted an engagement party at Credo a few weeks back and had an absolutely wonderful experience. I worked with Mark on coordinating my event and he was incredibly helpful and quick to respond to all of my questions. The space downstairs was the perfect size for our 40 + guest list. I didn't personally enjoy any of the food because I am pretty much allergic to everything but my guests raved about everything they were served. The wine, beer, and champagne was poured generously and overall the event went flawlessly. I was hesitant about being downstairs without windows, but the acoustics were fine and the set up worked well for our group. Thank you Credo for a wonderful night... I will most certainly be in touch for any future events!!
author: Bailey M.

description: I LOVE credo!  I have been to this restaurant a couple of times and have yet to be disappointed! The food is amazing and so is the staff.  Gustavo's food is inspiring and creative.  It's always a treat for me to come to credo!
author: Jessica H.

description: Had lunch with a girlfriend at Credo yesterday. Loved the food...loved the vibe (including the awesome tables)...attentive, friendly service. Can't wait to go back!
author: Linda L.

description: I went to this restaurant for a group dinner and had a pleasant experience eating the fondu and cheese platter for appetizer followed by the osso buco (braised pork shank) and a glass of wine. Service was friendly and efficient. All the food I had was great; others in my group ordered Sedanini alla Credo which I think I may try next time.
author: Kent W.

description: What a restaurant!! First off, the ambiance is amazing! I absolutely love the quotes all over the wall!! Second, the service is spectacular! My waitress was very attentive along with the rest of the staff! Third and most important, the food was SOOO savory! I went with a girlfriend and we decided to order a bunch of items off the menu and share! WOW, we were amazed at how gourmet the food was, how tasty everything tasted and the selection on the menu! We couldn't order everything but we're definitely coming back for me! Besides the main dining hall, we went downstairs to find the restroom and were happily surprised to find an amazing banquet room. I took the event planner's card because i'm definitely coming back and bringing both personal and work parties here!! You all would be fools not to come and see just how amazing Credo really is!
author: Sabrina G.

description:
nice to have another fidi lunchtime option during the workweek, especially one so close to the office! (+1 star)

i've been there twice now and have had the spinach salad both times, despite being intrigued by the other menu items.  i'm trying to have lighter fare during the day and get closer to hitting the rda of fruit/veggie servings, and this salad is so good it i almost forget i'm being healthy!  (+1 star) just simply dressed in a balsamic vinaigrette, sprinkled with pine nuts, goat cheese and cranberries...oh and crispy pancetta. (so much for being healthy!) but fried pork makes everything better =) i'm sure i could easily replicate this at home but the pancetta elevates it to another level.

my lunchmates have also enjoyed their entrees - the penne pasta, mushroom pizza and vegetarian panini.  the pizzas are big enough to share (or save half for later if you're not inclined to share!).  the sandwich isn't really a panini but comes with an interesting mix of healthy veggies.  plus i LOVE the olives and bread they serve after you order. (+1 star)

the compact lunch menu is very reasonably priced if you stick to pizzas, pastas, salads and panini ($12-17); the heavier entrees are pricier (up to $24) but who really orders lamb for lunch?  they also have a 2 course lunch menu for $24. (+1 star)

the restaurant itself has a nice atmosphere - sleek & modern but still warm.  there's a small bar with counter seating and plenty of tables.  it can get a bit noisy with all the hard surfaces and concrete floor but you can still have a conversation w/o shouting.  the quotes all over the wall add to the busy bustling feeling; they're interesting but occasionally distracting (at least you have something to keep you busy if the conversation is less than interesting!) (+1 star)

the only misstep is in the service.  the first time i came, we dropped in w/o a reservation and the hostess made a huge deal of how lucky we were there was a cancellation - to the point of being obnoxious.  um, okay, i get that your restaurant is very popular but it's not the french friggin laundry!  

the waitstaff are a little cold and robotic, like they're going through the motions; not as warm & inviting as the restaurant itself.  on both visits, they checked in on us often enough but with the impression that it was a bother to serve us.  on the second visit, the waiter spilled water on the table while pouring and was hardly apologetic; rather, he seemed annoyed that he had to clean up!  (-1 star) if only the whole waitstaff would be as gracious as the manager, who also graciously stopped by our table on both occasions (and subsequently followed up w/ me after i posted this review).

so 4 stars overall...
author: Jen P.

description:
Ate there last night ( Saturday August 14th for my 27th anniversary ) and it was just so-so.

Got there at 6 p.m. and the place was deader than Mel Gibson's career. 

Were met by host, given a nice table by the window. Parked right out front. 

Service was good, but they did not bring bread out until after we ordered which was about 15 minutes. May I suggest they bring out bread virtually the minute you sit down?

Bread was good, not great. I had them bring over oil and vinegar and garlic, which was freshly chopped and super. 

I had the soup of the night which was very good, but my wife thought it was too salty. Her salad was o.k., but a small salad and she was annoyed that it had zucchini in it. 

Our son ordered a pizza with Speck and he was not impressed. Granted he is 7...but he does know what sort of pizza he likes.

My chicken dinner was o.k., my wife had the quail which was also o.k.

On the whole the meal was just o.k. / I hate to keep using that term but I got nothing else. I had nothing memorable. Nothing stands out food-wise that can allow me to rave about this place.

I do however have a rant. 

On the back of the menu was a screed about rich people and capitalism and trickle down economics being a failure.

They even had a quote from Rush Limbaugh to prove their point that trickle down economics is evil and that it was a good time to be rich because the poor and middle class are flat lined on economic growth while the rich are really sticking it to the rest of us. 

Ummmm....I came for dinner not a lesson in Marxism.

It seems silly to poke fun at the very people you so badly need to fill your empty restaurant. May I boldly suggest to the owners to hire a more imaginative chef and to lay off sharing with your clients your philosophy on economic policy?

If you genuinely are so offended by the " rich " then why do you charge $36 for lamb chops?

I doubt seriously the poor you seem to concern yourself with can afford your lamb chops.

Based on how dead your restaurant was I'm going to guess neither the poor nor the rich are lining up to line your pockets with sweaty cash.
author: bill r.

description: Four of us came for dinner on Wednesday night. The food was good and the service excellent. It was quite noisy though,and one of our party was hard of hearing, so that was a problem. The quotes on the walls, of which there are hundreds, bothered me. I counted three quotes by women (there may have been more that I missed) in the main dining room. What is this, 1950? Women were WAY underrepresented. Here is a partial list of intelligent women they could have quoted: Helen Keller, Maya Angelou, Eleanor Roosevelt, Malala Yousazai, Aung San Suu Kyi, Hilary Clinton, Jane Austin, Marie Curie, Simone de Beauvoir, Rosa Parks, hildegard of Bingen, Yoko Ono, Dian Fossey, Jane Goodall, mother Teresa, Oprah Winfrey, Harriet Beecher Stowe, Virginia Wolf, ...just to name a few. The list goes on and on. The balance needs to be restored in this world. Showing so few quotes by women sends a message, and it is an insulting one.
author: Susan A.

description:
Credo catered an event for us, so I can't speak to the service in the restaurant itself.

For me, the experience was perfect from start to finish- Mark was very helpful before the event, and took a lot of stress off of my plate!  On the night, he and his staff set up with minimal direction- basically, just got on with it making me look good!  And the food was fantastic, everyone was raving about it.  Particular highlights were the mole chicken taquitos and the ceviche, although the mini-desserts were great, too!  I can't wait to go and try the restaurant sometime soon.
author: Julie B.

description: We had our rehearsal dinner here on a Saturday night and it was a great experience. We were able to use the downstairs space which was more private, served food family style (to save $) and after the dinner had friends meet us upstairs at the bar. Everyone there was very friendly and accommodating.
author: Melissa N.

description:
I've never felt inspired to write a review until after I had been to Credo.  I've now been there for lunch and dinner (a party of 12) and couldn't have come away with a better impression.  
-The atmosphere and openness (high ceilings!) of the restaurant strike you right as you enter and really put you at ease.  The hostess and staff were extremely attentive and accommodating both times.  I was particularly impressed with how well the Credo staff handled our dinner party of 12.
-Lunch: I ordered the Pizza Rustica and was very happy with the pizza that came out.  The crust was a good thinness and the sauteed onions and red peppers were a delicious touch!  Great place for a business lunch.
-Dinner: Our party of 12 mostly ordered family style and came away with only positive reviews.  I really enjoyed the Semplice salad (the Chianti vinaigrette has a great flavor) and definitely had a few more slices of the Rustica!  Great for a party or a date-a reservation is a good idea as it was crowded.
*All in all, highly recommended.
author: Daniel C.

description: I went here for lunch because I had a gift certificate. I actually never considered going here before even though I work a stone's throw away. Overall, the food is good, not great. We ordered the white bean hummus, burrata salad, soup of the day, garlic frites, and carbonara pasta. The hummus dip was really garlicky which I was a big fan of. The burrata salad is just a huge hunk of burrata on top of shaved asparagus. The burrata was excellent but I was expecting more of a salad to accompany it. The other items were good but again, not great. The menu was a little on the pricey side for the quality of food you get. I don't think I would come back again.
author: Amy N.

description: Not too shabby! Would I go here again.... Maybe. Why would I come back? The Brussels sprouts (side dish) is the best one I've EVER had. And I love Brussels sprouts, so I order it everywhere I go.  Other reasons, the friendly staff, who hooked it up with complimentary sparkling wine for 6 of us, and kept refilling! (because our table wasn't ready), and complimentary tiramisu for the birthday girl. my main course was small, and lacking. I had the seared scallops with squids ink risotto.... The risotto was good, but something about the scallops was unpleasant... so, with that said, the Brussels Sprouts will bring me back to this joint, and hopefully a different dish will also keep me coming.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Credo is an excellent restaurant, but quite noisy.  I go there at least twice a month for lunch and always have great food.

One suggestion:  I wish they would keep certain signature dishes on the menu at all times like the quatro formaggi pizza and the pasta with butter & sage.  Sometimes I get there and find that both of those items are missing from the menu and I get disappointed.
author: Karen B.

description: Amazing food the customer services is amazing. Great place to go with a group or a dinner date. I would go again.
author: Johnny R.

description: A nice neighborhood restaurant.  Credo - I believe.   We liked reading the quotes on the wall.  Our meals were enjoyable.  I had the Arugula salad and linguini.  My honey had the Coriander crusted ahi salad with Kale and Filet Mignon.  They make good mochas too.  We would probably eat here again.  The restaurant is clean.  The tables are not crammed together.
author: Simone H.

description: The service at Credo was top-notch, but the food was just mediocre.  Started with the meatballs which was on the salty side. Even the butter for the bread was overly salted...odd.  We shared a few entrees.  The linguine with mussels and clams was good, but also on the salty side.  Next we had the filet mignon, and my goodness that was incredibly salty. The meat was cooked well and was very tender.  The last dish was the scallops with black risotto.  Scallops were cooked perfectly, but the texture of the risotto was a bit hard.  Overall a decent but pricey meal.  Not likely a place I would visit again.
author: Tony W.

description: I felt like I was eating a meal in Northern Italy.  Wonderful flavors, the best pasta I've had in a long time and overall just a really great experience.  A great location too!  Keep up the great work!  I will definitely return!
author: Hillary B.

description: Pretty cool place...good food and great space....love reading all the famous sayings.
author: Peter S.

description: When this place first opened it was great. Now they charge for the olives and two of us went for lunch and they brought us three small slices of bread, were we supposed to share one slice? The wait person had the personality of a door knob and the food was not as good as it used to be. I will not go back, to many other choices in this part of town to pay for marginal food with bad service.  One more thing, the gal at the front a desk is a turn off.
author: Precilla C.

description: Went for as business lunch and had a below average experience.   The waiter was pleasant but challenged.  It took 15 minutes to get drinks and another 15 minutes to get our salads.  It then took 40 minutes to get our entrees.  During this whole time we rarely saw our waiter.  Had a good view of  the dysfunctional kitchen and listening to their arguments.
