Food was ok and nothing special.   They did comp our entrees but I only think they did since we told them they were going to have to box them up since we were late for our next meeting.  Go somewhere else.
author: Jenny N.

description:
i am THEEEEEE queen of writing down random quotes. the walls of this minimalist, industrial feel restaurant has got me giddy with joy. there are a slew of quotes with no room to spare up as far as thee i can see. service was not slow, and it sure beat sitting bored. there is something about super tall ceilings that just appeal to me and i feel like i'm in a special little nook away from the confines of my cubicle. 

i ordered the calamari to start. let me just state; calamari should ALWAYS have tentacles in it. that was a pleasant surprise. i usually find the tamed version of just the meaty part. i am super sad panda when that happens.

my entre was the seafood soup. delish. and immaculately served in a steaming oversized bowl. i guess i should say a huge salad bowl for 6. at least. 

i will be back.
author: kim p.

description: Went to this restaurant on a Saturday night. Had a reservation and got seated right away. The menu was somewhat uninspiring but they executed on it pretty well. Everything tasted good and the service was pretty good for the most part. The problem I had with the restaurant came at the end of the meal. My party racked up a pretty big bill and paid and remained at the table chatting. About 10 minutes after paying we were told we had to move so they could seat another party. I've worked in restaurants for years and would never ask that of a guest. They were trying to sit a larger party and certainly had enough open tables to do it without making us move but it was most convenient for them if we did. It just made me feel like they got our money and were done with us.
author: Justin K.

description: Credo consistently has amazing food - incredible pasta dishes with the requisite minimalist but huge flavor sauces - the way it's done in Italy.  Highly recommend.
author: Jayne H.

description: Really good hummus appetizer made with canellini beans, and good fritto misto, good size and variety. Pizzas are thin crust and very good. The pastas are cooked very well, with unique flavors.
author: Eddy N.

description: I come here for business lunches since the vibe is very lively, the food is decent, and it's easy to get a reservation on open table and get 100 dining points.
author: Kerry L.

description: What I really want is to rate it 3 1/2.  It has a great decor and atmosphere.  The 12 dollar hummus is to die for.  Make sure u get four people to share so u don't get full up on just hummus.  The lamb ragu is great.  Do not order the Caesar salad.  The dressing is so bland.   It's worth the 1000 PT opentable pts.
author: Ingrid Y.

description: Location is still good. Food is really meh. They have been open a while so now it's just what they're going to be, I guess.
author: Gina C.

description: Food was too salty and I wasn't sold by the decor. Good service and good wine but not worth the money. Winners were the apps: try the burrata and the buttermilk fried asparagus.
author: MorePeas S.

description: This place wasn't bad. Super nice atmosphere.  Just not memorable.  I actually was annoyed about the fact that I ordered an $11 drink, and I weigh 110 pounds  (and empty stomach) and I really had the feeling there was not much alcohol on the drink.  I'm not a alcohohic -- LOL -- but seriously it bugs me if the drink seems watered down and overpriced.  The place was lovely, but empty.  The food was fine.  Nothing to remember.  I ordered pork meatballs and brussel sprouts but I've had better at other places.  Service was really nice actually, but it didn't make up for the overpriced drink and ok food.  The food was not that over priced, but not amazing either.
author: Maria D.

description:
I've been here three times.  Each time was a disappointment.

I went when they first opened.  Service was atrocious.  We walked in early one evening and 2/3 of the tables were empty.  Nonetheless the hostess asked us to wait at the bar until a table could be prepared.  "What about one of those tables - the ones with the place settings?" I said gesturing to over a dozen empty tables.  "Oh, those are reserved and we don't have a walk in table available."  So we walked 10 feet away and stood near the bar and pointedly declined to order a drink.  Then about 5 minutes later the hostess discovered that there was a table available and we were seated.  Frankly, I don't remember anything about the food.  

Next time was for an office function where I didn't have a choice but to attend.  We were seated promptly.  We were a party of 10 and were seated in the main room, which is so loud that it is difficult at times to talk to the person next to you.  Forget about talking to the person across the table and one seat diagonally away - not going to happen.  So I got stuck talking to ______________ from purchasing.  No, not the restaurant's fault.  I had the gnocchi.  I know that a restaurant isn't going to make gnocchi as good as my Nanna - I accept that.  But these were like little potato shot puts - very dense and firm adrift in a sea of indifferent sauce.  Also, we were a large party, but the wait-staff was clearly overmatched.   The waiters themselves were fine, but I think there was only one or maybe two people assigned to do all of the secondary tasks (refill water, bring more bread, clear plates) in the whole restaurant.  All I remember is this poor guy, sweating heavily, practically running from table to table trying to keep up.  So, strike two.

Okay, I went back a third time.  It was a Friday and I couldn't get last minute reservations anywhere downtown so we took a chance and just walked in.  I mean, the first time didn't count since they had just opened and the second time was an unweildy party, so how bad could it be, right?  Okay, the fact that we got a table on a Friday night should have been a clue I guess.  This time, service was fine all around.  Nice hostess, attentive non-harried waiter.  Good, looks like the front of the house is getting itself in order.  (There was some gaunt over-caffeinated guy (at least I hope it was just caffeine) scurring between hostess stand and back so I think he must be the (new?) manager.)

But, the food.  My god, the food.  Started with the Caesar.  The "dressing" was a pasty sauce overpowered by salt.  I don't really know why salt would be added at all when dish has anchovies.  Companion's mixed green salad was okay - but how hard is that to screw up?

We split pizza and halibut.  Pizza toppings were good and cheese was bubbly and perfect.  But two slices had burnt on outside and bottom.  No over-browned - burnt almost black.  The halibut was supposed to be seared - but it was prepared more like a blackened catfish or something.  Halibut is such a wonderful light, flaky fish.  My favorite fish in the world.  The piece was a bit thin (a problem in itself for a $20 plus piece of fish) so maybe that is what threw the "chef" of his/her timing.  As I ate it, I couldn't even tell it was halibut as opposed to just some generic fish.  I read in the NY Times that some restaurants pass off cheap fish as halibut and, while I have no proof that is what happened here, I do wonder.  Why else would you destroy such a great fish?

Credo is in a great location and the space itself could be nice if they would install some sound baffles and scale back on the pretentious "what I believe" decor a bit.

But when the service varies between hostile at worst and merely competent at best and the food is consistently subpar, no amount of window-dressing can make a difference.

So, three strikes, lesson learned.
author: Octavio G.

description: Excellent dinner: meaty purple-potato gnocchi w/fantastic ragu, homemade ravioli w/ricotta and cooked egg inside and nice burnt butter/sage sauce, skillfully cooked brussels....great cocktail to start.
author: Jack G.

description: It is the best Italian food I have ever eaten. This would be a great experience for someone who doesn't like Italian food. I like how they put the really famous speeches on the walls and it makes it basically a history class!
author: Abel B.

description: I've been to Credo multiple times since they first opened in 2010. Overall, I really enjoy the restaurant. The atmosphere is upscale without being pretentious, the food is tasty, and the location convenient. The decor is great too; you can endlessly read all of the quotes on the walls!  It's also cool that the tables and water glasses have been repurposed, and Credo hosts and donates to many charitable events and non-profits.  The only down sides are that the menu changes pretty often (they got rid of the amazing hummus), and the noise level can get pretty high when the restaurant is busy. But, overall it is a great addition to the financial district restaurant scene and I will definitely be back!
author: R R.

description: Fun atmosphere, feels like you're in a newspaper and i love that part of their profits go to charity. Their food was also great, I had the scallops and my friend had the penne.
author: Limor B.

description: The food was pretty good but the service wasn't amazing. I loved the brussel sprouts, nearly ate three servings.
author: Chelsea K.

description:
When my husband told me we were going to dinner at Credo, I berated him for choosing a restaurant in the financial district (read: inflated prices and elusive and/or expensive parking). But much to my surprise, we lucked out and found free street parking right in front of the restaurant and the food was really fantastic!  So, here goes:  "You were right, Honey!"  There, I said it.  There you go, that's your "one."

The restaurant was moderately busy on the Saturday night that we went.  The decor, as other reviewers have mentioned, is modern/yuppy with credos ("I believe..." statements) written all over the walls.  Some of them are quite amusing.  The waitstaff was pleasant and prompt, and we were very pleased with the service.

We took advantage of the 1/2 off bottle of wine and ordered the Pellegrini 2007 Zinfandel, which we highly recommend to Zin fans.  Somewhat jammy, hints of pepper, and really smooth and easy to drink.  The Zin didn't overpower any of the dishes we ordered, even the more delicate tuna tartare.  

As for the food, we took a different approach and order 3 appetizers and one of the pasta dishes to split among us:  FRITTO MISTO - Monterey squid/Oregon Bay shrimp/shaved vegetables/artichoke hearts/tomato aioli. TARTARA DI TONNO - Ahi tuna/avocado/cucumber carpaccio/hearts of palm/ginger dressing. CARPACCIO DI MANZO - Shaved beef loin/arugula salad/hearts of palm/avocado/truffle dressing. SEDANINI ALLA CREDO - Short macaroni pasta/Italian sausage/pancetta/pecorino Romano/tomato  sauce/ topped with pizza dough & oven baked.  The Fritto Misto and Carpaccio were my favorites, but I thought the tuna tartare, while delicious, was a bit under-seasoned.  The Sedanini was quite the spectacle with its puffed up pizza dough layered over a big bowl of pasta.  The sauce from the pasta was really spectacular:  spicy, zesty, with nuggets of pancetta.  We had a hard time trying to not eat too much of the fabulous focaccia and olive medley that's served before your dishes arrive.  We ended our meal with a honey panna cotta with raspberry sauce.  

Overall, we had a great experience at Credo and will return to try other menu items.
author: Beth K.

description:
I like walking around the city on holidays when nobody's around. It feels like the entire world is just a massive playground, built just for me. The only downside, however, is that almost all businesses are closed, including my favorite local eateries.

This Memorial Day I was hanging out with my coworkers and we were imminently requiring sustenance, looking for something, anything to fill our stomachs. We stumbled upon Credo's minimalist storefront -- humble, unassuming -- and to our surprise it's open. We walk in...

--and Wow, the ambiance here is incredible! High ceilings, a colorfully stocked bar, and walls upon walls of endless quotations all beginning "I believe..." (Credo means "I believe" in Latin). I can't speak for the atmosphere on a busy day, but with the restaurant nearly devoid of customers it's evident how much thought was placed into designing and decorating. Being a bit of a sound junkie, I also realized they'd placed some sound absorbing material on the ceiling and as a result the acoustics of the room were fantastic! They were playing some fun indie pop in the background, which brought a big smile to my face.

We were seated quickly. The tables were fun and artsy, and I loved the glasses they used for water which were just like the bottoms of wine bottles, with the tops chopped off. The silverware was super awesome as well and there were little flat curved hooks at the ends of each fork, knife and spoon. I couldn't wait to use them.

The food came quickly, and it was delicious. Their bread was soft and fresh and served with an intriguing mixture of pitted olives, peppers and various Italian spices. For my dish I ordered from their prix fixe menu, which consists of a salad or soup of the day paired with either half a roasted chicken or the seafood of the day. I opted for the soup and seafood. The soup was a pureed carrot and ginger soup, very orangey and very flavorful. Although I loved it, the others at my table did not seem to lust over the ginger as much as I did. The seafood of the day was a fillet of grilled halibut served over a bed of julienned mixed veggies in a wonderful basil and olive oil broth. The halibut had a perfect, lightly seasoned layer of crisp, and the insides were juicy and tender. I was really impressed by the broth, though, which really enhanced the flavor of the fish and soft veggies when eaten together.

I had the chance to try my friend's dishes and they were quite good as well. The penne pasta is cooked perfectly al dente and comes with an epic tomato sauce. The hummus antipesto is very awesome and I highly recommend it, it's no hummus you know. A bit sharp and a bit cheesy, it curiously has the consistency of mashed potatoes.

All in all, a pleasant experience served with a delicious meal. Pricy? I'd say so. But I'll pay any day for a creative and memorable dining experience like the one I had at Credo.
author: Ayumi Y.

description: Dank.  Great for lunch and probably good for happy hour/post work although I've never been in the evening.  Spaghetti Carbonara will make you want to exercise for a few hours after eating it but is as delicious as they come.  The olive oil/garlic medley that comes wiht bread when you first sit down is also delicious.
author: Ali H.

description: Awesome food and service. Can get a little loud in there, but that is just Credo's style. My only complaint would be the prices. $24 for 5 raviolis! They were good, but not that good. Pizza was pretty tasty too.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: Came here several months ago for dinner.  Food was okay...we really liked the fondue-ish appetizer, but one friend's steak was overcooked and a component of another friend's dish was completely omitted (the menu said there would be peas!)  The omission was mentioned to a server, who went to go "check on it" and never came back :(  All in all, the dinner was okay...there are other places to try before returning here.
author: Mousputin S.

description: The bartender is great!!! But The maitre d ' is terrible! She is a mega B!!!! You aren't allowed to sit at the tables even though they are all empty!!
author: Sarah S.

description: Credo is prettier in person than on the website - and on my way to the restroom downstairs, I discovered they have a really cool private party space.  I took a bottle of wine from the cellar (2001 Carol Shelton Zin) and they were really cool about it - decanting and good glassware too.  I went with a friend and we were more up for talking than eating and the servers were nice about it.  Eventually ordered the mushroom pizza and it was just what I wanted - think crust - blistered on the bottom - light toppings - pizza the way I remember it in Rome and Naples.  Oh yeah, I'll be back to try the other things.
author: Ruth S.

description: My best friend and I work a block away from Credo and find ourselves there at least once a week. Love the decor, from the quotes on the wall, to the tables, even the water glasses! They have a great wine selection but whats even greater (and more affordable) is their house wines are so good.  If you go, definitely order the truffle french fries to start (DELICIOUSLY SINFUL).  The stuffed chicken with mashed potatos is my new fave entree and if you are going for dessert, definitely try the molten chocolate cake. Recently had the tiramisu, and its not the best I have had to be honest. Other than that, the staff is extremely friendly and attentive :) Check this place out!
author: Stefanie M.

description: Came here for a holiday work lunch. Would def come back.
author: BenHur C.

description: Was in town for business and stumbled upon this fantastic find!!!  The vibe is elegant but laid back.  Small intimate setting with unique menu items.  The chef sent us a shrimp cocktail sample that was divine!  The best fresh mozzarella and incredible service!  Next time I'm in San Fran I will be back.
author: Erin M.

description: This place has become our go to happy hour hang out, the food is great and the vibe is relaxed.
author: Clark A.

description:
The restaurant is housed in a room with a super high ceiling, it was quiet though.

The waitress had an attitude and I did not like her at all.  The busboy was nice.

I ordered the gnocchi with pesto.  It was good, the pasta was very good actually.  The pesto was OK, swimming in liters of oil.  The portion was pretty small though.

The focaccia served instead of bread was really good!
author: Sailing A.

description: I believe in a lot of things, but I don't always believe in beliefs. I believe that you can find good Italian food in the Financial District. I believe in Credo's Manhattan - made with Nocello Walnut - that I had during Yelp Drinks (http://www.yelp.com/events/san-francisco-yelp-drinks-week---san-francisco). I believe that I'll have another, in fact. I believe in the simplicity of a rustic pizza. I don't believe in excess, and that success is to give (thanks for the idea, Bono http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n7fhIVgpSnc). I don't believe R. Kelly could ever touch the sky. I believe in love. I believe in credos, and I believe that Credo is a restaurant and bar that makes San Francisco a better place for you and I.
author: Nish N.

description: A decent place for work lunch.  Very good interior decor.  It has two floors so it should seat a lot of people, but don't know why it's always full booking on a normal day.  The pizzas are good for sharing, so don't try to order one for yourself - you probably won't finish it.  The lasagna was delicious, I highly recommend it.  Service was attentive and nothing to complain about.  It's really tough to get a reservation, so try to book ahead of time.
author: Jamie L.

description: This place is good.  It's got a great atmosphere, good bartenders and a great location.  You get what you pay for.  I had lobster ravioli and of course it was good, it had lobster!
author: Corey V.

description: The food came out so fast that I burnt my tongue on the pesto.  But these leftovers I have right now (foccacia, olives..both free and pesto penne) are freaking tasty!  Mmm late night munchies
author: Pete S.

description: As one of the restaurants close to my new office, I had fairly high hopes for Credo, and they were partly borne out.  The ambience is not the greatest, but the food if on the expensive side is well-prepared.  If you have a large appetite, you should try the white bean hummus appetizer -- it's quite delicious and much, much tastier than its name and ingredients might suggest.  And though their menu is not particularly adventurous, it's got good stuff on it.  You might want to try the seared scallops which, though $24 for all of three scallops, have always been done nicely.
author: moosedog i.

description:
Although I had came here for lunch over five months ago, I still remember that I had  the worst restaurant experience EVER. I can't say dining because after nearly an hour of waiting to be served, I walked out of the restaurant not eating anything.

Hostess was rude and somehow only had eyes for a certain type of people. She was smiling and very receptive to the Caucasian gentleman that came up behind me... but somehow didn't see me, Asian female. 

After finally getting seated (10 minutes wait even with reservations) downstairs, where all the not-so-attractive people seem to be sitting, we got menus and were greeted by someone who took our drink orders. After 10+ minutes, our server finally showed up to tell us the daily specials. Keep in mind that we are here for lunch and now 20 minutes have passed. All of a sudden, she excused herself as she needed to "take of something". She returned about 5 minutes later to take our orders. Finally the server took our orders. Another 5 minutes go by, we wondered if we are going to get our drinks, that we ordered 20 minutes ago. Still nothing on our tables except our utensils and napkins. My friend asked a busboy to find a server to get us something. He was the only one kind enough to bring us some water and bread. My two other friends salad and soup arrives and I'm watching them eat as I didn't order a starter. Half way through their soup and salad, the main courses arrived. I looked at the dish I was served and was puzzled as I ordered a pasta but somehow ended up getting steak. Hmm... I asked for our server but no where to be found. When she finally turned up, we discussed what I thought I ordered versus what she heard. She went into the kitchen to try to rectify the situation. Another 5 minutes go by, the expediter brought out a dish for me, nothing close to what I ordered. By then 50 minutes had passed and I had no confidence I will ever get a reasonable meal at Credo. So, I excused myself from the table and left very dissatisfied and wondered if this restaurant knows how to run a restaurant. 

I ended up picking up a very satisfying sandwich down the street from the restaurant for a fraction of the price and most importantly, NO GRIEF. 

Not a restaurant I recommend or would ever want to work with.
author: Maggie H.

description: This was an average experience. The hummus was great but everything else was just ok. I eat out alot and was not very impressed. The server was in your face, interrupting converstations etc, but when we needed he was no where to be found. I also did not like how pushy they were for us to order wine. I left hungry.
author: oi y.

description:
This is a well designed, thoughtful, and beautiful place.   Food and service, however, need work.

The food was not well seasoned and needed much more salt, which is not provided. Admittedly, many us worry about our salt intake, but seasoning?  I had gnocchi with boar sauce.  It had way too much chocolate (I know, who could possibly object to chocolate?), and no other seasoning.  I believe that fusion cuisine can be wonderful if foods are fused with a wise, light hand.  This was not it.  My dinner partner had a lovely piece of fish--a daily special--with, again, no seasoning to speak of.  
Worse yet, out server's very smelly clothing needed laundering.
author: Milena M.

description: I usually come here for casual business lunches and after going for the fourth time last week, I'm a fan. The service is spot on, serve great focaccia bread and olives to start, and all the dishes I've tried thus far are delicious (larger quantity too!). Great meal for the price. If there is any downside, it could get a bit loud inside.
author: Chihee K.

description: My cousin was in town and we decided to get together for dinner.  After visiting Medjool, two weeks earlier, the waiter there also worked at Credo and suggested visiting there as well.  I was not disappointed, the server was very attentive and friendly, and the early dinner crowd was lively.  I had the lobster ravoli with shrimp and aspargus and it was delicious.  Too add to the interesting evening, former San Francisco mayor, Willie Brown walked in, while we were eating.
author: Carlos C.

description: Thank goodness someone thought to make good food in the financial district.  I go here for lunch a lot.  I'm half italian, so I'll give my two cents here.  My favorite dish is the very first one on the menu, substitute pancetta for tomatoes and bam..what a friggin treat.  Good service, good prices, great reading material on the wall.  You can't miss with this place.  And it's not far if you work downtown.  Bravo, Credo.
author: Amir B.

description:
I so wanted to love this place.  Loved the decor and the ambiance and the high-ceilings and the open kitchen and the nice back table my co-workers were seated in.  Was really looking forward to a great meal.  My co-worker absolutely loves going to Credo and I was excited to try it for the first time until.....

The service was so so (no refills offered on our drinks....i had an empty ice tea glass in front of me for most of the lunch and it took forever for someone to come by and refill our water glasses).  

The food was so frustratingly hit-or-miss.  The food is also why I will never dine at Credo on my own dime.  My message to the owners and managers is that at $14 for a tomato salad (sorry Burrata Caprese) and $17 for penne in tomato sauce with chicken, everything should be perfect and it just wasn't.  Our table ordered corn fritters and Burrata Caprese's to share.  The corn fritters were delicious but my last bite of salad was a thoroughly flavorless and unripe tomato which was so disappointing considering the price and the availability of amazing produce all over the bay area. 

Then my penne showed up.  ughhh....once again it wasn't terrible or it wouldn't have been terrible for a $7 or $8 lunch time pasta dish.  However, as a $17 dish it should have been spectacular and just wasn't.  Pasta itself was fine (probably store-bought) and the tomato sauce was good but nothing special but the grilled chicken was so dry...like sahara desert dry...like every single last drop of moisture had been grilled and sauteed out of it kind of dry.  The waiter comes back around and offers everyone pepper flakes or black pepper for their entrees....I am eating an italian inspired tomato sauce based pasta dish with no seafood....where the hell is the fresh Parmigiano-Reggiano to go with it?  It was never offered and I never felt comfortable enough to ask for it.

I would give it 2.5 stars if that were an option.  In summary, this place is achingly average and that is what hurt me the most.
author: Jim H.

description:
not sure if all the high star reviews are warranted.  what i experienced during a lunch was just mediocre italian food that had promise.

i split the rollata of mozzarella and prosciutto with a co-worker and we both wished the cheese was a bit softer and more flavorful.  with the accompanying tomatoes, basil and balsamic vinegar, it felt like a different version of a caprese but it didn't work.  for my main, i got the schiaffoni pasta w/ chicken, olives in a sage pancetta cream sauce.  on paper this dish sounded incredible but the execution was flat.  the pasta itself, which was like a thick pappardelle, was made very well and had nice flavor.  the chicken was almost non-existent and i was almost begging for there to be more sage and pancetta flavor in the cream sauce, they were just too subtle.

we decided against dessert and headed back to work.  we did though have a fun time reading all the quotes on the walls of the dining area.  overall, i thought this was a decent place to do a business lunch as long as you don't care too much about the food.
author: Swarup B.

description: I BELIEVE that Credo has a lovely happy hour, a nice staff, and delicious fare/drinks. I BELIEVE that the decor and atmosphere are lovely, the deep-fried stuffed olives are great, and the lemon-drop cocktail are spot on. I BELIEVE that I recommend this restaurant/bar to everyone.
author: Y K.

description:
So I wandered into this place one day for lunch and was easily seated at the bar within a few minutes.  The bartender taking my order was friendly and offered my the specials of the day.

My food arrived very quickly...a bit too quickly in fact.  The soup of the day was a potato leek and I'm usually a big fan, but this soup was about a quarter oil and the chunks of bacon didn't help.  I managed to choke down the entire bowl of soup while the bartender smiled at me.  I think she knew how bad it was...

Immediately after, my entree appeared in front of me.  Not exactly what I had pictured...the two soggy pieces of fish were covered in capers and doused in vinegar and squishy pieces of assorted squash boiled in vinegar covered the rest of my plate.  I definitely didn't finish.

I looked over to the people next to me eating a pizza, a salad, etc. and they all looked delicious compared to my specials of the day.

So, be aware when ordering here...don't get the specials unless you want a $30 disgusting lunch and a stomach ache later in the day.
author: Krystle C.

description: Pleasantly surprised, based on mixed reviews on yelp I wasn't too sure. Our hotel made reservations for us. We showed up 30 minutes early, and it was not an issue, we were seated right away. Food was amazing, sorry I'm bad at the names , but we had  antipasta, mixed green salad, prouchito pizza, soup of the day-potato and pork loin, all of it excellent. We saw a dish at the counter and inquired about it, it was a pot -pie type dish , next thing we know one of the managers brought it over to us, saying it was an extra one. It was so delicious. Service was great, I thought it was pricy, but my husband didn't think so.
author: Marlena C.

description:
We finally had a chance to try out Credo, and loved it.  The service was excellent, and our server recommended some amazing wines to go with our courses.  The Arrabiata pasta was so delicious, that I wished I wasn't sharing.  I also had the petrale sole, which was served in a caper sauce, and was perfect.  The only downside, was trying to decide between all the delicious pastas!  Can't wait to go back, and try out some of the other dishes.

Sorry Barbacco...Credo's in the same neighborhood, with much better food and wine!
author: Meghan L.

description: I'll give them a little break since they're new.   However, the food was pretty mediocre and the service was just ok.   It kind of seemed like the staff just didn't care which is unfortunate.   Get your sh*t together guys.
author: Fred X.

description: Cute spot in the Financial District.  The quotes on the wall are fun to read.   Good wines by the glass, and the caesar salad was delish!  If you come here you *must* order the Sedanini alla Credo - it's like pasta pot pie!  You may be intimidated by its enormous size, but don't be scared - you will finish it.  I wolfed it down...large tubes of rigatoni pasta and slices of Italian sausage mixed in a zesty tomato sauce, covered by a thin layer of crispy pizza dough...like I said, pasta pot pie!  Watch out for the pancetta though, they tasted more like cubes of soft fat.  That's a little much, even for me.
author: Karin V.

description:
Yeah, I would go back here regularly.  A little annoying that to be seated you have to have reservations, but we were easily seated in the back area facing the kitchen, and to their credit, each table looked as though it was full, so it makes sense they need reservations.

Was here for a lunch, and we split proscuitto wrapped mozarella.  It came on top of a salad that was equally delicious.  A really good appetizer.  The bread with the olives was a great starter as well... which pretty much prompted me into getting the pasta dish that came with a thick sauce, olives, and some chicken.  The pasta was great, and everyone else's meal looked good as well.  Definitely will go back to try the pizzas and the sandwiches.
author: Amit M.

description: Good business lunch, kinda pricey. But excellent financial district Italian resto. Recommended for casual business meeting. Boys at lunch! Not good for big groups however.
author: Kaytee M.

description:
We went in for Dine About Town with two friends several months ago, and had an excellent meal (I remember a very significant portion of sedanini -- tomato-based pasta dish with a layer of pizza dough baked on top -- and some delish cocktails; every other member of our party enjoyed their food, too, although I can't recall details now. But read on...)

Bolstered by this positive experience, we bought two $20-for-$40 vouchers to a special 3-course tasting menu w/ cocktail pairings, so went in last week to redeem them.

We had no idea what was actually *on* the tasting menu, so I specified on my OpenTable reservation that I'm vegetarian. Well, two of the three courses on the regular tasting menu contained meat, so the restaurant proactively accommodated my dietary preferences, substituting a rich, dreamy mushroom soup and perfectly salty, not too oily, arancini for the originally-planned chicken meatballs and porchetta sliders. Best of all, my cocktail pairings were changed accordingly as well (I mean, they're *supposed* to be *pairings*, but this was a busy Friday night and I can think of many other SF restaurants that wouldn't have made the effort). I was seriously impressed by the attention the team had paid to my dining experience, and in fact my husband admitted that my veggie food was in some cases even better than his!! The bread and spiced olives were a yummy accompaniment, too. Portion sizes were perfect, leaving us just enough room for dessert  (a sinful molten chocolate cake) in addition to our 3 dishes each. 

Anna, the mixologist, also happened to be our server for the evening, and took excellent care of us, coming back to check on us with every course, and of course serving up potent, innovative, and flavourful cocktails with a flourish and a smile. She happily discussed cocktail ideas, philosophies, and community-building with my budding mixologist husband, and had us sample a coffee-based aperitif with our dessert course. Credo is lucky to have her. 

So that's two out of two wins. We will definitely be back for more!
author: Simran T.

description:
I thought the food at Credo was excellent- I shared the burrata appetizer and the vegetarian version of the rigatoni with a friend.  Both were delicious a very hearty portion size.  (Although I saw someone who ordered spinach ravioli next to me and it appeared to be pretty tiny).

My only qualm with Credo was it felt a bit overpriced.  Despite that, I would definitely go back again for their fun atmosphere, delicious wine and tasty food.  

I though this was a great place if you wanted to eat downtown on a weekend since there aren't too many options on Saturdays.  I always like to eat downtown when I'm coming from home (the Castro), and I'm meeting a friend who is coming from Marin or the East Bay because it's the easiest spot to get to via public transit.  Sometimes it's a little bit of a challenge to find a good downtown weekend eatery, but Credo fit the bill.  Also, I made a reservation at around 4pm for 7:30 that same night, so although it was fairly crowded they had our table ready within 5 or so minutes of our reservation time.  Can't complain about that!
author: Jen B.

description: I've been to Credo about 5 times for dinner and a few more for drinks and I've always had a great experience.  Went twice with the old Chef Mario and three times with the new Chef Gustavo.  The food is very good and the service was great.  My favorite dishes were the Maiale Osso Buco and the Capesante scallops.  Took my sisters from out of town on a Saturday night and the Chef came to our table to say hi and chat with us about the food, his experiences, and other stuff.  Pretty cool!  Since we San Franciscans flee the FiDi on the weekends, Credo is a pretty good place for a Saturday night if you don't have a resi or don't want to wait 2hrs for a table somewhere else.  One of my favorite experiences was during Cinco de Mayo of this year.  The Chef changed up the menu and served up some great Mexican favorites like queso fundido, tacos, and molotes de papa.  Delicioso!  My date was vegetarian and the Chef was more than accommodating.  I'v been there for drinks after work and really like the bar area.  Pretty laid back and relaxed as opposed to other FiDi bars that get super crowed/loud on Thursdays/Fridays.  The bartender, Greg, is a cool dude and always down to chop it up a bit.
author: Ivan M.

description: Came here with a friend and loved it.  Our server (Tracy) was wonderful and offered up some great suggestions.  If you go, make sure you try a Credo Mahattan.  Foodwise, don't miss the rollata di mozzarella or the pappardelle al funghi porcini.  The lobster ravioli was only okay, but having tried my friend's entrée I'd say that I wouldn't mind going back there for that alone.
author: Dale R.

description: We came here on a Friday night before going to see a movie at the Embarcadero.  We had the fried olives (great starter -- but a little heavily fried), the pasta/sausage bowl with the pizza everyone talks about (the sauce is the secret, not the dough -- it's tasty), and a black cod special.  Look, its a neat space with neat tables and fun stuff to read.  It has a full bar, reasonable service, and very tasty food.  It's not going to become anyone's neighborhood favorite, but it makes for a great once a year treat.  It's much better Italian food than you normally get in SF, though certainly not NY quality.  What's the Steven Still's song -- "Love the place you have?".
author: Trent W.

description: We had our wedding rehearsal dinner at Credo this weekend!  It was amazing!  Mark went out of his way to try and make our evening very memorable.  The food was much more than expected and the service was top-notch!  Everyone was still talking about it on Sunday.  Very reasonably priced for the fare you receive.  Thanks again Mark!  The Smith's
author: Beth S.

description: I love this place. From service to quality to ambience - very cool! Nice break from my day when I am working from the SF office - although the break is on the pricey side :)
author: Saf A.

description: Fantastic Italian restaurant in Financial District with an awesome vibe and delicious food. Came here for a birthday dinner and had the veal ravioli with sage cream sauce and pine nuts. It was heavenly. My friends had a great pesto artichoke pizza, lobster ravioli, and pasta with pizza dough crust. Everything was so delicious, and the prices weren't that bad (mine $18). The restaurant itself is really nice and modern, there are colorful quotes on the walls and cool tables. New food find!
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
If you're thinking of coming here for a business lunch/dinner, DO NOT come here!  The hostess is so rude and snotty, and it was not warranted at all.  I made lunch reservations for work last Friday on Open Table and was running 15-20 minutes late.  When I called to let them know we were running late, the hostess was rude and it seemed like she was mad we were running late!  When we arrived, it was only five or ten minutes later than we expected and the hostess (the same one that answered the phone) said she cancelled our reservations because their policy is to cancel if we are late 10 minutes or more.  I told her that I called and told her that I was running late.  She ignored me and said that she'll try to see if she has an available table (as if she's doing me a favor).  She gave us a table and when we got there, it was set up for a table for four.  The three of us chose our seats and the hostess purposely put the menus in front of the three seats that were not mine! Did she want me to move to a different chair to where she put the menu??? I don't think so.  

The food here is fine but again, this is definitely not a place to go to for business because can you imagine having to go through all of this with your clients and/or business associates watching you? 

I spoke with the manager about this and she seemed empathetic and apologized and was nice enough to offer me to come in for a free meal.  I won't take her up on it but thought it was a nice gesture.  Unfortunately, the damage has been done.
author: Sophie H.

description:
Last night we had a great dinner at Credo. The food was delicious but what made it special was the staff. 
Melinda, the host, was friendly and professional and we shared a few minutes of interesting conversation. the waiter was great. all the staff made us feel home and well taken care of for the entire time. I think this counts as the best service I ever had in a restaurant in the city...

Food: we shared the caprese salad (perfect), their signature pasta (perfect) and the vitello tonnato, which is a very modern version of an italian classic (very good. not perfect but close). the aperitifs were great and so was our bottle of pinot grigio. overall, a perfect dinner. 

it's on the expensive side and it feels it is geared more to business people on expense reports than on friends having dinner together. that said it's as expensive as most other nice Italian places in town, like A16, Farina, etc...
author: francesca n.

description: Not super impressed with this place.  Pizza's were OK, the menu boring and the quality was average.For lunch, with reservations ended up waiting (outside) 12 min...perhaps a better experience during the evening hours.  So far, not a fan, which is a shame as I feel this place has lots of potential.
author: Rebecca W B.

description: Great service.  Great decor.  For the price, food was meh.  $11 salads.  A little pricey for lunch if you're just looking for a regular spot.  Since the atmosphere and service were great, I'd say that's what you're paying for.
author: Annie R.

description: Credo is a particularly unimaginative restaurant in the Financial District. Granted, the decor is nice, and we had good service, but lunch menu and the food resulting from it, were awful.  Our two starters, a mushroom fondue and a white bean hummus were essentially identical dishes - almost all fried flatbed.  And our main course - a chopped salad with salami and pepperoni - had flavors that were way out of balance.  You can do better downtown, and at a much better price.
author: Brian M.

description:
OMG!! This place is fantastic! My co-workers and I came here for lunch after buying a gift certificate off of livingsocial. com.  If you are looking for a sit down nice restaurant that doesn't cost an arm and a leg you've found your place.  

For our appetizer, we got the salt and pepper calamari . We ate it so quickly it didn't even have time to cool down.  Not only that but it didn't have the ugly leg bits that you find in most calamari. Perfectly cooked, not rubbery at all.

For our entree's, we ordered the soup of the day, the spinach salad, the pasta of the day, and the prosciutto panini.  Everything was perfect, and the fries that came with the panini were heavenly.  
I can't wait to go back to try the margherita pizza!
author: Nancy S.

description: I found the meal to be very satifying !  A group went out after work and stumbled upon Credo and have now added it as one of our "places"  The menu is extensive, the wine list all you could want and the service is friendly, fast, and competent.  The calamari was delicious, the hummas out of this world and the pork Milanese portion was a very generous portion.  Lastly their tiramisu is what it should be.  All in all good food and fun atmosphere big thumbs up!!
author: M C.

description: A great new place to dine! You really get your moneys worth with their generous portions something pratically unheard of these days.  I'm hooked.....but they got me with the Howard quote
author: R S.

description:
Came here with some old co-workers, with the intention of ordering from the D.A.T. menu, but the choices weren't very appealing. We ended up ordering from the regular menu. Out of curiousity, I ordered the duck ragu over chocolate paperdelle with candied orange. Other than perhaps a more earthy taste to it, the paperdelle was unremarkable. The duck ragu itself was good, but overall, the dish was disappointing. I tried and wasn't impressed by what my friends ordered either. I recall a fish dish, but otherwise I can't even remember what they ordered.

I may have been mildly affected by my drink, but I doubt it since I abandoned it relatively quickly. I had a strawberry lemonade ginger beer concoction. While the taste was good, practically speaking , the ginger bits should've been filtered out - they kept clogging up the cocktail straw. It was irritating, but in the end, it was fine since it was perhaps the strongest cocktail I've ever had.

The tiramisu and molten chocolate cake were just alright. I ordered an espresso to help me recover from my cocktail and I've never had such strong espresso before either. It was intense! The smell as the waitress was bringing it over was enough to clear my head.

Overall, I wouldn't go again. I had wanted to go elsewhere to begin with, but it was chosen due to convenience. I regret not being more insistent about my preferences.
author: Tammy L.

description: Walked in with a friend because they were offering a FREE lunch as a promotion. Great great idea! The olives for an appetizer were incredible, I had the salmon salad for lunch. It was the perfect size, not too big or too small for lunch. The service here is amazing, the dude actually put the napkin on my lap for me - who the hell does that anymore? The decor is retro and very sheik and they played good music (helloooo Beirut!). Prices were inline with the FiDi. Would definitely recommend a great place to go for lunch with coworkers or friends. I wonder if they have a happy hour....
author: Jordan V.

description:
Great.  Clean atmosphere with tons of natural light and a great bar.  The quotes on the walls are great conversation topics.

I had the calamari appetizer in a red sauce (excellent) and the rolled buffalo mozzarella appetizer (also spot on).  I had a seafood pasta that worked well with a nice glass of pinot.
author: David A.

description: If you're looking for a great place to eat downtown look no further. Every time I eat here it's better than the last. Excellent food, great service and a wonderful atmosphere.
author: Steele D.

description: Credo has been a long time favorite of mine and has continued to be one. It's service is phenomenal and food is exceptional. You can always count on Credo to make your experience worth wild whether it's just stopping in for a happy hour or wanting to enjoy a nice dinner experience with good food and great people. Credo is where it's at. Great work Credo and staff keep it up.
author: Scott E.

description: Food was nice but portions were small - I felt like I needed to call in for snack on the way back to the office. It was also very noisy
author: Tim K.

description:
Credo's opening day seemed to be going fairly smoothly as I sat down for lunch. The staff was friendly and the Pizza was good. My friend and I both ordered Pizzas and had them in front of us in no time. The Tuscan had sausage, smoked mozzarella, and red onions. The sausage and sauce dominated the dish but not in an unappetizing way. I couldn't find the distinct taste of smoked mozzarella in the dish but found the extremely thin crust very authentic. The oven was either not wood burning or it was too well cleaned. I like a little touch of ash on the bottom of my pizza.

The restaurant was beautiful, with high ceilings and a crisp bar. The small kitchen was fully exposed and steamed the front glass on a cold, rainy day.  I will go back to Credo and am interested in trying one of their sandwiches or pasta dishes.
author: Jake O.

description: The ambiance is very hip/trendy as well as the decorations.  I tried 2 of their cocktails to begin... neither were that great and one started tasting like muddy Listerine water after awhile.  We began with the Frito misto and I ordered the Sedanini which was delish and a great presentation.  However, my date's salmon was just so so and for the price we spent I was expecting a little higher in taste.
author: Gina W.

description: Credo (I Believe) is an absolutely unique restaurant. The food was delicious, customer service incredible, and ambiance was not only fun, but stimulating. Reading all the credo's on the wall not only contributed to great dinner talk, but was educational as well. The Julia Morgan cabernet was feast for the taste buds! Looking forward to going back!
author: Daniel S.

description: Fabulous foods and drinks at decent prices. Great service and atmosphere. Also nice spot for lunch and happy hour too.
author: eryn y.

description:
I've gone here several times for lunch and dinner.  The service is good, the drinks are strong and the food is excellent.

We've never had a bad dish.   The Antipasto Misto has a nice collection of meats and is good for an appetizer for two. 

Fonduta del Bosco is great.. the truffles add a nice touch.

I've had various pizzas, they've all been good.   The Sedanin alla Credo is awesome.. it's a bowl of pasta covered in pizza dough... 

As I said, never had a bad dish here.
author: lisa t.

description: Great place awesome location - bar seen is cool and so is the food.
author: Matthew A.

description:
Actually it should be 2.5 stars.....
Fun interior,very modern and we loved the quotes.We were very excited to go because we saw the place from the outside and had heard a bit about it. 9 pm reservation but we were almost 15 minutes early and were promptly seated.
Ordered a bottle of wine which was very nice, a bit pricey perhaps( 72) but when ordering Italian I find it better to spend a bit more.
Tomato soup was very heavy, a lot of bread in it and nothing special.Tuna tartar w. avocado was very bland - what a disappointment.
Barramundi with vegetables was cooked perfectly though. Short rib ravioli was again bland and had a strange light sauce with it.Not what you usually get with the ribs. Could hardly tell there was short rib in it.It could have been any meat  or chicken.
Chocolate cake was very moist and delicious and came with vanilla ice cream and creme fraiche.
Service was definitely on the hurried side because we were finished by 9:54 - extremely rare.Dishes came out soo fast. But I think they wanted us to go home and we were the last table.
On the way out nobody looked up or said good bye etc. - the staff was much too busy to talk amongst themselves !  Not good at all.
This could be a great and modern spot, it has all the ingredients but staff has to be trained better especially in customer service and just maybe---they should get a proper chef.
author: Maria C.

description: This place is great!  They make a great Manhattan!  The Hummus is delicious and so was the calamari.  The Seabass and the pork was very good.  The wine list has a nice choice of California wines & Italian wines.  They are open for lunch and dinner.  We were a party of 8 and had a great time.
author: Lynnet S.

description: my first time with co-workers for after work drinks and dinner.  great find.  the food was fantastic, really cute open space with fun decor and the staff was top-notch.  i will definitely go back!
author: Karen R.

description:
Had an amazing time at this restaurant.  I believe we went here on their 4th day of opening and it seemed like everyone was well knowledgeable on the restaurant, food, drinks, and atmosphere that this place is setting.  Speaking of which, the atmosphere was very unique and I would dine there just for that.  The silverware and table tops are what I would want to have at my house (contemplated on helping myself to their utensils) and the arrangement of the restaurant was very unique.  Seating is very interesting, you could either sit at a table, sit at the bar, or something that I will try next time, and sit at the kitchen bar.  The kitchen is an open kitchen and they were wise enough to include a few seats their, so if someone goes on their own, and after they finish reading all the quotes on the walls, they can watch their dish being prepared.  "I believe I am the Worlds best singer." - Celine Dion.  While that is not true, you will have a laugh over some of the quotes that are on the wall.
In terms of food, they offer very unique dishes that are worth visiting them and trying.  We had the sedanini alla credo (delicious pasta with sausage hidden under a pizza dough covering).  This dish was huge, it was split up between two and it was still very filling.  But we did leave enough room for dessert.  We ordered the Tortino di ricotta e frutta candita con salsa ai lamponi (Tuscan ricotta cheese and raisin cake).  Unlike our dinner this was rather small, but after having a hearty dinner, this was a good way to finish our meal.  The flavors are light, but enjoyable.  I would recommend this place to anyone in the area, especially for lunch.  We got in easy, but I would make reservations (especially if there is somewhere in particular you would like to sit.
author: Adam S.

description: I expected to walk out of Credo planning to write a 4 or 5 star review, but my entree was a total letdown.  The wine and salad were fine, and the other folks' entrees looked good, so maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.  I had the grilled chicken, and it could not have looked less appetizing, the way it was presented.  Picture a chicken defeathered, squashed flat, and grilled.  That was my plate.  I almost felt sick when it was set on the table in front of me.  My husband had a very simple, light spaghetti with mozzarella balls.  It was good, but very basic.  His friend had the signature dish, in the vegetarian version, with the pizza dough cover on top.  He liked it.  My only good memory of this meal is the quotes on the walls...cool idea.  Horrible chicken.
author: Molly P.

description:
I went there for lunch, although the food was good, the service was slow.
It felt like if the waiter had to be there for hours so should we.  
The desserts are really good !
author: Shirley A.

description:
Every time I walk by, Credo is "full" of diners. I have stepped inside to check out this restaurant for client lunches but have decided against it since the noise volume is so loud, I wouldn't be able to hear a word my client would say. 

I will still come back and keep checking it out to see when they do something about the noise level. Once that is fixed, I will try the food. Can't understand how people can eat in such a noisy restaurant.
author: Julia M.

description: I like this place even tho it's hella expensive for pasta.  Ordered the pasta pot pie.  It's big bowl of bowl of pasta with a pizza dough top.  Guy even came over and helped me cut the top off, which I liked.  My hommie ordered a steak and he said it was just ok.  Funny thing was we sat at the kitchen bar seats so we were watching the cooks do their thang.  Even saw them snag a piece off hommie's steak.  I'm pretty sure they heard my hommie cursing it up.  Still the service was top notch.
author: Richard N.

description:
Went to Credo because my wife found it available on open table at a pressing time:  4 people at 8 PM on a Friday night within walking distance from the Old Ship Saloon. 

I was in my cups when I got there (and had 2 more drinks with dinner), so my review may be crap.

I liked it - I was in no shape for anything subtle or delicate, so the monster Sedanini ala Credo (pasta inside a pizza crust - holy cow I am fat!) was right on. I did not try anyone else's food but my three companions all seemed happy with what they had. 

Theh service was good - effective and just present enough.

My biggest complaint is one that another reviewer had: the noise. Its just a bit too loud in there. There is a reason that those old school leather-boothed, richly carpeted steakhouses were done like they were done - its quiet, maybe even dignified. Credo, like many other restaurants in a more modern and stylish model, is sharp, clean, taut, and way too friggin loud once you get a few dozen people yammering at each other.

I would certainly go back if I were in the hood, probably to try the pizza.
author: Rick P.

description: We got the Groupon for Credo and decided to try it. Smack in the middle of FiDi, there was plenty of parking on a Monday night. There were many empty tables when we arrived, and we were seated promptly. The decor is modern and easy on the eyes. Service was good and the pasta dishes tasted fresh and flavorful. I was surprised that the soup of the day was a chilled gazpacho, since it was a typical summer night in SF; you know, 55 degrees and misty. The calamaretti app was delicous, alberi pricey. The spinaci side was a bit bland. IWhen the bill came, we were shocked at how expensive it was. I walked away with buyer's remorse, which I rarely feel after dinner. Don't get me wrong, the place is hip, and the meal was tasty, but I felt like it was overpriced for what it was. We can find as good or better Italian in SF for less.
author: Anne Y.

description: Love it!  Went there last year for our office holiday lunch and thought it was good enough to go again for this year's lunch.  Now I remember why...because it is awesome.  If I had to look really hard to find anything negative I would only suggest using different silverware.  It looks nice and fancy (kinda Nightmare Before Christmas theme type, of which I am a fan) but it is difficult to manage.  The round handles make it challenging but not to worry, I found a way to eat every morsel on my plate (except the veggies, not because I don't like veggies but because they had a odd taste to them) but I still love this place).  Joseph was a very nice and pleasant server.  Absolutely a two thumbs up from me.
author: Shirley B.

description: Great place for a nice hearty meal. Love all the qoutes on the wall.
author: Bradley H.

description: Not great, not bad.  Went here for lunch with some work peeps.  Ordered the veggie fettucine, which had so much promise and lacked, so much, on flavor.  However, it wasn't disgusting, so they get a star for that.  The service was friendly and quick, thus another star.  And gotta say, I think this is a really cute place, so it'd get another half, if that were an option.  Not gonna go back, particularly at those prices, but it's alright.
author: Adam T.

description:
Over priced. Not a big lunch selection. Went for lunch with colleagues. Not a good place for groups. The service was very slow. Took us 2 hours, 30 of which was actual eating time. Had Penne with chicken. Pretty spicy (fortunately I like spice... hotter than jalapeno hot). wanted half salad... not available. 
Appetizers were better than food. Bread with rosemary spicy olives, stuffed olives and crispy flat bread with cannellini bean dip.
Orders included chicken panini and lamb panini which came in hamburger buns? huh? Nobody ate their parmesan fries. Fries were cold. (My manager refused to complain so I'm doing it here on behalf of all foodies). Room was a little too smoky.

Bottom line......... over priced..slow service. Food was just OK.
author: Shiru M.

description: We ate dinner here last night and thought it was just ok.  The service was ok.  We had friends in from out of town and one ordered the crab and shrimp ravioli, which came out of the kitchen cold.  The server had it remade and didn't charge, but I was still embarrassed given that we had recommended the place.  The veal ravioli my husband ordered was just ok.  I had the cheese tortellini with spinch, nuts and oil, which was very good and everyone with me liked it.  I can't say I will go back anytime soon.  I agree with others that the place has great potential but for now it is too expensive for what it is at this point.
author: Rise G.

description: They have all of these quotes on the wall.  My favorite is the one from Tiger Woods where he claims that he received all of his family values from his parents.    The food is good.   The service is inconsistent.   At the bar, I felt ignored, but once someone paid attention to me, I really did feel that they were attentive.   It might be good for a party, but not romantic enough for a date.   I probably wouldn't go back given all of the other great choices in the city.
author: Asit P.

description: Awesome Italian Food.  Great location and fun crowd.  Very good wine list as well.  The quotes on the wall add a very interesting conversation topic.
author: Nyk K.

description: I get pretty excited when anywhere new opens within walking distance in the finacial district.  Tried Credo 2 times and the 2 star rating is a blend of the 2 visits.  First time the pizza was delicious with 4 cheese and wilted arugula but the second time the pizza was swimming in oil to the point i was grossed out and couldn't finish.  The taste actually wasn't too bad but the oil killed it.  First trip I had good service but the second trip it was horrible.  When you finally get to run out of the office and eat you still need to keep it within a reasonable time frame.  Took ~15 minutes to meet our server and then about 30 minutes to get our food.  Only saw him those 2 times before having to track him down for the check...  I can see how some people might have a lucky 4-5 star dining experience but this place is just too streaky to waste a precious lunch away from your desk.
author: Joshua F.

description: Had a private event at Credo.  They took great care of us.  The food was mid-range.  The steak was a bit fatty.  Overall a good experience but not top notch.
author: Matthew B.

description:
The reason I'm giving this 2 stars instead of 1 is because their service is good. But the food ranges between average and awful. 

You'd think that with wood burning stove, they'd be able to make a crispy pizza. Think again. Their pizza is soggy and doughy with nary a fresh ingredient in sight. The veal ravioli is probably, no definitely, the worst ravioli I've ever eaten. The pasta is too thick, doughy, and rubbery. Actually rubber might have tasted better. The sauce was awful too.

The calamari appetizer was the only dish we actually ate. Calamari well cooked. Sauce average. We didn't want to risk dessert so we bolted.

Until Credo gets a chef that can cook, save your appetite and wallet (because this place is not cheap), and go to one of the touristy places in North Beach. I swear even they're better.
author: Jay K.

description:
Overall 3.5 stars

I dined here on a Saturday night... which means lots of parking in front and nearby in the Financial District.  The foccacia bread served at the table was quite stale.  Fortunately, the rest of the food was decent as we ordered the pasta dish with sausages and pizza dough on top... a wonderful visual presentation and tasted mostly fine but I wish we had more pasta and less sausages as the sausages made the dish too salty for my taste.  The Milanese pork chop which was ok but nothing to write home about.  

May come back for lunch.
author: Eleanor C.

description: Good for lunches downtown. Somehow finds the Venn overlap of good, sometimes great, food and service; but not so over the top that the restaurant itself becomes the primary focus of the conversation. Senior management of the restaurant obsesses on the details, but gets the big picture. I love the lasagna.  Sometimes energy drops on the weekends, really a function of the 'hood than the restaurant itself.
author: Anup D.

description: First of all, I LOVE the atmosphere!  The text on the walls was fun and fascinating to read.  I would even eat here alone since I would be entertained reading the walls!   The tables and glassware were fabulous.  The texture, the reuse factor...I was in LOVE!  I had great service, the cocktails were delightful and the food...ahhhh the food.  "I believe I love Credo!"
author: Melly G.

description:
Great waitress, ok food (for the price).  One dish was very good and two were just ok.  

The tomato and green been salad would have been great except that the tomatos were flavorless.  

The veal ravioli with sage and pancetta was quite good.  

The cornish hen was well prepared but with little flavor.

Not a bad experience overall; however, for the price point I expected more.  

Finally, this is the ONLY resto in SF I have seen do an add on charge for SF's living wage law.  The ONLY extra charge I expect to see on my bill is for taxes.
author: Food B.

description: Run, don't walk to Credo! This hidden gem is absolutely phenomenal. The food was absolutely delish (we had the Sedanini Alla Credo and Pici Toscano). Both were absolutely delightful. Could have done without the Cesar Salad and Chocolate Dessert we order. The wine we chose and the bread were delicious has well. I'd definitely recommend this restaurant and I'd definitely come back.
author: Cara P.

description: great HH until 6:30pm.  the ragu pasta (small plate) on the HH menu is so delish!  i'm craving it again and just had it a couple days ago.  you must try this when you go.
author: Gina P.

description: Looking for a great pizza, cocktail, glass of wine, or all around good time?  Then look no further.  I sat at the bar and started with a great Limoncello and St. germaine cocktail.  I will be back to try other things, but I can honestly recommend everything I had; the sausage pizza, the pappardelle with mushrooms, and don't miss the Tiramisu for dessert.  Oh, and the Nebbiolo by the glass is fantastic.  Even the service was friendly as could be.  This area is in much need of a foodie revolution and we welcome Credo to the fidi.
author: J. F.

description: After a round of cocktails at the disappointingly dark Local Edition on Friday April 13th three of us walked over to try Credo and wow, that was a great idea! Knowledgeable staff and good drinks, complemented by a terrific pizzetta and a ceasar salad for appetizers and all three of us were content - and we could see each other!
author: Bob Y.

description: Went there for lunch.  Great bean hummus with even better toasted, buttered rosemary bread to eat with olives, which are delicious, stuffed with rosemary and garlic!.  Arrabiata pasta is a food safe choice as are their pizzas.  Nice ambiance, service was so so, but got better as it went along.  Ther mixed drinks are really good, but try not to have too much for lunch.  Also, try the tiramisu, so moist and delicate.
author: Jon Z.

description: Once you get past the pretentious statements posted all over the wall (I know, I know, it's part of the "honest food" theme), you can start exploring the menu.  We split an appetizer of wild mushrooms, which was exquisite, and moved to the salads, which were fresh and imaginative.  We were surprised with a tiramisu on the house since we were celebrating, and while it's not the desert I would have ordered, I have to say that it was very, very good.
author: Judith W.

description:
I really enjoyed my dining experience at Credo.  I loved that the restaurant is very open and light.  The quotes on the wall are a wonderful conversation starter which, in my opinion makes this a perfect restaurant to go on a first date or business luncheon.  The large windows facing the street also makes it a fun people watching spot.

The food was very good especially the fried olives and calamari.  Their panna cotta is amazing too!  The service was great and I would recommend eating at this restaurant.  This restaurant could potentially be a fun location to host a birthday party or cocktail reception.
author: K C.

description:
Their food is decent but 12 bucks for a one-third full glass of house Merlot? I'm not as dumb as I look, trust me! 23 bucks for a pasta dish? A single cheese pizza, 19 bucks? Who in the hell are they kidding? But I must say the restaurant was full of suckers!!!!! And they seemed to enjoy it! I love a good meal. I dont mind paying a fair price. I just dont like to feel like I had been turned upside down and had my pockets emptied. Then to top it off they added a 20 percent fee (they call gratuity to our bill and didnt tell us so we tipped 15 percent on top of that! I called the next day and they were nice enough to return the additional 15 percent. If money is no object, then go for it!!!! If you work hard for your money then California Kitchen down the street is about half the price.
I have changed my rating from 2 to 3 stars because the MGR cared enough to listen and reply to my review. That is great customer service!
author: Steve W.

description: PRICEY but yummy. I had the salmon salad appetizer and it was definitely big enough for lunch. My friend had a delicious turkey club with parmesan fries. And they give you yummy focaccia bread with spicy olives to start. Delicious! I plan to come back and try the gnocchi.
author: Latte Queen W.

description:
This is the first time I have ever been compelled to write a Yelp review. Credo has a great look and location. However, the food is totally overpriced and barely mediocre. It was hard to carry on a conversation even though my friend and I were sitting next to each other at the bar. We both ordered the lamb shank as our dinner entree. It came with flavorless polenta that was chock full of leeks -- the dark green part. The lamb was barely warm and not falling apart as a good lamb shank should. It was covered in some nondescript flavorless brown sauce and I guarantee the shank wasn't braised in the sauce . It also came out of the kitchen way too fast. Always a bad sign. I also thought it was strange that the shank cost less than the pork chop that was on the menu. Granted I did not sample a lot of menu items, but my many years of dining in SF tell me that if this place doesn't step up its game it is going to have a short life. The rent has got to be a killer.

On a positive note, the bartender was incredibly attentive and concerned that we were not enjoying our entrees. She comped us a gelato. But in the end all the gelato in the world won't make up for high priced, amateur food in the financial district. I would have been more satisfied if I had thrown a ton of cash at Perbacco.

Just for kicks I might give this place another shot at lunch for pizza and salad.
author: marilyn u.

description: I was here for a business dinner and the food was amazing (although the restaurant was a bit noisy.) My favorite part: they carry gluten free pasta! (Just let the server know when you arrive as the pasta takes a few extra minutes to prepare.) They don't have many desserts for the gluten free, but they are very accommodating with the rest of the menu.
author: Andrea V.

description: Liked the decor (good selection of quotes on the wall). I paid with a coupon and ate by myself, yet still received polite, swift service. I had tuna encrusted with something or other and thoroughly enjoyed it. Good desert too (ice cream inside of pastry covered with chocolate sauce--try it).
author: Chris P.

description: Food was good but service was horrible.  Whenever my mom visits we go here one night, which has totaled 4 times.  Tonight it took us 2.5 hours to eat, and that wasn't because of the kitchen. Our server would ignore us for 30 minutes, and not see us trying to get our attention. Tables sat 45 minutes after us paid their bill at same time we did.  I love this place and was truly disappointed.
author: kara S.

description: I'm editing my review based on the restaurant's feedback.  This space is lovely.  I wasn't wowed by my vegetarian pasta dish but my two companions loved their fish dishes.  I'll give this place another try.  Our server was really friendly and the host went out of his way to get a cab for us.
author: Grace R.

description: Credo has very authentic Italian food.  Chef Mario was born in Firenzi, and his cooking is a perfect reflection of the cuisine of Florence.  Dishes are simple in presentation, with a rustic flare.  The food has incredible, lingering flavor.   From pasta dishes, to the pounded pork or chicken, and pizza - the food is great.  The meatball and Tuscan toast appy is very tasty!  The sides, like spinach and roasted potatoes are a wonderful compliment to the main dishes, and don't forget to leave room for dessert!  Mario's Tiramisu out of this world!  The quote filled wall space creates a fun atmosphere, and sitting at the chef's counter is also a great adventure.  The wait staff is personable, and the drinks / bar are great, as well.  Although we live in Berkeley, we often say, "Let's go to the City and have dinner somewhere" - and then we begin to plot out a place to eat.  Now that Credo is in town, we have a new order to that equation - "Let's go eat at Credo" - Which means being in the City is a simply a coincidence, not the reason for the journey.
author: Miles B.

description: I had an awesome time at Credo!  The staff was so welcoming and knowledgeable, especially for just opening. AJ, who works the door was a gem!  The pizza and gnocchi were some of best I've had.  Looking forward to going there again!
author: Danielle W.

description: Came he on our visit to SF and used a Groupon.  Nice atmosphere and we had a very attentive waiter which for a Friday night in the city was nice.  Tables at the restaurant were a little close.  Nice bred and olives served with our starter.  We had the fired olives with marinara sauce, nice but I've had better, albeit in Italy :).  My husband was very happy with his risotto fruti di mare (risotto with mixed seafood).  Think Italian paella.  I had the veal house made ravioli.  They were lovely, the cream sauce was ladled on a bit too heavy but we used to live in Italy where sauce is a condiment not the main dish.  I ordered the grilled mixed vegetables as a side and was anticipating the lovely, sliced grilled vegetables that we enjoyed so much in Italy.  Instead I got diced vegetables cooked on a flat top grill, they weren't bad but when ordering grilled vegetables I expect some grill marks!  All in all our bill was a reasonable $53 and considering I had bought a $50 GC for only $25 on Groupon it was a good deal.  We tipped well and went home with full tummies.
author: Christine P.

description: My husband and I recently ate at Credo, and enjoyed an exceptional culinary experience! We each had different appetizers and entrees and found not only the food, but the service to be outstanding.
author: Peggy E.

description: well,  I went to Credo on June 03,2010 because we wanna try  SF dine about town 2010. I came here with my friend and order 2 courses + 1 course.
