author: Elisabeth T.

description: I would give a 3.5 stars, but not quite 4, so 3 it is.  I had a very pleasant meal with a few friends.  The food is pretty good, but not something to die for.  The service is very nice and the price is right.  The pasta with the top crust looks very impressive.  Also tried the pork loin and it was huge.  The decor is simple, clean and attractive.  It's very appropriate for business casual meeting as well as just regular friend gathering.
author: E H.

description: Absolutely nothing special here.  Not terrible, but no reason to go here.  Palio's pasta is much better, and any decent pizza at Tomasso's is better.  The bar is dull.
author: Happy C.

description: Great straight-forward nuvo-peasant Italian food it an amazing setting.  Top marks for interiors and a great addition to the SF scene.
author: John O.

description:
A-OK. Lunch review only.

Food was good, not great or inspiring. Not really worth the price for what we (2 of us) shared...
insalata di pollo: Despite the under-seasoned chicken and slightly bland home made mozzarella, the rest of the components of the salad were tasty. The corn and carrot flavors really came through, and the Chianti dressing wasn't over-powering, although there was a little too much of it. Portion was not worth $11.95. I can get twice as much salad at mixt greens for the same price.
casoncelli di bergamo al burro fuso (tortelloni stuffed with ricotta and spinach in sage browned butter sauce): This was the best dish, although still lacking some depth, and the portion was a bit small (7 'jumbo' tortelloni). The sauce was not too buttery and the fried sage added a nice touch. I think they used about 10 spinach leaves in the whole stuffing because I did not taste it at all, and there were a lot of hazelnuts, although that did not bother me.
because I was still hungry, I ordered the daily soup (mind you, I have an appetite for my 120lb body, or it could just me credo needs to serve bigger portions). It was a tomato soup... good, although not amazing. It had a pretty strong garlic flavor, according to my lunch mate, but I enjoyed it.

Service was good, my water glass was never empty. 

Decor was modern and comfortable. Loved the wood tables and silverware, although the knife was kind of a pain in my hand. It was pretty noisy for lunch... I'd say it was at about 80% capacity and there was only 1 person at the bar. They should have had the wall posters made out of fabric, or put something in to absorb some sound.

I'd only go back to try a pizza or paninoteca. Based on what we ordered, credo was not really worth the $- taste or portion wise. When you're serving a basic penne pasta in a spicy garlic tomato sauce for $10.95 for lunch, how is that worth the money? Yes this place is in the Financial District, but that's no excuse for overpriced pasta. Maybe lasagna for $12.95, but plain pasta for $2 less??
author: Sarah K.

description: My first visit to Credo was Friday, April 23rd.  We did not have reservations, so we sat at the community table.  The service was excellent and the food fantastic.   The only other restaurants for which I have had similar perfect al dente pasta are Don Giovanni's in Napa and Alba, Piemonte, IT.  I have found a new favorite spot!
author: J J.

description: I have to say that this place is a breathe of fresh air. It strangely has a casual vibe yet some of the food is very classy. I think that it can be a hit or miss for people depending on what they order. This place is across the street from Equinox where I work out and when feeling like I had a good work out - my friend and I hit this place for a reward. Ok - so we sometimes go even if we didn't have a good workout! We have found a couple dishes which we always order since we know they are delicious and one in particular that is unique (at least I think it is!) to Credo. That dish is the Sedanini alla Credo. The best way to describe it is pasta with sausage, pancetta, sage and pecorino covered with pizza dough and baked! It comes out the size of a full size pie and is SO good. It is also probably an entire day's calorie intake but it is worth it! I also love their version of caesar salad which comes topped with a soft boiled egg. This last visit I tried the pomegranate duck breast with fried plantains (yum) and it was really good. I loved that they crisped up the skin which gave the dish another dimension. A lot going on in this dish with the mole sauce but I really liked it. I have to admit I have not tried any of their desserts since after the Sedanini that is almost impossible without needing to be rolled out!
author: M S.

description: very good food, had the rosemary chicken and was quite happy.  the calamari was also very good, and I have had a lot of calamari!
author: Michael W.

description: My friend and I went to lunch here yesterday and I was underwhelmed. On the positive side: Nice "New York style" space and two very friendly waiters. On the negative side: Super noisy (not suited for parties over 2!), mediocre, overpriced food. The complimentary salt/olives/bread combo are a nice touch and our water came quickly (including my special request of water without ice). Our waiter seemed a bit miffed when we didn't want to order a cocktail right away and told him that we wanted to pick our food first and then pair the wine. He did let us taste the wine we were interested in though which not all restaurants do. I ordered the salmon salad which the woman eating at the table next to us seemed to enjoy and which was served Nicoise style with hard boiled egg, olives and green beans. My friend went for the "fish of the day", a sauteed petrale sole with vegetables. I chose the Rose off the wine list and asked our waiter to recommend a white for my friend's fish. He suggested the French Sauvignon Blanc which was delicious but at $14.95 one of the most expensive glasses of wine on the menu. Our food arrived much too fast and we were both surprised by that, especially in the case of my friend's fish dish. The presentation was completely unremarkable (piece of fish slabbed on a pile of greens in my case). Taste was ok but not memorable. My friend's fish was bland and had no crunch/crust which I would have expected from a pan-fried fish. Overpriced at $18.95. We had a great time regardless, catching-up with each other  but when a bus boy wanted to clear my plate (that still had some fish and salad on it) and I told him that I was still eating, he shrugged his shoulders in disbelief as if to say "There is a line out the door, eat up". Our waiter talked us into ordering the tiramisu which was a large portion but not remarkable either. According to our waiter it was the best dessert on the menu and that has me worried. There was a strange $2.60 "service charge" on our bill of $65 but we didn't bother to ask what it was (SF health coverage charge??). At $42 per person (including tip) I felt this place is overpriced and also a bit overrated. Next time I want  authentic Italian food at lunch time in the FIDI, you will find me at Perbacco.
author: Heike H.
